Battles Loom for Control Of TV's Portal to Cable
description: The unobtrusive cable control box that sits atop many television sets is about to become a new battleground for the nation's computer, telephone and cable television companies. The ultimate prize: control of the access to all the video entertainment and new types of electronic information that enter and leave the home.

title: Unemployment Dips Below 10% in New York City
description: Mainly as a result of fewer people seeking jobs, the unemployment rate for New York City fell to 9.6 percent in March from 11.3 percent in February, according to Government data released yesterday. It was the first month since last April that the rate has been below 10 percent.

title: JUSTICES PAVE WAY FOR ABORTION LAW
description: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for North Dakota to begin enforcing an abortion law that requires women to wait 24 hours after a counseling session before they can have an abortion.

title: Two Insurers Deny Charge Of Sales Bias
description: California's two largest auto insurers today denied charges by the state's insurance commissioner that they were deliberately selling fewer policies in low-income Los Angeles neighborhoods than in higher-income areas.

title: Hedging Earlier Defense, Agency Chief Admits Waco Raid May Have Been Flawed
description: The head of the Federal agency that conducted a raid on a cult near Waco, Tex., on Feb. 28 today revised his earlier descriptions of the operation in which four agents were killed and conceded it might have been flawed.

Baseball MLB EXECUTIVE COUNCIL -- Suspended Jose Mesa, Cleveland pitcher, and Hal Morris, Cincinnati first baseman, for three games and fined them undisclosed amounts or their parts in a fight on March 30. American League

title: Review/Circus; Three Rings' Worth of Thrills, Spills, Frills
description: That glorious gallimaufry the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus is back in Madison Square Garden with a spectacle that celebrates the 200th anniversary of circuses in America. The country's first circus was a one-ring presentation in Philadelphia in April 1793. The show that continues through May 2 at the Garden is a three-ring event, a heartwarming hodgepodge that justifies the traditional billing of "The Greatest Show on Earth."

title: Collins & Aikman Group Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Jan 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 226,435,000, which included restructuring costs and loss contingency reserves related to employee, legal and environmental liabilities of $ 23.1 million. title: Article 269693 -- No Title
description: The budget agreement in Albany that gives the Metropolitan Transportation Authority virtually all of the $9.6 billion it requested for a rebuilding program over the next five years promises a smoother trip for mass-transit riders in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Eugenie Leontovich, 93, Actress, Playwright and Teacher, Is Dead
description: Eugenie Leontovich, an actress, playwright, director and teacher who created memorable roles on Broadway in "Grand Hotel," "Twentieth Century" and "Anastasia," died yesterday at the Kateri Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: DF&R Restaurants Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from cumulative effect of accounting change of $ 305,000, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months.DF&R Restaurants, which went public in January, also reported pro forma earnings figures, as if the company were subject to income taxes for each period, and without the effect of the accounting change.The company said its pro forma net income for the latest third quarter was $ 632,000, or 14 cents a share, compared with $ 421,000, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Its 9 months' earnings totaled $ 1,572,000, or 38 cents a share, compared with $ 1,167,000, or 29 cents a share, in the comparable year-ago period.

title: U.N.L.V. Regent Seeks Maxson's Resignation
description: A university regent has called for the resignation of ROBERT MAXSON, president of the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, saying his ability to lead "has been irretrievably lost" because of recent problems.

title: Big Selloffs in Stock and Bond Markets; 30-Year Treasury At 7.05% as Rally Appears Capped
description: Interest rates surged yesterday, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond above 7 percent, as new employment figures intensified the market's concerns about inflation.

title: Westchester's Executive Faces New Accusations
description: Questions about the ethics of County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke multiplied today when he acknowledged that he sought a job for his son-in-law and an admission interview for his daughter at New York Medical College, which has a $14.6 million contract to furnish doctors to the county hospital.

title: Another Scuffle; Knicks Win Ugly
description: The Knicks were neither kinder nor gentler tonight. However, when tempers became short with the Miami Heat, the Knicks showed enough restraint to avoid another brawl, or another loss.

title: Theater Wing Seminars
description: Stephen Rea, Martin Short, Bill Irwin, David Shiner, Robert Klein, Jeff Daniels and Christopher Durang are among the actors scheduled to participate April 27 in a seminar on performance sponsored by the American Theater Wing. Isabelle Stevenson, president of the Theater Wing, will be chairwoman of the discussion, which will take place at 11 A.M. at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, 33 West 42d Street, Manhattan. The author and critic Brendan Gill and the producer Jean Dalrymple will be co-moderators. The Theater Wing will also hold a seminar on playwrights and directors on April 28 and one on production on April 29. Admission to all will be free. The seminars will be broadcast six times each week on CUNY-TV cable channel 75 in the five boroughs. Information: (212) 765-0609.

title: Opel Gets Court to Bar VW From Luring Its Managers
description: Adam Opel A.G., the German subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, was granted a temporary injunction today prohibiting Volkswagen A.G. or its new production chief, who recently left G.M., from trying to hire Opel employees.

title: Big Selloffs in Stock and Bond Markets; Tobacco Shares Pull Others Down; Dow Loses 68.63
description: The stock market fell sharply yesterday, pulled down by plunging tobacco shares and rising interest rates.

title: Environment One reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Environment One previously had reported unaudited earnings for 1992 of $ 471,000, or 12 cents a share.

title: Albania's Independence
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Fund Reporting Can Get Complicated
description: ALTHOUGH mutual funds are intended to make investors' lives easy by turning financial decision-making over to professional managers, matters can become complicated when investors wear a different hat -- taxpayer.

title: COLUMBIA GAS REORGANIZATION PLAN EXTENDED
description: Columbia Gas Systems Inc. said yesterday that a Federal bankruptcy court had extended the date it has exclusive rights to file a reorganization plan until July 23. The natural gas pipeline company, which has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors since July 1991, asked the court last month to extend the deadline, which was originally yesterday. After the company's exclusive filing deadline passes, creditors may submit reorganization plans to the court. Columbia Gas's reorganization has been disrupted by a variety of legal issues, including whether $1.7 billion in debt securities held by one of its pipeline units should be counted as loans or capital contributions.

title: Questa Oil & Gas reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MedChem Products reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Jacor Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 688,000.c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $ 1,832,000, or $ 4.51 a share.The company said that the 1992 results included charges against income of $ 7,082,263 resulting from the early termination of an interest rate protection agreement and $ 8,600,000 resulting from the reduction in carrying value of certain assets to their net realizable value. The sale of radio stations WMJI and WYHY in January 1991 resulted in a gain net of income taxes aggregating $ 11,933,527.

title: Family Dollar Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Rangers Stay in Fifth, Getting Ready to Say Fore!
description: If the Rangers pack up and go home on April 17, the day after the regular season ends, this will be the game that haunts them. They will be on the golf course, or in the backyard in a lawn chair, or passing pucks to little kids at some hockey camp, and they will think about last night. They will think about the Islanders, and they will grit their teeth and close their eyes and probably feel just a little bit sick.

title: W. Rice Brewster, 94, A Corporate Lawyer
description: W. Rice Brewster, a New York lawyer specializing in corporate law and business finance, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. A resident of Manhattan, he was 94.

title: Lawsuits Seek to Ban Smoking in Fast-Food Restaurants
description: In what legal experts say is the first case of its kind, three mothers of children with asthma have filed lawsuits here to try to ban smoking in the nation's fast-food restaurants, arguing that smoke in the air violates their children's civil rights under the Federal Americans With Disabilities Act.

title: BOSNIAN SERBS' PARLIAMENT RULES OUT MEDIATORS' PLAN AS BASIS FOR PEACE ACCORD
description: Shunning appeals for moderation from their leader and the Yugoslav Government in Belgrade, the parliament of Bosnia's Serbian nationalists tonight rejected even a conditional acceptance of a peace plan already approved by the country's two other warring factions.

title: How Do Your Garden Vegetables Taste?
description: To the Editor:

title: Unilab Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $ 2,121,000, or 5 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net income and included extraordinary gain of $ 1,690,000, or 5 cents a share, from net operating loss carryforward.Latest year's results are after payment of preferred stock dividends of $ 1,607,000, and 1991's results are after $ 2,126,000.The latest year included nonrecurring charges of $ 90,377,000, including $ 78.3 million recorded during the fourth quarter primarily associated with the write-off of intangible assets and goodwill, and $ 12.1 million due to problems resulting from the billing system conversion in northern California.

description: b-Included a provision of $ 14,850,000 relating to the company's ongoing dispute with the Health Care Financing Administration and a charge of $ 2.9 million for restructuring costs, which consisted principally of severance payments to terminated employees and cost and expenses associated with the closing of certain of the company's home infusion branches.c-Net incomeYear-ago results ended Sept. 30; company changed its fiscal year to Dec. 31 in October 1991.

title: Japanese Consortium Backs Motorola on Satellite Phones
description: Motorola's ambitious plan to provide a global satellite-based telephone service got a crucial endorsement today when an upstart Japanese telephone company with some powerful backers announced that it was organizing a consortium to invest in the project.

title: Observer; Serving Humble Pie
description: Listening to experts on the health-care problem is like reading computer manuals. Their brilliance is obvious and indisputable, and I for one -- I won't speak for you -- can't understand a thing they say. This leaves a person feeling melancholy, as well as stupid.

description: b-Included extraordinary income of $ 1.2 million, or 12 cents a share, from the sale of a 50 percent interest in Eastern European operations.

description: b-Net income

title: At Impasse on Jobs Bill, Senate Quarrels Instead
description: Frozen in filibuster just 42 days into its legislative year, the Senate dropped all pretense of debating President Clinton's jobs bill today and instead fell to squabbling over whose foot is dragging most.

title: Murdoch Tells of $350,000 Weekly Deficits at The Post
description: Rupert Murdoch said yesterday that the problems of The New York Post were far worse than he suspected when he took over last Monday, with weekly deficits running to $350,000, not $250,000, and filthy premises, broken photocopiers and shortages of everything from newsprint and ink to reporters' notebooks.

title: Chance to Move Up, and Move In
description: To attract the hundreds of college graduates who tether themselves to headsets, at starting pay in the low to mid-20's, T. Rowe Price boasts of two other incentives.

title: Discounted Theater Tickets
description: More than 75 Off and Off Off Broadway theaters are offering discounts of up to 50 percent throughout the month as part of the Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York Third Annual Passports to Off Broadway program. For information on participating productions: (212) 768-1818.

title: Sulcus Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Call It a Rainout for Teams and a Delay for Perez
description: There was supposed to be an exhibition baseball game here today, but the outfield grass at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium was wet, the crowd was small, and the skies were threatening.

title: Accugraph Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company recently changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Aug. 31.

title: A Delius Premiere
description: "Sea Drift," an early work by Frederick Delius, is to be given its New York premiere at 8 tonight at Carnegie Hall by the New York Choral Society. Composed in 1903, the piece is a setting of a poem from Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass." The actor Carl Lumbly is to read excerpts from the poem before the musical work is played. The major work of the evening is Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana," for which soloists and a children's chorus are to join the 150-member choral group. Tickets are $13 to $40. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Care Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Arden Group (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 233,000 in the quarter and $ 932,000 in the year.c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 2,813,000 and $ 1,995,000, for the quarter and year, respectively, which both included adjustments taken in the fourth quarter consisting of a write-down of Omninote inventory by $ 1,562,000, a write-off of $ 555,000 of engineering costs attributable to the manufacture of Omninote equipment, and a write-down of facsimile machine inventory of $ 1,190,000.The year-ago periods also included an adjustment consisting of an increase of $ 988,000 in a reserve previously established with respect to anticipated future costs of carrying leased but vacant properties, to reflect added expenses expected to be incurred until such properties are either subleased or are terminated.

title: Need a Doctor? Shop Around.
description: Health care has become a big business, so I approach medicine like buying a car. First, know your needs and the market, then interview possible dealers. Later, assess the alternatives and make considered choices based upon the best available care, attitude and financial arrangement.

Tele-Communications Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 15 million in the latest year and $ 19 million in 1991.Tele-Communications attributed much of its net loss for the year to $ 52 million associated with the early extinguishment of SCI Holdings Inc.'s debt, in conjunction with the spin-off transaction whereby Storer Communications Inc.'s assets were distributed to the company in December 1992.

title: 1787 And 1993
description: Another revolutionary ripped up another Constitution 206 years ago. The Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia was faced with a fundamental problem. In 1787, America already had a Constitution: the Articles of Confederation of 1781, which required the unanimous consent of all 13 states to any amendment.

title: Depleted Nets Are No Match for Bulls
description: At one point during New Jersey's game with the Bulls tonight, Doug Lee, fresh out of the Continental Basketball Association, where he played with those ferocious La Crosse Catbirds, had the responsibility of guarding Michael Jordan. Might as well give Jordan a police escort to the basket. Several dunks and jump shots later, Lee was left shaking his head and the injury-plagued Nets were left in the dust, losers by 118-105.

description: b-Net lossc-Net income

title: Final Four: It's Prime Time, Bay-Bee!
description: ALARM CLOCK TIME While the Final Four starts at the appropriate time of 5:42 P.M. today and should end by 10 P.M., CBS is unconscionably starting Monday's title game at 9:22 P.M. Presumably, the network wants us to receive two "Evening Shade" reruns, and neither is the one with a topless Charles Durning. The start time is 40 minutes later than the already too-late World Series schedule on CBS. Maybe things will be better when David Letterman is around next season. JUST FOR FUN, MAKE BELIEVE YOU'RE BRENT MUSBURGER Turn down the sound at game time tonight, do your tortoise-shell glasses and proclaim, as Brent once did, so often: "You are looking LIVE at the Louisiana Superdome..."

title: Not Man of Hour or Minutes
description: As Greg Anthony returned from his five-game suspension tonight, questions still remained regarding the Knick point guard.

title: American Greetings (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
From Calvin Klein, the Barest Essentials
description: Here are a few scenarios.

title: Review/Music; Interpretations of Bach, One Orthodox, One Not
description: How quaint the ponderous arguments that once surrounded the "authenticity" movement now seem! As two performances of Bach's B-minor Mass showed this week, theories about performance practice will always be less important than the practice of performance. It was irrelevant whether original instruments were used or not, whether ensembles were small or large, whether Bach would have liked such performances or not. Nothing could have been predicted about the results, and nothing about the results was consistent, other than the presence in each performance of individual moments of musical insight.

title: Billups Pleads Innocent
description: Former Cincinnati Bengals defensive back LEWIS BILLUPS pleaded not guilty yesterday to two Federal charges that he made telephone calls threatening REX CHAPMAN of the Washington Bullets.

title: Over 250 Fugitive Moments, Frozen in Time
description: An event of cardinal importance in the museum world was the opening just over a week ago of "The Waking Dream: Photography's First Century" at the Metropolitan Museum. This is the debut under its own flag of the museum's newly formed department of photography, and it deals on the grand scale with a period of some 50 or 60 years in the second two-thirds of the 19th century during which the possibilities of human perception were extended beyond all expectation.

title: Driver Education Exceeds the Basics, Attracting Japanese
description: The classroom topic at Sacred Heart High School in Yonkers one recent day was ergonomics, the science of designing a workplace to meet people's needs. But this was not a science class. The course was driver education, and the workplace in this case was a car.

title: Don't Promise the World
description: OUT OF CONTROL Global Turmoil on the Eve of the Twenty-First Century. By Zbigniew Brzezinski. 231 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $21.

title: U. of Virginia Considers Wide Ban On Intimate Teacher-Student Ties
description: The University of Virginia is considering a ban on sexual liaisons between professors and students, which one university administrator called higher education's "dirty little secret."

title: Tacos, Tequila and Taxes
description: Willie Nelson's television spots for Taco Bell's new line of steak burritos and tacos may seem fairly cheesy, but they are part of a well-orchestrated promotional campaign that coincides with the release of Mr. Nelson's "Across the Borderline." The fast-food chain is offering specially priced cassettes with certain purchases; and the Jose Cuervo tequila company, sponsor of the singer's forthcoming concert tour, is giving away "Willie Nelson signature shot glasses" by mail.

title: Added Color
description: IMAGINATIVE COLORS HAVE A RIGHTFUL PLACE IN AN artist's studio, just as brightly hued flowers are expected in a garden. But in the painter Robert Dash's garden on eastern Long Island, much of the color comes, surprisingly, from chimerically painted accents.

title: Sports of The Times; No Underdog Ever Wins Final Four
description: THE Final Four. It's so big now. Dean Smith can remember when he couldn't give away his two competitor's tickets in 1952, but now it's an annual convention of biggies. No underdogs, no outsiders, no Sycamores need apply.

title: Six Screens, With Melted Butter
description: Philip Thomas lives in Newark, and now he can walk to the movies.

title: No Wonder Strauss Was Deaf To Debussy
description: After Richard Strauss attended a performance of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," a friend explained the audience's dismay: "There are musical phrases, but they are not stressed or underlined so that the general public notices them." Strauss replied: "Yes, but I'm a musician, and I can't hear anything."

title: You're an Unlikely Hero, Charlie Brown
description: It was a surprise for the batter -- and the cartoonist. Charlie Brown not only hit a home run last week, he won a game. Breaking a losing streak that goes back to when baby boomers were babies was no April Fool's joke. But Charles Schulz, who has been drawing "Peanuts" since the 1950's, said the homer just happened. First he drew a panel that showed Charlie turning somersaults and shouting, "I was the hero!" Then he worked out the rest. The record books will show that the losing pitcher was the great-granddaughter of Roy Hobbs. Never heard of the mythic home-run king in Bernard Malamud's novel "The Natural"? Neither had Charlie's sister Sally. What's next for "Peanuts"? Will Schroeder forsake Beethoven for 2 Live Crew? Will the kite-eating tree go vegetarian? Will Snoopy trade his Sopwith Camel for a Stealth fighter? Will Charlie even break .500? Experts doubt it. "I don't mean to knock his skill," said Clark Gesner, who wrote the musical "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown," "but his average is not very good."

title: Foreign Affairs; Plotting To Sell Reform
description: Not so long ago, Boris Yeltsin was Communist Party boss in Sverdlovsk and Bill Clinton was Governor of Arkansas. Now both country pols have made good: the back-slapping Russian bear and the bear-hugging American. And now they are binding their fortunes and futures in Vancouver, the Russian plotting to survive and the American to succeed in a place appropriately much closer to Washington than to Moscow -- and at a meeting it is no longer fitting to call a summit.

title: The High Cost of a Dream
description: WHAT REMAINS AND OTHER STORIES

title: Environmentalist Who Sets His Own Agenda
description: Will the real Richard L. Amper Jr. [ Letters, March 7 ] please stand up.

title: Growing Numbers Seek Out Alternative Medicine
description: For four years Lilia Telberg complained to her doctors about unrelenting fatigue. Her blood count was low, and her blood pressure was high.

title: Juvenile Gala, Very Animated
description: EVERY string in town had been pulled for the "Bunny Hop" benefit for the pediatric day hospital at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, which was held at F.A.O. Schwarz on Wednesday night. "I'm good friends with Christine and Austin Hearst and they own Popeye, Betty Boop and Olive Oyl, so that's how we got them," said a chairwoman of the event, Courtney Arnot, a young mother and the wife of Dr. Bob Arnot of CBS News. "Also, the man who invented the Ninja Turtles once stayed at Sloan-Kettering, so he donated them to us."

title: 'McFirm' Needs a Better Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: A Season Boils Down To Sweetness and Sales
description: "PUT on the fog lights," said Jo-Ellen Servilla. Smoke from two evaporators filled the Rock House Maple Syrup Sugar house in Easton recently as they boiled 120 gallons of sap into three gallons of syrup.

title: At A.C.L.U., Free-Speech Balancing Act
description: Maybe there was a time in the history of the American Civil Liberties Union when the issues it grappled with and the positions it took were straightforward. But that has not been so for a long time and certainly not this weekend as its members enacted after vigorous debate (always vigorous in the A.C.L.U.) a new policy on sexual harassment.

title:
IN SHORT/BASEBALL;
The Girls of Summer
description: One cloudy afternoon in April 1931, Jackie Mitchell, a 17-year-old minor leaguer, took the pitcher's mound against the Yankees in an exhibition game in Chattanooga, Tenn. Mitchell struck out Babe Ruth on four pitches, then Lou Gehrig on three. Mitchell's feat is little remembered; even less remembered is that the remarkable pitcher was a woman. Such a fate has been all too common, Barbara Gregorich observes in WOMEN AT PLAY: The Story of Women in Baseball (Harvest/Harcourt Brace, paper, $14.95). Women have been playing the sport since students at Vassar College formed two teams in 1866. Two decades after professional baseball began in 1869, women formed "base ball clubs," nicknamed the Bloomer Girls. For the next 40 years, these teams barnstormed across the United States, playing men's semiprofessional and minor league teams in exhibition games. The teams were a victim of the Depression, Ms. Gregorich writes, as women were pushed into softball, "a game significantly less expensive and less difficult to play." During World War II, Philip K. Wrigley organized the All-American Girls Baseball League, which inspired the recent movie "A League of Their Own"; the league lasted 12 seasons, until 1954. The book concludes with profiles of two women who attempted unsuccessfully to become major league umpires, Bernice Gera and Pam Postema. Ms. Gregorich has written a novel about baseball, "She's on First," but her writing here is frequently wooden. Nevertheless, she is to be commended for bringing out of obscurity such baseball pioneers as Maud Nelson, Lizzie Arlington, Amanda Clement and Alta Weiss.

title: Mother Is Accused Of Scalding Son, 10
description: A Bronx mother frustrated by her 10-year-old son's performance at school disciplined him by stabbing him in the hand and scalding him with water on the arms and back, the police said yesterday.

title: Japan's Recession Felt in the County
description: FOR Kumiko Buller, a real estate agent who works for Ye Village Realty in Dobbs Ferry, a particular three-bedroom Colonial in Irvington had always been an easy rental property to offer to relocated Japanese executives who sought her services. That house's location near the train station and the elementary school made it desirable -- and as soon as one Japanese family returned to Tokyo, Mrs. Buller could count on a waiting list of clients.

title: Aiding Russia: Plant the Right Seeds
description: AS Bill Clinton holds discussions with Boris Yeltsin that are now more urgent than ever, Mr. Clinton needs to remember a fundamental law of business: put your money where the yield will be highest.

title: World Markets; Italy's Scandal Scares Investors Away
description: AS Italy's leaders in Rome confront a corruption scandal of huge proportions that has stripped away all sense of political direction, the outlook for the country's foreign exchange and government bond markets remains bleak.

title:
MUSIC;
Rarely Seen Stravinsky Opera Offered
description: There is a good chance that most people attending this month's performances of "The Rake's Progress," by Stravinsky, will never before have seen the opera. That's fine with Glenn Parker, director of the Westminster Opera Theater, who will direct the production.

title: Truly Modern Filibuster: Choreographed Gridlock
description: On what was supposed to be an off day, the Senate came to work this morning just long enough to certify that it cannot agree to vote on President Clinton's jobs bill, to register a few political accusations and to plot its next battle.

title: Caviar Distributor and 2 Fishermen Charged With Evading Limits on Scarce U.S. Roe
description: A prominent New Jersey caviar distributor and two Washington State fishermen have been indicted on charges of conspiring to illegally market sturgeon roe, the prized eggs used to make caviar. Following a trail of falsified documents and high-priced fish eggs, Federal investigators said, they found poaching and mislabeling in a mysterious industry that produces one of the world's most expensive foods.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-15 SUMMIT OPENS WITH U.S. OFFER

title: Hate and Fear in the Gay Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: At a New Gallery, Seven Different Approaches to Portraiture
description: The art scene continues uncertain, yet the new galleries keep coming. Phoenix Group, at 247 Main Street here, is the third one to be visited by this reviewer in as many months. And a snappy setup it is, too, installed in the ground floor of a clapboard house, complete with Ultra Era white interior, polished wood floors and, in back, space to park three or four cars.

title: Wall Street; Nudged by Bullion, Gold Stocks Sprint Higher
description: GOLD showed signs of life last week, with the London price of bullion rising $7.40 to $340.10 per ounce. But that was old news to owners of gold stocks. Those stocks tend to be much more volatile than the underlying metal, reflecting the fact that when bullion goes up in price, the profits of gold mining companies can go up by a much larger percentage. (The bad news is that profits also decline farther when prices fall.)

title: Impact Fees Re-Examined in California
description: There is no receptionist at the front desk of the Riverside County Planning Department. A revolving sign assures visitors that "someone will be with you in a few moments." Another notes that the agency is closed every other Friday. Just beyond is a cavernous open area filled with empty desks.

title: Where Discipline and Confidence Meet
description: EARLY in the Tiny Tots Intermediate competition, it became clear that the contest was shaping up as a confrontation between Jarrael Stevens, a third grader in Norwalk, and Jaclyn McCaffrey, a brown-haired pixie from the Bronx.

title: POSTINGS: On the East River; Design for Middle Income
description: Four towers designed by Cesar Pelli anchor a major development on a vast waterfront site in New York. It sounds like Battery Park City, but the description could apply to the Queens West project in Hunters Point.

title: Peru Moves Rebel Leader to a High-Security Cell
description: Abimael Guzman Reynoso, mastermind of the Shining Path guerrilla movement, was transferred today from a temporary Pacific island prison to a specially constructed underground cell where he is to spend the rest of his life.

title: Amy S. Goldman, Jonathan Cohen
description: Amy Susan Goldman, an assistant merchandiser at Brooks Brothers in New York, was married yesterday evening to Dr. Jonathan Charles Cohen, a clinical psychologist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in White Plains. Rabbi Judah Miller performed the ceremony at Temple Brith Kodesh in Rochester.

title: THE FOREIGN POLICY MACHINE
description: I was delighted to read Mark Danner's incisive analysis of George Bush's foreign policy failures ("How the Foreign Policy Machine Broke Down," March 7). Danner fearlessly points out that "enthusiastic appeasement followed by diplomatic bumbling forced the country to send its young to needless military action" in Panama and Iraq.

title: Don't Rush to Judgment in Trade Center Blast; Abused the Privilege
description: To the Editor: In "Tirades and Sympathy" (Op-Ed, March 27) John Hockenberry makes a misguided attempt to humanize one of the World Trade Center bombing suspects. If guilty, Mahmud Abohalima is one who has abused the privilege of living in this country: more to the point, he is a malicious killer.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Inner-City Families as Instructors
description: MEDICAL anthropology students at Case Western Reserve University are learning the realities of inner-city health care by studying with the experts -- inner-city mothers.

title: Capturing the Butterfly
description: The new Venezuelan passport identified the woman as Nora Estrella Ramirez, but most people in Caracas knew her by a Hebrew name, Mihal Kourany. She had turned up in Caracas in late 1984, and moved into a small apartment in Altamira, an affluent neighborhood at the foot of the mountains a few blocks above the American Embassy. She had begun working as a foreign-exchange money broker, doing business with a number of major banks. She had clients and friends in Brazil and planned to move to Sao Paulo eventually.

title: Longer Drumbeats For Lithium Battery
description: ONE line that lets you know you're dealing with a revolutionary battery is "Best if used by 2002." It's the first thing that catches one's attention on the plastic bubble pack of a pair of 1.5-volt AA Lithium Energizer brand photo cells now surfacing in the marketplace. Next year's batch will read "Best if used by 2003." And so on.

title: A Shift of Focus on Abortion Law
description: There have been few more graphic symbols of the anti-abortion movement's power than the Hyde Amendment, a nearly total ban on Federal financing of abortions for poor women. It has endured for 16 years, in one version or another, with substantial bipartisan support and the backing of three Presidents.

title: The Gun Lobby Is on the Run
description: When New Jersey reverses itself and defeats a measure sponsored by the National Rifle Association that would overturn a ban on assault weapons, you know something is happening. And when Virginia, the home to hundreds of thousands of hunters and gun owners, passes a tough new gun control law over the N.R.A.'s strong objections, you know something very big is happening: the gun lobby is on the run.

title: Not All Can Walk Again
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BASEBALL SAVED US By Ken Mochizuki. Illustrated by Dom Lee. Unpaged. New York: Lee & Low Books. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: New Jersey Network Holds Its Own
description: The New Jersey Network, the state-owned television system, which less than a year ago was threatened with extinction as the Legislature cut its financing and legislative leaders proposed selling its stations, is back from the financial brink.

title: Sightings Of the King, Etched in Glass
description: Bertelsmann AG plans to add a touch of Graceland to its new U.S. headquarters at 1540 Broadway (45th Street). The German media conglomerate, which owns RCA Records and Doubleday Books, will install a 9-foot-high Elvis Presley triptych in the lobby when the building opens in June.

title: MARCH 28 - APRIL 3: Regulating Communications; The F.C.C. Gives A Sharp Blow To Cable TV Prices
description: It has been a long time since the Government hammered a business as hard as the Federal Communications Commission did last week, when it ordered cable television companies to cut prices by more than $1 billion a year. The rules, adopted to put in practice a law passed by Congress last year, sent the stocks of some big cable companies tumbling by 20 percent over two days.

title: Beth Rubin and Mitchell Hofing
description: Beth Sharon Rubin, a daughter of Herbert Rubin of Brooklyn and the late Lillian Rubin, was married last evening to Mitchell Herman Hofing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney L. Hofing of Yardley, Pa. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Bosnia Vows All-Out War If Serbs Don't Sign Accord
description: The Bosnian Government warned today that it would abandon the shaky cease-fire here and resume full-scale war against Serbian nationalist forces if the West failed to press the Serbs into signing a peace accord that has already been accepted by the country's other two factions.

title: Skillful Students Offer Money-Saving Ideas
description: THE economic turnaround has not yet caught up with many county residents who are still looking for ways to save money rather than spend it. For those willing to sacrifice prompt delivery of services for substantial savings, programs offered by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services at regional Technical and Occupational Education Centers can pay off. The centers offer services ranging from automobile and computer repairs to carpentry, floral design, catering and haircuts, performed by high school students, young adults and displaced workers looking for opportunities to try out new vocational skills.

title: MARCH 28 - APRIL 3: Bosnia; A Small Start Against War Crimes
description: By most standards, it was a flawed trial -- just one substantial piece of evidence, a confession by a man with a history of mental disturbance. But nearly five months after he ran into a Bosnian checkpoint outside Sarajevo, Borislav Herak was sentenced to death for his role in the Serbian "ethnic cleansing" of Muslims. A shocked courtroom heard him recount cutting Muslim prisoners' throats, machine-gunning Muslim families, raping and killing 10 young Muslim women held captive. He effectively condemned his partner in the dock, Sretko Damjanovic, 32, who confessed but then recanted, saying he had been beaten. Unless saved by appeal or reprieve, the two Serbs could become the first soldiers in the Bosnian war to be legally executed.

title: The Answers
description: 1. False. In the early 19th century, centers of forestry education were established in many European nations.

title:
FILM;
Fact Meets Fiction In a Memory Tale
description: "I was a liar," Tobias Wolff wrote in "This Boy's Life," his acclaimed memoir of a difficult childhood in the 1950's. "I couldn't help but try to introduce new versions of myself as my interests changed.

title: College Majors Often Prove Minor
description: IN THESE judgmental times, when you are what you eat, wear and drive, it's comforting to think back on those simple days in college, when all you were was your major. On campus, a field of emphasis was a trusty Rorschach test: A declaration of electrical engineering meant a nerd with a pocket protector; business, a loud fraternity brother with a sweatshirt and loafers without socks; philosophy, a head-in-the-clouds intellectual who was disconnected from life.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Home Design/Magazine Part 2 Special Today: Education Life/Section 4A A special report examines the bolder breed of youth in the 90's. Also: * Adult students at alumni colleges. * A mixed message in black schools.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Reassigned Chad Ogea, pitcher, to Charlotte of the International League.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: JOE MORGAN A Life in Baseball. By Joe Morgan and David Falkner. Norton, $21.95.

title: Character Counts
description: SCREEN DOORS THAT ONCE BANGED SHUT ON porches in Maine are among the latest arrivals in a new wave of home accessories with weather-beaten beauty. Admiration for the crackled paint finishes on old kitchen chairs and the lively aniline dyes on the latest reproductions of rugged cupboards has brought what used to be considered Cinderella furniture into the limelight. Farm tables that have more than served their time -- or at least look as if they have -- are also being reappreciated, snapped up by a generation of urbanites who seem to be pining for a visit to Great-Aunt Fanny's attic.

title: At Last, the Gotham. In First, As Indicated.
description: After several blasts of winter and two postponements, they finally ran the Gotham Mile at Aqueduct yesterday, and the race turned into a roaring homestretch duel that was won in a photo finish by the Heatherwood Farm's As Indicated over the Brophy Stable's Itaka.

title: Ribicoff Talks Politics From Kennedy to Clinton
description: ABRAHAM A. RIBICOFF, who was first elected to public office in Connecticut 55 years ago, turns 83 on Friday, and he remains as active, physically fit and as up to date on state and national affairs as ever. "I want to work until the day I die," he said during a recent interview at his Litchfield County home. "When your mind is busy, your body is doing well," added the former United States Senator and Connecticut Governor who stays in shape with regular walks. The quiet-spoken, white-haired lawyer, who works five days a week as special counsel to the Manhattan law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, was first elected as a state legislator in the Connecticut General Assembly in 1938. Few can match his record of public service. He has served as legislator, a municipal judge, a Congressman, Governor of Connecticut (1955-61), a Cabinet member in the Kennedy Administration, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, and a United States Senator for three terms. After 18 years in the Senate, Mr. Ribicoff retired from public life in 1981 at the age of 71.

title: Richard N. Lander, 64, Historian And Ex-Westchester Jurors Chief
description: Richard N. Lander, the retired Commissioner of Jurors for Westchester County and also a local historian and church official, died on Friday at his home in Armonk, N.Y. He was 64.

title: Hate and Fear in the Gay Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Squabble Over Sponsorship Puts Unicef Bill in Jeopardy
description: The United Nations has its own inscrutable ways, but when it comes to the arcane protocols of governing bureaucracies, it may have met its match in Albany.

title: Donna Tempel, Andrew Lazarus
description: Dr. Donna Lynn Tempel, the daughter of Guenter Temple and Adrienne Krumbruch-Felicciardi, both of New York, was married on Friday to Andrew Scott Lazarus, the son of Theodore Lazarus of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Fredye Lazarus. Rabbi Phillip Hiat performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations in New York.

title: Now You See It, Now You Don't
description: "MORPH 1.1" (Macintosh): $149 list price, Gryphon Software Corporation, 7220 Trade Street, Suite 120, San Diego, Calif. 92121; telephone (619) 536-8815.

title: The Networks' Best-Laid Plans
description: The "television program development season" in Hollywood is like nothing so much as spring training in Florida: the sun is always shining, the breeze is full of the promise of summer, and every rookie looks like Willie Mays.

title: It's a Shop. It's a Club. It's the Latest.
description: ROMP, a three-week-old store in the NoHo section of Manhattan that sells what it calls "avant-garb," is indeed a romp through every current teen-age fashion trend. The store's name could stand for Really Old Memories Persist -- particularly memories of clothes from the 70's, like sharply flared bell-bottoms and zipper shirts with pointy collars and pull rings.

title: Fine Points Stall Budget In Albany
description: The prospects for passing a New York State budget by the end of the weekend dimmed somewhat today because of last-minute disputes over a variety of issues and because of a court decision that requires changes in the way appropriations bills are written.

title: The Voice That Defies De Klerk and Mandela
description: What white South Africans know best about the Pan Africanist Congress is its blood-curdling slogan -- "One settler, one bullet" -- and its secretive guerrilla brigade, the Azanian People's Liberation Army, which has managed with just a few clumsy terrorist attacks to awaken white nightmares of a race war.

title: How a Country Boy Snared a Money Man From the Big City
description: Two jets, a yacht, limousines, mansions, a Fifth Avenue office -- by the end of the 1980's, whatever money could buy, Steven Hoffenberg had.

title: Before the End of the World
description: TO GIVE THEM LIGHT

title: The One Night the 3's Just Wouldn't Go In
description: Kentucky fired 841 3-point shots this season; its opponents took 416. Kentucky made 333; its opponents made only 139. In four tournament games, Kentucky had fired 90 threes; its opponent, 55. Kentucky made 42; its opponents, 15.

title: Torborg's Dreams: Mets Search for a Unifying Theory
description: Fred Wilpon, the president of the Mets, walked across the organization's training complex in the Florida sunshine last month, his millions of dollars in investments exploding off of mounds and at the plate. The 1993 season was almost at hand, and the owner's mood was at once optimistic and mordantly mistrustful.

title: A New York State of Mind
description: New York style bubbles up from the bottom. It has nothing to do with what designers say. It crisscrosses cultures and eras. It combines old clothes and new. And most of all, it's personal. It's the way young New York breaks all the rules.

title: Kitchen Gadgets
description: Simple in function and form, these handy utensils are high in style but low in price: Many cost less than $5.

title: Amy Hoyt, J. A. Backstrom Jr.
description: Amy McAllister Hoyt, the marketing administrator for the Philadelphia law firm of Rawle & Henderson, was married yesterday to James Arthur Backstrom Jr., a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of North & Vaira. The Rev. Edwin R. Green officiated at the Wayne (Pa.) United Methodist Church.

title: Weicker's Capital Program: The Bridgeport Office
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has gained a reputation as a man who, travel as he may, likes to get home to his own bed in Albany and will undertake strenuous arrangements to make that possible. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, on the other hand, seems to want to move the capital to wherever he is, an equally strenuous proposition.

title: To Be Mentally Ill Doesn't Mean Raving
description: [ The following letter refers to a front-page article April 1 on the guilty plea by Sol Wachtler, former Chief Judge of New York State, to threatening to kidnap the daughter of his former lover. As part of the plea agreement, Mr. Wachtler was allowed to include in the court record a psychiatric diagnosis that concluded that Mr. Wachtler suffered from a form of manic depression known as bipolar disorder. After the hearing, Michael Chertoff, United States Attorney for New Jersey, insisted that Mr. Wachtler's behavior not be excused by mental problems. "This was not a man who was staying home in a bathrobe or going around like a screaming banshee," he said. ] To the Editor:

title: Disrespect Rules
description: WHEN Richard Wallman walks the halls of John Marshall High School in Rochester, he never knows what he might see or hear. There are students who look right through him when he talks. There are students who use obscenities when they tell him to get lost. There are students who threaten each other with weapons while he is in within earshot.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: IT'S GONE! . . . NO, WAIT A MINUTE . . . Talking My Way Into the Big Leagues at 40. By Ken Levine. Villard, $20.

title: Fitness Way Up in the Sky
description: THE first thing they did at the spa was convert me into numerical equivalents: Five foot seven, 127 pounds, 20.6 percent body fat, 14.8-inch "back flexibility," 63-pound bench press, 47 stomach curls in one minute and, intriguingly, 35 VO2 MAX ml./kg./min.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 21 about young Hollywood executives referred incorrectly to Elizabeth Guber's production company. It is Fried/Woods. The article also characterized a film company incorrectly. It is Largo Entertainment, an independent company with a distribution arrangement with 20th Century Fox and Universal.

title: Life in a Family of Nine Puppeteers
description: "Don't you feel silly talking to a dummy?" Jerry asked the visitor in his living room. When she nodded a bit sheepishly, he paused a moment for effect, then guffawed and said, "Well, so do I."

title: Jennifer Scruby, A. I. Ryshawy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Scruby of Orange Park, Fla., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Jennifer Lorraine Scruby and Alexander Ivan Ryshawy, the son of of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Ryshawy of Morristown, N.J.

title: Rangers Get Their Assignment: Skate Uphill
description: Neil Smith looked exhausted. His eyes were red, his shoulders were sagging and he looked as if he needed the wall to keep his head from falling. Obviously, he did not play hockey at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, when his Rangers lost to the Islanders, 3-2, in overtime. But he looked as drained as the players. That is what this season has done to anyone involved with the Rangers: exhausted them.

title: When Choreographers Bow to Older Dancers
description: WHEN DONNA UCHIZONO'S new evening-length work "The Sage's Passage" has its premiere on Thursday at the Kitchen, the audience will not be exposed to a typical display of downtown dance featuring sleek bodies and spiky haircuts darting through space. Ms. Uchizono's troupe is made up of two men in their 20's, two women in their 30's (including Ms. Uchizono), two women in their 50's, one man in his 60's and one septuagenarian. The four older company members, all professionals dancers, were recruited after a three-month search and dozens of phone calls.

title: U.S. Passport: New Antifraud Model Issued
description: People receiving United States passports, either new or renewed, in the next few weeks will be the first to get a new antifraud model.

title: Mansell Hurt in Crash During Practice Run
description: NIGEL MANSELL was injured yesterday in a crash during a practice session for today's Valvoline 200 Indy-car race at Phoenix International Raceway. The accident left Mansell hospitalized with a concussion that will keep the English driver from making his oval-racing debut.

title: The Big Lizard Needs Tender Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Movies
description: SATURDAY NIGHT MAY never be the same. Watching movies at home is now more popular than going out to movie theaters, a recent survey by the Electronic Industries Association found. And with a growing library of videodisks that includes cultural events as well as films, viewers have at least 7,000 more reasons for staying in.

title:
DINING OUT;
Dishes Prepared With Creative Flair
description: For years the area around Lawrenceville, with its venerable preparatory school, and Princeton, five miles away, has been long on sophisticated and cosmopolitan residents but lamentably short on sophisticated dining spots. Ph.D.'s may be a dime a dozen in Mercer County, but educated palates have generally had short shrift. And so the arrival of a delightful new restaurant called Acacia, across the road from the Lawrenceville School, is welcome news indeed.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THRIVING ARTISTS

title: Crime Pays For These Teachers
description: A darkened room. Gunfire. A dead body and a body of evidence. Whom do you call? The professor -- at least if you're dealing in fiction. That's Prof. B. J. Rahn of New York City's Hunter College.

title: Chasing Chairs
description: ISAAC MIZRAHI, FASHION designer and compulsive chair buyer, walked into Lubin Galleries, an auction house in lower Manhattan. From every corner of the showroom, chairs began singing to him, like Circes in slipcovers. "Why do I have this chair karma?" he asked, pausing before a tattered pair of 1950's swivel chairs. "I have 1,001 chairs. I need tables, lamps, andirons."

title: Florida Blazes Trail to a New Health-Care System
description: The Florida Legislature approved a sweeping overhaul of the state's overburdened health-care system early today, making Florida the first state in the nation to combine free market competition and government regulation in a way similar to the Clinton Administration's plans for controlling soaring medical costs.

title: Public & Private; Justice Made Easy
description: The President of the United States has a good deal to do this spring before he gets around to what will likely be the summer announcement of a nominee for the Supreme Court. He may not have decided yet who will get the job, but the question of how that person will be selected should be much on his mind.

title: Texas Tech Reaches Final With Ohio State
description: This was the height of impertinence: Sheryl Swoopes, the 6-foot forward for Texas Tech, hitting a fadeaway follow in the lane over Heidi Gillingham, the 6-10 center for Vanderbilt.

title: Special Music for the Easter Season
description: Easter week observances begin today, and church choirs and musicians on Long Island will explore the season musically. These are some highlights:Today

title: MARCH 28 - APRIL 3: Ireland; A Cry of Protest Against Violence
description: Officials in both Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic agree adamantly on one point: that, although they have been unable to end the civil war that has killed more than 3,000 people in the predominantly Protestant North since 1969, this does not mean there is an officially acceptable level of killing.

title: This Week's Numbers
Heating and Cooling the Geothermal Way
description: The steady hum of machinery and the presence of four massive drilling rigs rising 30 feet in the air are the first indications that something other than parking is going on at the site of parking lot No. 1 of Stockton State College.

title: Computer-to-Go Generation
description: EVER SINCE the start of the microcomputer revolution, educators and parents have entertained a fantasy ideal of a computer on every child's desk. But as schools become more technologically savvy, that idea is slowly evolving into a more practical notion of classrooms using a mixture of a few powerful desktop systems and many portable machines.

title: Don't Rush to Judgment in Trade Center Blast
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprise! Maryland Area Shakes With Quakes
description: When the ground shuddered and heaved under Jackie Richards's house one night last month, she awoke with a start and thought "someone took dynamite and blew up my front yard."

title: Industrial Stuttgart Has a Bucolic Side
description: STUTTGART is a large, rich and powerful industrial city; it is also cozily bucolic, almost pastoral, with vineyards sloping down to the main train station. This stimulating paradox helps to explain my own affection for Baden-Wurttemberg's dear old capital city, a mix of the irritatingly parochial and the vibrantly cosmopolitan.

title: Anne R. Lloyd-Jones, J. D. Calder
description: Anne Rutledge Lloyd-Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Lloyd-Jones of Stamford, Conn., was married on Friday to John David Calder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Calder of Cincinnati. The Rev. John Andrew performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Thomas Church in New York.

title: THE QUIZ
description: As humans turned to agriculture, they converted large tracts of woodland and jungle into farmland and grazing areas. Soon trees were being harvested for fuel and building materials, and later to produce pulp for paper and other print products. Most of us, however, know little about the forests and jungles that cover 37 percent of Earth's land surface. Check your forest knowledge quotient here.

title: A Summit to Discuss Mere Money
description: In the years that superpowers reigned supreme, summit meetings were awesome spectacles. Nations great and small would watch spellbound as two men with the power to pulverize the planet met to impose limits on their rivalry and delineate their empires. Their every utterance, their every handshake, their every signature had instant and fateful impact on millions of lives, and set billions of dollars in motion.

title: Hard Cash Versus Software
description: THE DEATH OF MONEY

title: After 6 Years, a Family Reaches Broadway
description: The scenario is familiar. A group of dedicated actors bands together. Ego aside and money unconsidered, they form a company for the love of theater and the purpose of ensemble, all the while juggling odd day jobs, parenthood and things like that.

title: Kelly Takes Job And Runs
description: Pat Kelly is 25 years old now. Not ancient, but he is no kid anymore either. He is starting his third major league season. Has it really been that long? It sure has. And the Yankees are still waiting for Kelly, still waiting for him to be their next great second baseman.

title: Where Musicals Find a Home
description: I was interested in the article "New Jersey, a Home for Musicals" (March 14), about how New Jersey's regional theaters are picking up the slack producing new musicals.

title: When a Careful Hand With Eggs Yields Intricate Folk-Art Designs
description: DOROTHY DISCKO of Darien attracts a lot of attention at the supermarket as she painstakingly goes through carton after carton of eggs to make sure the ones she purchases are smooth and shapely. She is not buying them to eat, but to use as an art material, the basis for pysanky, the Easter eggs decorated with designs and symbols that have been traditional in Ukraine since pagan times.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: BASEBALL IN THE AFTERNOON Tales From a Bygone Era. By Robert Smith. Simon & Schuster, $21.

title:
Middletown Journal;
Plan for Sports Complex in a Park Draws Fire
description: THE meeting would have made Ross Perot proud, Mel Slocum said. Close to 400 people showed up at Middletown High School North a few weeks ago to take an active role in their government.

title: Angela T. Bianco, Scott W. Smilen
description: Dr. Angela Teresa Bianco, a chief resident, and Dr. Scott Walter Smilen, an attending physician, both in obstetrics and gynecology at New York University Medical Center, were married last evening in Roslyn, L.I. The Rev. Joyce Fuchs-Gioia, a multidenominational minister, officiated at the Roslyn Country Club.

title: Alumni Colleges Bring Them Back
description: ALL YOU ADULTS who wish you had gone to an Ivy League or other hard-to-get-into college but never had the chance, take heed. It is not too late. For an intense summer week or two, you can sample what life is like on some of America's finest colleges by living there, attending classes, eating in dining halls and rubbing shoulders -- and minds -- with professors.

title: A Few Proposals on Auto Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Down on Death Valley
description: WE were two miles above Death Valley, on the narrow trail to Telescope Peak. "Watch out!" cried my wife. A man with wild hair and a manic grin was racing toward us on a mountain bike. We jumped aside. He nodded, his eyes ablaze with excitement and fear, and spurted away down the rocky path.

title: After Lost Seasons, Even Blank Slate Looks Good to 3 Teams
description: The Kansas City Royals did not expect to lose their first 7 games and 16 of their first 17. The Boston Red Sox did not expect to finish last for the first time since 1932. The Los Angeles Dodgers did not expect to finish last for the first time since 1905. A year ago today, these thoughts did not exist even in the most remote crevice of their minds.

title: Judgment Days
description: Just when you thought it couldn't happen here, it has come to pass. The telefonino -- the cellular phone, an emblem of Italy's rags-to-Rolex, Gucci-guzzling 80's -- has been pronounced, definitively, out . Not because of any worries about health hazards, but simply because cellular phones do what they always have done: attract too much attention.

title: FOUR FUTURES FOR RUSSIA
description: Russia is at a painful turning point, facing momentous alternatives but appearing powerless to make a deliberate choice. Its people stand at the junction of their authoritarian traditions and their novel experiment with political freedom; they hover between a state economy and a free market; they are simultaneously bound together and driven apart by their history and their current striving for a new identity.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Jersey City Waterfront's Hibernation Ends
description: A FOUR-YEAR dry spell in construction along Jersey City's waterfront soon will be broken as two developments of low-rise retail buildings take shape amid the residential and office towers. The projects will bring to the once industrialized riverfront a new dimension of retailing -- warehouse clubs.

title: A Spa That Plays in a Low Key
description: SOME spas have programs. They have ideologies. They know what their guests ought to become, and so they doggedly push them toward nirvana, even if it means policing every bite of food, every sliver of lemon peel unthinkingly dropped into tea. They have posters and leaflets and brochures and chirpy enthusiasts who are paid to provide that missing willpower.

title: Wait Till 'The End'
description: To the Editor:

title: Blankety-Blank! The Devils Shut Down by Maple Leafs
description: Just when it looked as if the Devils would play the first scoreless tie in their history, Doug Gilmour scored with 3 minutes 38 seconds left tonight to give Toronto a 1-0 triumph at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: Mardi Welch, T. P. Dickinson
description: Mrs. John H. Welch of Mount Kisco, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Martha Hayes Welch, to Townsend Penberthy Dickinson, a son of Mrs. Townsend B. Dickinson of Surry, Me., and the late Mr. Dickinson. A June wedding is planned.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
San Juan
description: Spring is always a good time to visit San Juan, but especially this year, with the hoopla of last year's Columbus quincentennial having died down, leaving behind new monuments and museums. Old San Juan is less crowded with cruise ship day trippers than during the winter, hotel rates begin to drop, and many hotels offer inexpensive summer packages to lure visitors during the slowest months.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Gambling on Success, and A Diploma
description: TEN years ago a former Chicago businessman, Donald F. Kuratko, began to teach a college course on a relatively novel topic: entrepreneurship. But he wanted to impart more than ivory-tower hypotheses. To understand entrepreneurs, Mr. Kuratko believed, students needed to feel the cold blast of risk-it-all reality. "You should go to bed at night and feel your spine sweat," he said.

title: Kangaroo Island
description: To the Editor: I am afraid that in describing the many delights of Kangaroo Island in Southern Australia ("An Island's Endearing Menagerie," Feb. 21), your writer might have done a disservice to readers by implying, in discussing guides and four-wheel-drive vehicles, that the tourist environment is more formidable than it really is. It is true that a substantial portion of the island's roads are unpaved (pea gravel) but they are smooth and easily traversed in a regular car.

title: My Paper Prison
description: For seven years, while I sat chained in a series of secret cells in Lebanon, millions of Americans felt themselves to be held hostage, too. They watched their Government stumble, lie, break laws and generally show itself unable to handle the dilemma forced on it by a tiny group of fanatical, fundamentalist Moslems in one of the Middle East's smallest countries.

title: The Children of the Shadows: Shaping Young Lives
description: They are the children of the shadows: the impoverished youth who live in the tumbledown neighborhoods of the American inner city; the children of often desperate and broken families, where meals are sometimes cereal three times a day; the young people who daily face the lures of drugs, sex, fast money and guns; the unnoticed youths who operate in a maddening universe where things always seem to go wrong.

title: In Killick-Claw, Everybody Reads The Gammy Bird
description: THE SHIPPING NEWS

title: Woodrow Swancutt, 77, General In Air Force and Atomic Test Pilot
description: Woodrow Swancutt, a retired major general in the Air Force who was a decorated World War II pilot and later flew the plane that dropped a test atomic bomb on Bikini Atoll, died on March 21 while walking near his at home in San Antonio. He was 77.

title: 13 Millionaires, 90 Losers
description: THE WORST TEAM MONEY COULD BUY The Collapse of the New York Mets. By Bob Klapisch and John Harper. 304 pp. New York: Random House. $21.

title: Chile Advances in a War on Poverty, And One Million Mouths Say 'Amen'
description: Adan Ramirez and his wife, Gladys Fuentes, say that in the 1980's, when their family income was $170 a month from his electrician's job, "we had to choose between eating and paying the bills." Then, in 1990, Ms. Fuentes borrowed $350 through a new Government program set up to help tiny businesses, bought an industrial sewing machine and began doing piece work for clothing manufacturers.

title: A Gay-Rights President Is at a Loss for Words
description: Barely five months after homosexuals converged in city streets to celebrate the victory of a Presidential candidate who had aggressively sought their support, some of those revelers are threatening to turn the gay and lesbian march here this month into a demonstration against Bill Clinton.

title: Clear Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title:
FILM;
Michael Palin's New Role: He's His Own Grandpa
description: Michael Palin has a bad reputation for being good. In all of show business, there is no more notorious victim of an obliging nature. The man is seriously helpful. You can't even miss his house in Gospel Oak, in north London, because a large photograph of Mr. Palin and three happy children is visible from the street through an upstairs window.

title: TriBeCa
description: WHAT: TriBeCa. It's more than a concept, less than an idea, somewhere between a location and a neighborhood. Commuters know it as the tangle of streets that don't give you any advantage at all in trying to beat the Holland Tunnel traffic. For most Manhattanites, it's all the streets they thought were in some other borough. Subway riders emerging at Franklin Street, confronted with street names like Varick and N. (for Nathaniel, not North) Moore, spin in a circle, then head off aimlessly and petition strangers for help.

title: . . . No Reading, Either
description: New York magazine celebrates its 25th anniversary with a dinner party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, March 30.

title: U.N. Panel Calls for More Peacekeepers in Bosnia
description: Meeting in emergency session today, the Security Council called for more peacekeepers in eastern Bosnia and condemned the Bosnian Serb military for besieging the eastern town of Srebrenica and barring deliveries of aid to the 60,000 civilians stranded there.

title: A Muse in Uniforms and Armor
description: The program at Christian Francis Roth's fall fashion show on Tuesday noted that the designer's inspiration was "rich girls," a far cry from his last show, which was all about grunge. No wonder he now refers to Sloan Lindemann, who has been his business partner and financial backer since February, as his "muse."

title: A Nicotine Fit Brings Down The Bull Market
description: EVERYONE knew that the Marlboro Man was lethal to many of his customers. But who thought he could kill a bull market?

title: MARCH 28 - APRIL 3: Egypt; The Fight Sharpens Against Fundamentalism
description: Egypt last week was in the grip of the Government's fiercest struggle in over a decade to crush the country's armed Islamic militant movement -- a campaign that amounted to a dangerous gamble by President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Mr. and Ms. Smiths: Don't Sell Out
description: In Frank Capra's 1939 movie classic, Jimmy Stewart, as an idealistic freshman senator, Jefferson Smith, fights for the concerns of ordinary voters against a cynical and corrupt Washington establishment and wins. Last fall, Americans sent 125 freshmen and freshwomen to Capitol Hill, the most in 44 years, hoping for a real-life remake.

title: Ms. Kauffman, Stephen Hollowell
description: May wedding plans have been announced by Dorothy Andrea Kauffman, who is the music department associate and a producer at WQXR-FM, and Stephen Alan Hollowell, the investigations manager at Mount Sinai Medical Center, both in New York.

title: From a Humble Sump, a Sanctuary
description: AN old drainage basin doesn't seem like much of a place to set up a bird sanctuary. But that's just what Hofstra University plans to do with the state-owned sump that runs under Hempstead Turnpike west of the New York Jets practice field in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Peter of Hunsbeck
description: LOITERING WITH INTENT

title: It's Impossible to Grow Just One Columbine
description: There is something about columbines. The flowers are so beguiling in form, they are sure to please. Their name was derived from the Latin columba, meaning dovelike, which refers to their shapely form.

title: L.I.E. Walls Constitute Visual Obscenity
description: This is yet another letter on the continuing saga of the "noise walls" on the Long Island Expressway [ "Expressway Noise Walls Disputed," Feb. 14, Letters, March 14 ] . I travel between my home in Glen Cove and the East End regularly. The great wall has made the two-hour trip less than pleasant.

title: Late-Night Drama Not According to Plan
description: THE Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, which ended a week ago, featured a series of late-night dramas. Most involved teams with one sponsor and four or five experienced professionals. The rules required each player to play at least half each match, so it was common to lose ground in the afternoon, while the sponsor was in action, and for the professionals to surge back at night.

title: Vile and Intolerable
description: To the Editor:

title: He Wasn't Supposed to End This Way
description: REMEMBERING DENNY

title: Their Stinky Little Secret
description: SMART HEARTS IN THE CITY By Barbara Probst Solomon. 337 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $21.95.

title: Conciliation Service Aids Mental Patients
description: ALMOST any hospitalized patient experiences a sense of helplessness and a loss of control. But for someone in a psychiatric unit those feelings can be intensified. And when such a patient has a question, a criticism or a major dispute about the treatment given by a mental-health-care provider, resolution of the complaint can be a problem.

title: Bolshoi Express Offers Rail Tour
description: The Bolshoi Express, a luxury steam train built in the 1950's and refurbished last year, will offer tours in the former Soviet Union between May 2 and Oct. 28. The Express had been used by high-level Russian officials; now, under the auspices of Cox & Kings, a 235-year-old London travel company, the train will carry tourists on four itineraries ranging from 10 to 14 days.

title: Susan Mazzola, H. M. Rodriguez
description: Susan Marie Mazzola, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Mazzola of Massapequa, L.I., was married there yesterday to Howard M. Rodriguez, a son of Lucy Torres of Rio Piedras, P.R. The Rev. Ronald A. Barry performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the St. Rose of Lima Church.

title: Where Do Musicals Come From?
description: THIS is the time for singing about musicals. Given a blitz of "Oklahoma!" nostalgia, it is difficult to avoid knowing that the Rodgers and Hammerstein classic opened on Broadway 50 years ago -- last Wednesday to the day. Another yearlong observance marks the centennial of Broadway itself, the theater district that has been traditionally defined by musicals.

title: Miss Kaufmann, Basil Battaglia
description: Sandra Kaufmann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl B. Kaufmann of Chadds Ford, Pa., was married yesterday to Basil R. Battaglia, a son of the late Bruno and Carmella Battaglia of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Allan Hohlt performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral Church of St. John in Wilmington.

title: Basketball Slavery
description: This final weekend of the N.C.A.A. tournament should be basketball's golden hour. The field is down to two teams from which the national champion will be crowned tomorrow.

title: Settling With The Airlines
description: SOME $400 million in airline discount vouchers are scheduled to be distributed to travelers under a settlement in a class-action suit charging nine airlines with price fixing. The settlement was approved by Federal District Judge Marvin H. Shoob in Atlanta on March 22.

title: Outer Space
description: The first time setsuo ito visited the Bridgehampton, L. I., site where his house now stands, the sun was setting over the Atlantic Ocean; when he turned east he could see the moon rising at the same time. So he bought the knoll and, on weekends over the next few years, camped out in a tiny hunter's shack hunched lopsidedly on the hillside, to get the feel of the light and the land. Then, combining his love of nature and of the purely abstract, the conceptual artist-turned-designer created his dream house: a multilevel complex that, from above, looks like a spanking new space station afloat in a green galaxy.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Seniors Lead Shared After burning up the Cochise Course at Desert Mountain for three days without breaking away from the pack, Gibby Gilbert wasn't certain who would win The Tradition in Scottsdale, Ariz. "Ten-under-par's not out of it," Gilbert said yesterday after he and Tom Shaw each birdied the 18th hole to drop to a 54-hole tournament record of 14-under 202 and took one-shot leads into the final round of the $850,000 tournament, the first Senior PGA major of the season. Mike Hill was at 203, with Dale Douglass and Tom Weiskopf at 204. (AP) A Surprise Leader: Greg Kraft, who has never finished higher than sixth in seven pro seasons, shot a three-under-par 69 and took a one-shot lead after 54 holes in the Freeport-McMoRan Golf Classic in New Orleans. Kraft was at four-under 212, a stroke ahead of Payne Stewart and Russ Cochran. (AP)

title: NOTES
description: The semiotics of lapels is becoming more complicated.

title: Right. Let's Make That 'Once Again, Kudos . . .'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mixed Message In Black Schools
description: AT WEEKLY chapel services for students at the Urban Christian Academy in Savannah, Ga., Nelson Mandela has been praised as a hero doing God's work, and South Africa's apartheid system excoriated as evil and sinful. But Priscila Dickerson says she found a different view of Mr. Mandela and his country in an independent-study workbook when she was an 11th grader at the school two years ago.

title: Sunset of the Golden Age for America's National Pastime
description: SOMEDAY, crouched over their keyboards in front of their interactive television sets, tapping out their instructions to the managers and their bets to Commissioner Rose's office, major league baseball fans will remember this 1993 season as the sunset glow of the golden age, when salaries were in check, morale and morality were high, and the pastime still reflected the myth of its grassy-sweet big innings.

title: After Years at the Top, There's Something to Prove
description: In their best years, at the zenith of popularity, just one name or nickname would be needed to set them apart from the best of the rest.

title: Mutual Funds; A Capital Quarter for Real Estate
description: CALL it Wall Street's nod of approval for the new occupants of the White House: a 3.3 percent rally for equity funds in the first quarter. At that pace, there would be double-digit returns for the year as a whole.

title: THE CAMPUS CRIME WAVE
description: As a university professor deeply involved in student discipline over the last 14 years, I write to underscore some of the points Anne Matthews makes in her article "The Campus Crime Wave" (March 7) and offer a few of my own. There has been a change in campus crime since the early 80's, and it doubtless has to do with the rise of student-on-student crime. Alcohol is indeed a factor in 90 percent of the cases. Raising the drinking age 10 years ago created enormous problems on campus while solving none: breaking the alcohol laws has simply become a more ingrained feature of campus culture.

title: Great Homes Series Offers Premiere
description: Apart from musical performances associated with church or synagogue, the conjunction of the Easter and Passover holidays severely curtails concert activity this week. Today's schedule, however, has some enticements, beginning at 2 P.M. when the pianist Mordechai Shehori joins the Bronx Arts Ensemble in a program including works by Handel, Mendelssohn, Chopin and Liszt. Also on the program is the world premiere of "Variations on a Sephardic Melody" by the Bronx-born Gerald Cohen.

title: Pretending to Be Ordinary
description: ELIZABETH BISHOP

title: A Controversial Man in an Eccentric Place
description: Mention Richard H. Glanton's name to any student or former student at the Barnes Foundation or to anyone connected with the art world or Pennsylvania politics, and you may hear a string of expletives that would make a longshoreman blush.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Georgetown
description: THE Wilsons are typical of many young adults who grew up in well-to-do Fairfield County. Thomas Wilson is from Westport, his wife, Susan, from Weston. Like many of their peers, they are rearing their first child, and cannot afford to live in either town.

title: There, They Could Say, Is the Jew
description: SHYLOCK

title: Day Later, Islanders Come Up A Goal Short
description: The energy was gone, expended the night before in Madison Square Garden. When the Islanders skated onto the Nassau Coliseum ice tonight, they looked tired, they looked flat, they looked as if they needed a night off.

title: An Asian-American Feels Deep Pain
description: "Asian-Americans Say They Are Treated Like Foreigners" [ March 7 ] provoked real sympathy, since I know what it is like growing up and living in this country as a third-generation Japanese-American. I am conscious of the fact that I am not always viewed as an American, or somehow less of an American because of my racial characteristics.

title: High-Tech Talk
description: I have dialed the future, and it has brought me, on a 3.3-inch Videophone screen, a regular-looking guy in a white shirt and a very dull tie. His name is Tom Burns, a service representative in the video services group of A.T.&T. He's in St. Louis, I'm in New York and the two of us are having a high-tech face-to-face. This is it, at last -- the telephone equivalent of the moving sidewalk, the monorail and space-food sticks.

title: Prescriptions and Time Running Out For Many Independent Pharmacies
description: Like the mom-and-pop grocery, the village bookshop and the neighborhood hardware store, small independent pharmacies are under siege. But unlike the pressure on other retailers, competition from large chains is only part of the problem.

title: 'I Want' Now Gets
description: POWER to the people. The little people, that is.

title: Kimberly K. Smith and Rick Miller
