The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. LP indicates that a book is available in large print.

title: Restrictions On Glen Cove Estate
description: I am the president of the Daniel Gale Agency, a residential real-estate organization, an exclusive affiliate of Sotheby's International Realty. We are assisting Sotheby's in the marketing of Salutation on West Island in Glen Cove. An item article in the Long Island Journal [ March 28 ] mentions that the the property can be subdivided or used as a conference center. We understand the property may not be further subdivided because of a prior deed restriction by the late Mrs. Morgan prohibiting any further subdivision of West Island as a whole. Also, any future use such as a conference center of Salutation, except as a single-family residence, must be approved by the West Island Home Owner's Association -- at present, an unlikely circumstance.

title: Rent Control
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day With Christine Whitman
description: AT 10:30 one recent morning, after a 40-minute drive from her family farm in Hunterdon County, Christine Todd Whitman called a meeting of her campaign staff in the People for Whitman headquarters in a modern office building in Clark.

title: Q and A
description: Climbing Mount Kilimanjaro

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
After 15 Years, Co-op for Poor
description: A $7.1 MILLION, 45-unit town-house project is under way in a poor section of the Dorchester neighborhood, financed by four area banks and city, state, Federal and union pension funds. The two- and three-bedroom complex, Lucerne Gardens, will start out as rental but become a co-op within 15 years, said Robin L. Berry, project manager for the developer, Winston/Lucerne.

title: Eve Michel and Alfred Milanese
description: Eve Musette Michel, the director of design for the New York City Economic Development Corporation, was married yesterday to Alfred Charles Louis Milanese, who heads the New York retail and distribution operation for Martin's Handmade Pennsylvania Dutch Pretzels. The Rev. Michael Donahue performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Church in New York.

title:
Viewpoints;
'Quality' Must Put Customers First
description: MORE than a decade ago, American business suddenly found itself far behind in the race for world-class quality. But if the wake-up call came late, it did come loud, and the response was revolutionary. A consultant caravan mobilized to cater to companies desperate for advice. All sorts of self-proclaimed gurus now sell their stuff, and companies are still buying.

title: Vietnam Poet Sings a Song Of Endurance
description: In South Vietnam before the Communist victory of 1975, Trinh Cong Son sang of the longing for peace in a divided country, the sorrow of war between brothers and the grief of mothers and sweethearts. He was the voice of the young and the bane of the Government.

title: A Certain Style
description: A chair, if it's the right one, can have it. So can a room, a house and possibly everything in it. Even a tree can be said to have it (though that is certainly not the first thing to consider when planting). Many people go happily through life without a trace of style. But just as many others are continually pleasured by their ability to create it or appreciate it.

title: Wendy Friedman, Roy Futterman
description: Theodore H. Friedman and Judge Eve Preminger of New York have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Wendy Kate Friedman and Roy Louis Futterman, the son of the late Drs. Edward and Sara Lee Futterman.

title: Rare Gold Baubles: Small, Ancient And Radiant
description: Gold was the metal Mycenaean nobles chose for rings the size of kumquats and belt decorations as showy as any cowboy's. Women also opted for gold in their necklaces, their enameled pendants and the ornaments that glowed on their gowns.

title: THE FOREIGN POLICY MACHINE
description: Until we amend the Constitution, we are fighting a losing battle as long as a President enjoys unchecked "the power to grant reprieves and pardons for offenses against the United States, except in cases of impeachment" (Article II, Section 2). This passage unintentionally fosters cronyism. A President can enlist his own appointees to act outside the law, then pardon them should an investigation get dangerously close to himself.

title: 8 Torahs Stolen Over a Half-Year Period
description: Eight Torahs, the hand-inscribed scrolls that stand as the Tree of Knowledge for Jews and are considered sacred second only to human life, have been stolen from synagogues in Manhattan in the last six months.

title: Louisiana Alligator, From Pies to Picante
description: IT'S a rare kind of swamp critter that doesn't suit the taste of a Cajun cook. Alligators are no exception. They have never been as popular or as sociallycorrect as crayfish, shrimp and oysters, which are, after all, smaller and easier to catch. But alligators have long been eaten in Louisiana's country houses and hunting camps in the coastal marsh lands. Now they are showing up on the menus of restaurants well outside Cajun country, even a few upscale places that don't pretend to be Cajun.

title:
END PAPER;
Down-Home Learning
description: "HEY, COME ON and play the piano with old man Mose!" With that, 75-year-old Mose Vinson plays a fast boogie-woogie tune, and the crowd of children gathers around the piano man. "They love it," he says. "Sometimes I take their little hands and play a song and place their fingers on the keys. I tell them to go home and practice what they've learned."

title: Commercial Property: Avenue of the Americas; From Corporate Corridor to Boulevard of Barristers
description: FOR years, Avenue of the Americas was called the Corporate Corridor. And for good reason: Street after street of look-alike buildings, headquarters to Exxon, J.C. Penney, W.R. Grace and other corporate stalwarts, stretched from the 40's to Central Park, spelled only by an occasional hotel.

title: The Challenge of a Monologue in the First Person
description: Making a career as a solo autobiographical performer seems an inherent contradiction: if what you do is talk about yourself, eventually all you'll have to talk about is talking, sure to drive an audience away. One solution may be to move on, in form and content -- once the personal ground is covered. Two performers whose work will be in repertory at the Joseph Papp Public Theater this month occupy positions at each end of this spectrum.

title: Cards and Phillies Vie for Top in 4-Team Race
description: This preview was prepared and written by Murray Chass. Teams are presented in alphabetical order and the starting lineups are his projections. Probable starters for the Mets appear on page 3. Relief pitchers listed are the closers.

title: Rio de Janeiro Battles Cholera
description: With cholera spreading through Latin America for the last two years, the city of Rio de Janeiro in Brazil reported its first cases last month. Health authorities in the city are working to prevent the outbreak -- fewer than 30 confirmed cases, and one death as of the end of March -- from spiraling into an epidemic.

title: Hate and Fear in the Gay Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline Ewing, Jonathan Crystal
description: Caroline Day Ewing, the daughter of Alexander C. Ewing of Winston- Salem, N.C., and Millbrook, N.Y., and the late Carol Sonne Ewing, was married yesterday to Jonathan Michael Crystal, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Crystal of Beverly Hills, Calif. The Rev. Anne Bolles-Beaven, an Episcopal minister, officiated at the Colony Club in New York. Rabbi Charles Lippman took part in the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: We've put Martin on this rotunda of irrelevant adulation and removed him from the struggle for economic justice. Somewhere along the line we managed to resurrect the messenger and bury the message. THE REV. JOSEPH LOWERY, on the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. [ 16:4. ]

title: Waiting for That Letter From Princeton
description: The letters are in the mail, and by tomorrow, the hundreds of high school seniors around the state who applied for admission to Princeton University will know their fate -- acceptance, or a message from the dean of admission that concludes, "We do appreciate your having had the interest and taken the time to submit an application."

description: PANDAEMONIUM

title: Irish Ex-Premier Hopeful for Ulster Accord
description: Life is not as exciting now for Garret FitzGerald as when he was Prime Minister of Ireland and persuaded Margaret Thatcher to give Dublin an official toehold in Northern Ireland for the first time since Ireland won independence from London in 1922.

title: The Most
description: There's nothing like a great buy, although what makes it great isn't always immediately apparent. Here are 12 household items, each a superlative example of its kind, whether it's the fluffiest, tiniest -- or even just the oddest.

title: You Gotta Work The Room
description: I HAVE been playing guitar in New York restaurants for more than a decade. To many of my classical musician friends, performing in a clattering, bibulous dining room is only one notch above strumming in the Union Square subway station.

title: WATCH CONGRESS SQUIRM
description: Elizabeth Drew, like many writers on campaign finance, misstates the problem ("Watch 'Em Squirm," March 14). It's not that special interests have too much power; representing interests is what elected officials in a democracy are there to do. The problem is that politicians' overdependence on campaign contributions gives too much influence to the interests of the rich and leaves the rest of us underrepresented. No campaign finance law can change the fact that the rich have more money to give out than the poor. So no reform will work unless it makes fund raising less important in the election process. Public financing or free air time on television would help enormously. Eliminating PAC's sponsored by labor unions and other mass-membership organizations -- the only means by which small contributors can now have an impact -- would just reinforce the power of the large donors. BENJAMIN ROSS Bethesda, Md.

title: East Gets a Win, Place, Row
description: Eastern crews dominated the opening heats of the 20th annual San Diego Crew Classic today.

title: No Singing Required . . .
description: 'On Stage at the Met' brings hundreds to the Opera House for a benefit dinner, March 28.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Storms Fail to Dampen Waterfront Appeal
description: THE three storms that pounded Long Island this winter apparently failed to damage the allure of waterfront property even though beachfront houses swept out to sea were often on television newscasts.

title: Murphy to Rockies
description: Outfielder DALE MURPHY was released from a minor league contract yesterday by the Philadelphia Phillies, allowing him to join the Colorado Rockies. Murphy, 37, hit .250 this spring. He played in only 18 games last year because of knee surgery, hitting .161 with 2 home runs. (AP)

title: Therapists in Allen Case Often Seem Like Family
description: In a voice that even the court stenographer had to strain to hear, Dr. Susan Coates testified last week about the day last October when Mia Farrow told her that she had, once and for all, had it with psychotherapy.

title: Officials Heed Calls On Breast Cancer
description: Spurred on by grass-roots groups, many of them organized by breast-cancer patients, elected officials are offering help in searching for clues to the high incidence of breast cancer on Long Island.

title: Behind the School Battle Lies the City's Identity Crisis
description: Few people are predisposed to think that as New York City goes so goes the nation. But in the case of public schools, this largest of school systems, with more than 1 million students, is struggling with issues that have national resonance -- family values, sex education, gay rights and what children should learn in the confines of the classroom.

title: Adult Students, Adult Needs

title: Educators Optimistic On More State Aid
description: After years of gloom, Long Island educators are hoping that the state's improving financial picture will have positive effects for them. For the first time since 1990, school districts are not expecting severe budget cutbacks from the state.

title: Be the First to Volunteer And Keep a Dump Away

title: Students Get Early Look at Work World

And what began as an educational experiment blossomed into a loving relationship between pupils and visitors.

title: ARREST OF DRIVER IS PROVING TRICKY
description: A top aide to former President George Bush who specialized in humiliating Massachusetts Democrats has created some political embarrassment for Gov. William Weld, a Republican, with a highly publicized arrest here this week on a drunken-driving charge.

description: Not all Chinese restaurants are clones with similar-sounding names, interchangeable menus and predictable food. The Emperor's Wok in Kings Park has one of those forgettable names, but its food is memorable.

title: Braves Release Davis
description: The former Cy Young Award winner MARK DAVIS was cut by the Atlanta Braves yesterday as they got down to the 25-man roster limit. By dropping the left-hander, Atlanta secured spots on the pitching staff for another former Cy Young Award winner, STEVE BEDROSIAN, and the rookie GREG McMICHAEL. The Braves are responsible for Davis's $3.25 million salary in 1993. (AP)

title: Juvenile Offenders' Salvation Strategy

But Honor House in Eatonville, Fla., is not a jail, and the 18 teen-agers who live there are not inmates, even though they have been sentenced to serve time.

title: Successful Soldering Requires Practice
description: Plastic plumbing pipe and high-strength adhesives like epoxy have reduced the need for soldering, but knowing the technique can still be useful. Soldering is the strongest method of joining copper pipe, and it is often the best way to join sheet metal and secure electrical connections.

title: The Heat of the Moment

They honor delicate fish like shad, which swims inland along the East Coast, brook trout from the heart of the country, as well as herring from Alaska and salmon just beginning their procreative push up the Columbia River.

description: WHEN Cathy Zaorski left the Dana Clinic at Yale-New Haven Hospital recently, she took home a clean bill of health that ordinarily would have taken many weeks to compile.

Weather and river forecasters are predicting the best river-running season in years due to heavy run-off from snowpacks as high as 200 percent above normal in sections of southern Utah, southwestern Colorado and the Sierra Nevadas.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Standly Holds On Mike Standly shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday, then withstood final-hole challenges by Payne Stewart and Russ Cochran for a one-stroke victory in the Freeport-McMoRan Golf Classic in New Orleans. Standly, who finished 72 holes at seven-under 281, missed a chance to close out his first PGA Tour title when a birdie putt stopped an inch short of the cup on the 18th hole of the 7,116-yard English Turn Golf and Country Club course. That left the door open for Stewart and Cochran to force a playoff with birdies on the final hole. But Stewart had a 25-foot birdie putt come up an inch short, and Cochran missed from 40 feet. Each shot 69 yesterday to finish at 282. Standly began play two strokes behind 54-hole leader Greg Kraft. Standly had six birdies, five on the front nine despite rain and wind gusting to 25 miles an hour. His only bogey of the day was on the 11th, but he birdied the 12th and then parred in. Stewart, the 18- and 36-hole leader before falling a stroke behind on Saturday, threatened to play himself out of contention with bogeys on Nos. 4, 5 and 7. But he turned in even-par 36 and shot 33 coming home. The $180,000 winner's check is Standly's largest payoff ever. (AP) Johnson Beats the Wind: Trish Johnson of Wales shot a windblown five-under-par 67 to run away from the field for a four-shot victory in the $450,000 Las Vegas L.P.G.A. at Canyon Gate. Johnson, three shots behind the second-round leader, Brandie Burton, when final-round play began, was one of just nine players to break par yesterday as wind gusts reached 40 mph. She completed 54 holes at seven-under 209 for her first victory in six seasons on the L.P.G.A. tour. Missie McGeorge, who was paired with Johnson, shot 71 to finish second at three-under 213.

title: Republicans Redux

title: Woodrow Swancutt, 77, General In Air Force and Atomic Test Pilot
description: Woodrow Swancutt, a retired major general in the Air Force who was a decorated World War II pilot and later flew the plane that dropped a test atomic bomb on Bikini Atoll, died on March 21 while walking near his at home in San Antonio. He was 77.

description: In rejecting the peace plan for Bosnia negotiated by the international community, the Serbs have evidently concluded that they have enough military strength on the ground and enough stoicism to withstand whatever is coming.

title: Ball Drops, Year Starts: Time for Baseball '93
description: Remnants of the vitriolic 1992 baseball season and its equally histrionic off season still remain, like so much pollution-blackened snow that simply refuses to melt. But for those who feared this day might not ever come, it is here, the opening day of baseball, 1993.

title: Man Held in 3 Slayings
description: A 27-year-old Queens man was arrested on Saturday in the shooting deaths of three men in a Mexican restaurant in the Bronx last month, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Oscar Pagan, was arrested at his home at 88-09 214th Street in Queens Village shortly after 2 A.M., said a police spokesman, Sgt. John McCluskey. Two employees of the Lena Restaurant at 206 East 198th Street in Bedford Park and a nephew of the owner were shot on March 9 after at least two robbers took about $100 from the cash register. One customer survived a gunshot wound and another employee escaped.

Truman was just a relatively obscure Senator, Jesse Jackson was 1 1/2 years old and Linda Brown, whose family name would be immortalized 11 years later by a United States Supreme Court decision, had not yet been born. But in downtown Brooklyn a white Midwesterner named Branch Rickey was already plotting a civil rights revolution of enormous magnitude.

Various pollsters were corralled to compile the evidence. Anyone objecting was summarily dismissed as, at the very least, a liberal, maybe even, as it came to be known during George Bush's 1988 campaign for the White House, a card-carrying member of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Ireland's Troubled Sleep
description: Twenty thousand people thronged central Dublin two Sundays ago, calling on the Irish Republican Army to "Stop the Bloody Murder." They congregated in silence to hear Sinead O'Connor, the pop star who tore up a photo of the Pope on "Saturday Night Live," sing the Roman Catholic hymn, "Make Me a Channel of Your Peace." The rally made for compelling drama on TV news and on the front pages of American papers. But like many Irish-Americans, I was ambivalent. The media's fixation on the event reinforced misguided conventional wisdom about the Irish conflict.

title: Herbert Fisher, 71, Jamesway Founder

But in Connecticut and a handful of other states, places like this represent a new environmental frontier.

The eight hourlong programs scrutinize such trouble spots as doctor training, the cost of life support for old people, the benefits and perils of expert surgery and miracle drugs and the problems of caring for the mentally ill and dealing with AIDS. American practices are compared with those in other countries.

description: The sea bird can play the same role as the deer in the cycle of infection that causes Lyme disease, according to a new study.

title: Pacific Gateway Properties reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $ 23,611,000, or $ 6.09 a share, on the sale of a portion of the company's interest in Golden Gateway Center.

title: Corrections
description: The opening paragraph of the main front-page article yesterday about the summit meeting in Vancouver referred incorrectly in some editions to the amount of aid pledged to Russia by President Clinton. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was $1.6 billion, not $1.6 million.

title: CHC Helicopters reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included gains on the disposal of aircraft of $ 2.2 million. The company did not say if any of these gains were recorded in the third quarter.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: American Bank of Connecticut reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
When Day Care Turns Deadly; A Fire Kills 2 Boys and Stillness Now Unsettles Eleta Brown
description: Since the February afternoon when two little boys died in a fire in the basement of her house where she provided illegal day care, Eleta Brown, 82 years old, has stood at her window, lonely and bored, waiting wistfully for the day when authorities will allow her to tend children once more.

title: Braman Wants Labor Agreement Blocked
description: NORMAN BRAMAN, the Philadelphia Eagles' owner, has asked the courts to block the labor settlement reached between the National Football League owners and players.

title: Coke Selling Three Units To Bottler
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that it had agreed to sell three bottling companies, including its Dutch subsidiary, to its largest domestic bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., for $360 million.

title: Professional Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss and included $ 758,000 in securities losses and $ 840,000 in tax expense, which was offset by similar securities gains and tax benefits in the second quarter of 1992.

title: ISG International Software reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: "Everything we believed in, all we thought we had created, has been washed away in a year." -- NADEZDE JEVDIC, a 72-year-old widow in Sarajevo. [ A14:4. ]

title: The Outlook Is Still Risky For New York Office Space
description: As the American economy heads into what appears to be an ever-more-solid recovery, the New York commercial real estate industry continues to reel from the shocks of the overbuilding of the 1980's and the job losses of the recession.

title: Lassonde Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Treasury Sales Abroad Set Record
description: Private investors overseas bought a record $31 billion of Treasury bonds and notes last year, with much of the demand coming from buyers in London and the return of the Japanese.

title: Costly Bargain for Devils: How 1 Penalty Turns to 2
description: The Devils' recent misbehavior toward referees has helped to turn their push to gain second place in the Patrick Division into a desperate effort to hold on to a playoff spot.

title: Joseph Bryan 3d, 88, an Author
description: Joseph Bryan 3d, an author and editorial writer, died on Saturday at his home, Brook Hill, in Richmond. He was 88.

title: Philadelphia Climbs Out of Fiscal Depths and Builds by Sharing Sacrifices
description: This city, long known for incompetent government, has made one of the most stunning turnarounds in recent urban history, experts say. Last week, its leaders announced it would end the year with a balanced budget for the first time in seven years.

title: School Challenge From the Right
description: There is more reason than ever this year to lament the traditionally low turnout for New York City's community school board elections: the Christian right hopes to take advantage of apathy to pack the boards and advance its agenda. Now more than ever, New Yorkers owe it to their children to vote.

title: CPI Aerostructures reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shares outstanding reflected initial public offering of 1.04 million units in September 1992.

title: Head Start in Maine
description: To the Editor:

title: Planner's Vision of a People-Friendly Arts Plaza on the Passaic
description: SO many people suffer from so much unnecessary agita when they see the word Newark. Larry Goldman knows everything there is to know about that one. He is stepping carefully down Saybrook Place in his cordovan wing tips, dapper, restless, the irresistible force personified.

title: Official Virtually Rules Out Taxing of Health Benefits
description: President Clinton will not try to help pay for his health-care program by taxing "in any significant way" the health insurance benefits that workers receive from their employers, one of his top health-care planners said today.

title: Rich Man Who Profited Wins an Investing Case
description: It's called the rich man defense, and few arguments have been more popular for Wall Street firms in arbitration: All rich clients, the theory goes, are by definition sophisticated investors. So, if they have losses in their accounts, the brokerage firms cannot be held liable.

title: How One National Health System Collapsed; Where Are the Doctors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Luria (L.) & Son Inc.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Stock Options: Bentsen's View
description: While the Clinton Administration has favored curbing excess executive compensation, its Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, weighed in yesterday on the side of those who oppose forcing companies to take a charge for the stock options they give executives.

title: Accounts
description: * The Daily News, New York, to Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, New York, to develop a campaign for the newspaper's sports section. Billings were not disclosed. * Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and Waldorf Towers, New York, to AC&R Advertising, New York, to handle its account, previously at Peter A. Mayer Advertising Inc., New Orleans. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $1.5 million.

title: Not All Solar Heating Has to Be Expensive
description: To the Editor:

title: China Applauds as Its Officials Plunge Into Profit
description: Happily married, his career flourishing, a 31-year-old midlevel city official named Lu Zhoukui abruptly decided last August to xia hai, or plunge into the sea.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Einar Steen-Nokleberg Weill Recital Hall Pianist

title: U.N. Plans to Evacuate 20,000 Trapped Muslims
description: The top United Nations relief official in what was Yugoslavia said today that United Nations convoys would try to evacuate up to 15,000 Muslims from Srebrenica, in eastern Bosnia, which is under siege by Serbian nationalists.

title: U.S. Confirms F.B.I. Alerted By Egyptians
description: The State Department acknowledged today that the Egyptian authorities had warned the American authorities repeatedly in the months preceding the World Trade Center bombing about an Islamic fundamentalist network in the United States.

title: Former Nanny Testifies Farrow Slapped Son
description: A former nanny for Mia Farrow's children testified yesterday that Ms. Farrow had not always been a good mother and once slapped one of her adopted sons across the face because he could not find a dog leash.

title: In Unmasking Anonymity of Crime, Victims Face Inmates
description: As Ralph H. Hubbard spoke of another commonplace murder in the city, the sidewalk slaying of his son, his face was a weathered, Jobian mask of tolerance that made his jailhouse visit all the more fascinating to the assembled convicts who listened and wondered about his feelings.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Wheaton Advances David Wheaton began his bid in the Japanese Open at Tokyo yesterday with a 6-4, 6-3 victory in the first round over a Japanese wild-card entrant, Ryuso Tsujino. Wheaton is seeded 10th in the $1.2 million tournament, being played on hard courts in Tokyo. Ninth-seeded Brett Steven of New Zealand, the highest-ranked man in action yesterday, beat Tommy Ho of the United States, 7-6 (7-5), 6-3. Also advancing were No. 11 Jan Siemerink of the Netherlands, No. 13 Christian Bergstrom of Sweden and No. 15 Guillaume Raoux of France. Siemerink edged Stefano Pescosolido of Italy, 2-6, 7-6 (7-5), 7-5, Bergstrom ousted the American qualifier Kenny Thorne, 6-3, 6-7 (5-7), 7-5, and Raoux defeated Jeremy Bates of Britain, 7-6 (7-3), 6-3. Patrick McEnroe, a qualifier, overcame a slow start to outlast his fellow American Chuck Adams, 0-6, 6-2, 6-2. (AP)

title: Samson Energy Co. L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $ 12,183,000 reduction in the carrying value of oil and gas prices.Share earnings are in units.

title: Arkansas Rookie Makes Debut
description: Making the first opening-day pitch of his presidency, Bill Clinton threw it high, wide and very careful today -- and was booed for his efforts.

title: Scimed Life Systems Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a charge for litigation settlement of $ 28 million.

title: Review/Television; An Unhealthy Hospital Stars in 'Titicut Follies'
description: "Titicut Follies" finally makes it to television tonight, a quarter of a century overdue. Frederick Wiseman's remarkable first documentary, an unsparing visit to the Bridgewater State Hospital for the Criminally Insane, in Massachusetts, was banned by the state's Supreme Court on the grounds that it violated the privacy of inmates, several of whom were shown naked. The ban was finally overturned in 1991.

title: Observer; An Aposiopesis, Eh?
description: "We are not amused," said Queen Victoria. She only said it to send Prince Albert right up the wall. "You know I can't stand it when you lay that royal we on me," said Prince Albert.

title: Winds of Change Ruffle Fashion's Lull
description: Fashion indeed has reached a watershed. Traditionalists and revolutionaries agree. That is about all they agree on.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Easter oratorios and special choral works in Weekend on Friday misstated the date of a service featuring two versions of "Lamentations of Jeremiah" at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. It is tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., not on Sunday.

title: Smith Just Won't Argue With New Orleans Odds
description: Dean Smith flinched a bit when the name Fred Brown was mentioned. Needless to say, he will flinch in the future when the name Chris Webber is mentioned in connection with North Carolina's 77-71 victory over Michigan tonight.

title: Sharper Image Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Please Don't Tell Knicks Playoffs Aren't in Session
description: The Knicks have already adopted a playoff mentality, although the playoffs are still several weeks away.

title: Tourist Killing Casts Pall Over Miami
description: When Barbara Jensen Meller, a German tourist just off a plane from Berlin, headed out toward the warm ocean breezes of Miami Beach in a rented red Ford Taurus on Friday night, she did not know just how close one of the most alluring places in America could be to one of the most hellish.

title: Bosnians in Besieged Sarajevo Look Back on Year of Horror
description: Determined to find something for her four young children to eat, Stanka Voloder set out one day last week and walked five miles to the barbed-wire perimeter of the United Nations headquarters here to rummage through the garbage. After a while, she found three rotting potatoes and an onion, walked home to the Bistrik district in the city center, and cooked her treasures over a wood fire.

title: Crowley Milner & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Finding a Way to Unite 2,280 Wayward Atoms
description: CHEMISTS at the University of Michigan have overcome formidable technical difficulties to create a gigantic ball-shaped molecule that they believe may offer clues to how proteins function in living organisms.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Chronicle column on Saturday about the new acting president of Wellesley College misstated the role of a search committee. It will seek candidates for the permanent presidency of Wellesley, not for the chairmanship.

title: Reviews/Music; When a Dramatic Accent Shows an Intriguing Puzzle
description: In the beginning there is the music and in the end, the listener. Between the two worlds lies a third: technique and interpretation intertwined, a system of mental gears and physical moving parts that bring composers and their audience together. Somewhere in that purgatorial middle lies the art of Jessye Norman.

title: Braintree Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Braintree said that 1993 net income included $ 77,000 of income tax expense. The bank recorded no such expense in 1992.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: How One National Health System Collapsed; Needs of Rural America
description: To the Editor:

title: Civil Rights Trial Is Likely to Leave a Long-Term Mark on Rochester Police
description: Although five former narcotics officers have been cleared of beating and threatening suspects, their civil rights trial will likely have long-term effects on police operations here.

title: On My Mind; America's Allies in Serbia
description: If you have any ideas about new options in Serbia and Bosnia, the President said on the phone after the summit talks, let me know. So I did.

title: Review/Pop; A Musically Mad Scientist
description: Lindsey Buckingham might be described as the mad scientist of California pop. The singer, songwriter and guitarist who masterminded the gossamer folk-rock harmonies of Fleetwood Mac's biggest hits is a notorious perfectionist in the recording studio. And at Town Hall on Wednesday evening, in a concert that was part of his first solo tour, he worked with considerable success to recreate the layered textures that have made both his Fleetwood Mac and his solo albums models of a certain kind of meticulous craft.

title: Vestro Foods Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary gain of $ 178,000, or 1 cent a share, from utilization of net operating loss carryforward.The results are after scheduling preferred stock dividend.Vestro Foods said that its sale of the assets of Fine Baked Products operations Dec. 18 resulted in a loss of $ 795,000. The company said that it also wrote off $ 1,015,000 related to covenants not to compete from former owners of business, ''which no longer had any future benefit to the company.''

title: With No Parents, Ladeeta, 18, Presses On
description: It was 3:30 on a Monday morning and Ladeeta Smith could not sleep. Just hours earlier, she had visited her mother in a Bronx nursing home, and she was haunted by the image of her emaciated body covered with sores. At 41, Patricia Bobo Smith was dying of AIDS and no longer recognized her daughter.

title: Beeba's Creations (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $ 1.7 million, or 47 cents a share, from the sale of 375,000 shares of Body Drama during Body Drama's initial public offering in October 1991.

The Vancouver summit meeting, the $1.6 billion in assistance President Clinton promised President Boris Yeltsin and the decision by 19 Western nations to give Russia 10 more years to pay off $15 billion in debt coming due this year form the first stage of a renewed Western effort to support democratic reforms.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: After the most harmonious round of budget negotiations in four years, the State Legislature approved a $32.08 billion budget that many lawmakers proclaimed as the start of a fiscal recovery for New York State. A1.

title: Banyan Mortgage Investors L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 2,072,431 related to settlement of litigation.

title: APPLE COMPUTER UPGRADES ITS SERVICE OPTIONS
description: Apple Computer Inc. upgraded its service options, including extending warranties on its entire line of personal computers and peripherals. Apple also said three of the nation's largest distributors, Ingram Micro Inc., Merisel Inc. and the Tech Data Corporation, would recruit other dealers to become authorized dealers of Apple peripherals.

title: Budget Blur Leaves Some With Questions
description: After months of haggling, cajoling and deal-making, it all came to this: New York State's $32.08 billion budget was passed in a blur late Sunday and early Monday, so quickly that many legislators weren't quite sure what it said.

title: Rocky Mountain First for an Old Familiar Voice
description: Charlie Jones slept only a few hours Sunday night. In bed by midnight, up by 3 A.M. The white-haired veteran of network television who has never really been anybody's marquee star was tense and exhilarated about making his debut as the play-by-play announcer for the expansion Colorado Rockies on KWGN-TV.

title: Job to British Telecom
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said today it would supply a digital data network to the Brussels-based air traffic control agency Eurocontrol under a five-year contract. The terms of the contract were not disclosed, but British Telecom said it was worth several million pounds and was the largest it had won in mainland Europe.

title: Liquor Brands' Accounts in Review
description: The Schieffelin & Somerset Company in New York is rounding up agency finalists to pitch for its Johnnie Walker Black Scotch Whisky and Tanqueray Gin and Vodka brands account, with combined billings estimated at $15 million.

title: Nets' Petrovic Can Practice
description: Drazen Petrovic has been cleared by the Nets' medical staff to practice with the team tomorrow. Petrovic, who was placed on the injured list with a torn ligament in his left knee on March 30, isn't eligible to play until April 8.

title: Tank Parts, Off the Shelf
description: As the Pentagon slims down to fit a much diminished threat, it won't be buying weapons at the same expansive rate. The resultant downsizing and consolidation in defense industries pose a tough puzzle for the Pentagon: how to preserve technological know-how and a skilled labor force against the possibility of resuming defense production.

title: Appeals Panel Backs U.S. in King Trial
description: A Federal appeals court sided with the Government today in a dispute over a prosecution tactic that is threatening to undo the fragile alliance among the four officers on trial in the beating of Rodney G. King.

title: SOFTWARE PUBLISHING SHARES FALL SHARPLY ON FORECAST
description: The Software Publishing Corporation's shares tumbled 33 percent yesterday, after the company said its fiscal second-quarter earnings and revenues would fall below expectations. After the market's close Friday, the maker of graphics and data base software said it expected to post earnings of 15 cents to 17 cents a share on revenues of $31 million to $33 million for its second quarter that ended on March 31. In the corresponding quarter last year, the company's net income was $4 million, or 32 cents a share, on revenues of $43.4 million.

title: Words With Aliens
description: THE MUTANOID WORD CHALLENGE pits a child, 7 or older, against a cast of satisfyingly disgusting-looking mutanoids, little garbage-loving extraterrestrials who have agreed to iron out their differences with Earthlings by playing a word game.

title: Time to Remember; Time Not to Forget
description: Opening day is supposed to epitomize a lot of things. But seldom is it supposed to bring a well of tears, a lump to the throat. Emotions usually course along shallower paths, caught in the pomp and circumstances, driven by the cadences pounded out by the feet of marching bands, blaring speakers and roaring crowds.

title: Clinton Is Relying Less on Advisers In Finding Supreme Court Nominee
description: In a marked departure from his recent predecessors, President Clinton appears to be far more involved in the selection of a new Supreme Court Justice and is relying less heavily on the choices of White House aides.

title: Poll Says Public Favors Changes In Health Policy
description: Fired by a sense of crisis, a majority of Americans say they are willing to accept substantial changes in their health-care system, including government price controls, new taxes and longer waits for nonemergency appointments, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Recreating Concerts From the 19th Century
description: The music of 19th-century New York will be presented in two typical concerts of the period, this week and next month, by the early-music chamber group Vineyardmusicke. "The Harp and the Horn," a program of works played in the small music halls, salons and music gardens that abounded near Union Square in the early 19th century, will be offered on Thursday at 8 P.M.

title: Aid Recipe For Russia: Add a Ton Of Savvy
description: Charles Bennett, West Point class of 1962, trained as a navigator bombardier on a B-52, preparing to drop nuclear bombs on the Soviet Union. Today, at 54, he is a Peace Corps volunteer in the small city of Kamyshin on the Volga River, teaching Russians how to create small businesses in a market economy.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on March 22 about the increase in reported AIDS cases in New York City misstated the percentage of increase in each category for this year's first two months, compared with last year's. For all men, the figure was up 56.4 percent; for all women, up 82.3 percent; for men who had sex with men, up 40.8 percent; for intravenous drug users, up 80.54 percent; for all those who engaged in heterosexual sex, up 55.9 percent.

title: Fujimori Sees a Peaceful, and a Prosperous, Peru
description: Expressing "not the slightest regret" about seizing expanded powers one year ago today, President Alberto K. Fujimori says his authoritarian moves are rapidly pacifying Peru and setting the stage for a free-market economic boom here in the mid-1990's.

title: Computer Outsourcing Services Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Time U.S. Recognized Angola's Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Divorce Is Final: Jets Ship O'Brien to Packers
description: Ken O'Brien's nine-year career with the Jets, which hit a rapid decline the past three years under Coach Bruce Coslet, ended yesterday when the team traded the quarterback to the Green Bay Packers for an undisclosed pick in the college draft later this month.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; No Review of Espionage Conviction
description: The Supreme Court today refused to review the espionage conviction of Clayton J. Lonetree, the marine convicted of spying for the Soviet Union while assigned to guard the American embassies in Moscow and Vienna in the mid-1980's.

title: AIDS Study Casts Doubt on Value Of Hastened Drug Approval in U.S.
description: A European study that found no benefit from early treatment of the virus that causes AIDS with the drug AZT has also cast doubt on the validity of certain tests that the United States Government has approved in the last few years to speed up licensing of new drugs against the disease.

title: EUROPEANS URGED TO PRESSURE SERBS
description: Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator on the Balkans, called today for "relentless pressure" to be placed on Bosnian Serbs to make them accept a peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but he cautioned against lifting the arms embargo on Bosnian Muslims.

title: Article 083593 -- No Title
description: After the most harmonious round of budget negotiations in four years, the State Legislature approved a $32.08 billion budget today that many lawmakers proclaimed as the start of a fiscal recovery for New York State.

title: It's Michigan's Call, but It's Carolina's Title
description: No matter how successful his basketball career may be at the University of Michigan or beyond, Chris Webber will never be allowed to forget the moment tonight, with a national championship in the balance, when he called a timeout he did not possess.

title: Drexler's Hamstring Has Him Out Again
description: CLYDE DREXLER will miss several games after straining his hamstring Saturday night in the Portland Trail Blazers' loss to the Washington Bullets.

title: Marlboro's 2-Fisted Pitch
description: Ever see a cowboy try to walk a tightrope? Philip Morris is about to ask the Marlboro cowboy -- perhaps the world's best-known advertising icon -- to perform that daunting feat.

title: Review/Television; Baseball's Self-Inflicted Sports Injury
description: A baseball fan need not possess too long a memory to recall $4.50 box seats, end-of-season salary drives by players to make $100,000 and talk that focused on home runs, trades and strikeouts, not arbitration, revenue-sharing and $7 million-a-year paychecks.

title: Officer's Death Sets Back Household International
description: Household International Inc. said today that its chairman and chief executive, Donald C. Clark, was delaying his planned retirement after the weekend death of Edwin P. Hoffman, the company's president and chief operating officer.

title: Sports of The Times; The Man In the Gray Raincoat
description: WHILE the Yankees were taking batting practice before yesterday's opener with the Indians, a husky gray-haired man in a gray raincoat suddenly appeared in the Yankee dugout behind third base, hopped up the steps and strode toward left field. George Steinbrenner had emerged from his silent spring.

title: Bilingual Education Yields Good Results
description: To the Editor:

title: North Carolina Takes the Title
description: The Fab Five was fabulous, and the Tar Heels were terrific, but when 64 teams came down to the final game last night, it was the North Carolina five who stood alone in victory and the Michigan Wolverines who were left to wait yet another year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For 20 years, ELLEN HAAS has been an outspoken advocate of the consumer's right to safe and nutritional food, often finding herself at odds with the Agriculture Department under the Reagan and Bush Administrations and with farm groups. In 10 years, by her count, she testified at 76 Congressional hearings.

title: Decision Is Appealed On Decency Standard
description: The United States Department of Justice has appealed the decision by a Federal judge in Los Angeles in June that declared unconstitutional the so-called decency standard, which required the National Endowment for the Arts to "take into consideration general standards of decency" when awarding grants.

title: Now It's Bill Clinton's Package
description: Stepping out from the large foreign policy shadow of his predecessor, President Clinton now assumes the risks, and courts the dividends, of embracing a Russian leader who's in deep political trouble at home. It's the right move -- an unstinting bid to encourage the best possible outcome, even while beginning to hedge against the worst.

title: Cornucopia Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 122,416 write-down and loss on investments, a $ 5,400 write-down of properties and a $ 6.9 million gain on the sale of a property.c-Net loss and included a $ 750,000 write-down and loss on investments and a $ 219,073 write-down of mineral properties.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Electro Rent (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
It's All Sunshine In Florida Debut
description: After eight decades of watching major league teams head north at the end of spring training, Florida got its first taste of regular-season play today and found the result to its liking as the expansion Florida Marlins defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-3.

title: Three-Goal Rally Sinks Rangers
description: Want to know why the Rangers will probably miss the playoffs this season? Watch the tape of last night's game against the Hartford Whalers. In a crucial game, on their home ice, the Rangers could not hold a lead against the fourth-worst team in the National Hockey League. The fourth-worst team .

title: Caribbean Chill
description: Christmas is not supposed to end for Little Switzerland Inc., a chain of 19 duty-free shops in the Caribbean, until Easter Sunday. But the holiday for its stock ended with a jolt yesterday. Little Switzerland, which has prospered by selling luxury goods to tourists, reported third-quarter earnings of 32 cents a share; analysts had expected 52 cents.

title: Depositors Set Off a Run on a Shady Serbian Bank
description: Panic has set in among the depositors at Serbia's largest private bank, a mysterious institution run by a woman who has become known as the Balkan Rothschild and whose activities have been central to the survival of the hard-line Serbian government.

title: There's No Cause for Comfort As the Islanders Look Ahead
description: Practice was over and the Islanders skated quietly off the ice and into their dressing room this morning. Rap music played from a radio, but few players spoke as they packed for a flight to Washington and a chance for 2 more points in the Patrick Division playoff race with the Rangers and Devils.

title: Alpine Meadows of Tahoe Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
A PLUTONIUM PACT WILL AID DISPOSAL
description: Seeking a new path to East-West disarmament, Russian and American experts have agreed to team up to develop and build a new type of reactor that can burn plutonium from nuclear warheads and turn the deadly bomb fuel into electricity. The $1.5 billion nuclear reactor would be built in Russia and fueled at least partly by plutonium from Moscow's huge stockpile of scrapped nuclear arms.

title: Executive Changes
description: APPLETON & LANGE, New York, a unit of Paramount Communications Inc. that publishes medical texts and scientific journals, named Eric J. Newman president. CELGENE CORP., Warren, N.J., a chemical and biotechnology company, named Thomas H. Odiorne president and chief operating officer.

title: GE Capital Agrees to Buy Pacific Life Insurance
description: GE Capital Services said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the United Pacific Life Insurance Company from Reliance Group Holdings for $550 million. The deal marks GE Capital's second large move this year into the annuity business.

title: Market Place; Makers of brand-name products face some tough questions.
description: INVESTORS wanting to buy their favorite brand names at a discount could have had their pick in yesterday's stock market. Colgate-Palmolive, Proctor & Gamble, Clorox, Heinz, Kellogg and Coca-Cola each fell at least a point, while the rest of the market inched ahead.

title: Frances C. Boas, 83, A Foundation Founder
description: Frances Cullman Boas, a founder and trustee of the Gomez Foundation for Mill House, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Presidential Realty Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary net gains of $ 557,000, or 15 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 606,000, or 17 cents a share, in the year, both from sales of properties and investments.c-Net lossd-Included extraordinary net gains of $ 41,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 222,000, or 7 cents a share, in the year, both from sales of properties and investments.Presidential Realty said its fourth quarter income before items reflected a $ 95,000 write-down of foreclosed properties and nonrepetitive general and administrative expenses related to severance payments to an officer of the company.The company said that the 1991 fourth quarter loss before items reflected a reversal of interest income and amortization of discounts related to a Fairfield Towers note receivable as a result of a default in interest payment on the note and the reclassification of the note to nonaccrual status. The loss also reflected expenses associated with the conclusion of a settlement agreement with Ivy Properties.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Dow Gains 8.38 Although Consumer Stocks Are Battered
description: Investors continued to abandon consumer product stocks yesterday, extending a selloff begun Friday when Philip Morris announced it was cutting prices of its Marlboro and forgoing increases in its other cigarette brands in the face of competition from cheaper alternatives.

title: New Brain Scanning Technique Can Show Strokes in Progress
description: STROKES are responsible for killing or disabling half a million Americans every year and are the third leading cause of death in this country. Until now, doctors have had neither a really safe and reliable method of diagnosing stroke, other than clinical observation, nor any way to treat the disabling effects.

title: By Design; Dark Shadows
description: Come fall, the way to go will be in black from head to toe. From a squishy brimmed cloche or close-fitting cap to platform-soled shoes or ankle-muffling boots, the idea is to be drenched in black. No dibs or dabs of bright accessories should distract. This look, once the province of widows and more recently the uniform of the avant-garde, has now been proclaimed the peak of chic.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Armen Takhtajan; Botanist Plans Survey of World's Flowers
description: BORN before the Soviet Union existed, Dr. Armen Takhtajan has outlasted both it and the pall it cast over genetics to stand today among the small number of botanists at the top of their field.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on March 21 with an article about changes in state taxes for affluent people omitted the year on which the data were based. It was 1991. Thus the chart only partly reflected the effect of the 4.5 percent income tax phased in by Connecticut in 1991. In later years, a typical Connecticut couple earning $200,000 a year would owe $9,000 -- not $3,000 -- in state and local taxes, close to what similar couples pay in Georgia, Kentucky and Virginia.

title: Domestic Vehicle Sales Up 11.9% in Late March
description: Sales of domestically produced vehicles rose 11.9 percent in late March, a gain that may have reflected pent-up demand from earlier in the month, when harsh weather interrupted normal shopping patterns in many areas.

title: Abuse-Case Reversal Called Sign of Trend
description: The moment an appeals court overturned the 1988 conviction that sent Margaret Kelly Michaels to prison for sexually abusing 19 children, the case of the former day-care teacher became a symbol of legal questions larger than her fate.

title: F&C Shares Plunge by 50% As Company Sues Founder
description: The shares of F&C International Inc. fell 50 percent today after the fragrances and flavors manufacturer said it had sued its former chairman, Jon P. Fries, accusing him of manipulating inventory and sales to make the company appear more profitable than it was.

title: Fly-by of Jupiter Detects Puffs of Planetary Dust
description: WHEN the European-American spacecraft Ulysses flew by Jupiter in February 1992, the huge planet seemed to make some decidedly unwelcoming gestures. It appeared to be blowing puffs of dust in the face of the passing spacecraft.

title: Dundee Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 187,165,000 for adjustment of asset values.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: G.M. Financial Chief Takes Lopez's Duties
description: The General Motors Corporation today appointed its chief financial officer to take over the duties of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the aggressive head of worldwide purchasing who abruptly resigned last month to join Volkswagen A.G.

title: INSIDE
description: Reactor Would Derive Power From Plutonium

title: CHRONICLE
description: The three children of PRINCESS CAROLINE of Monaco have been deemed legitimate by Pope John Paul II, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Among other things, this means they are now eligible to succeed to the throne of the principality. They had not been considered legitimate before because their parents married outside the church.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-15 MEMORIES OF A CITY DESTROYED In Sarajevo, no building of any consequence reamins undamaged and few families have survived untouched by the fighting that began a year ago with an attack on a downtown hotel and has continued almost uninterrupted since. A1 Daily convoys will go to Srebrenica to evacuate trapped Muslims. A14

title: Mercedes Still Shopping for U.S. Plant Site
description: Mercedes-Benz A.G. said today that it would decide within a few months where to build its first passenger vehicle plant in the United States, which would assemble a new model of a four-wheel-drive sport utility vehicle.

title: College Student Fatally Stabbed
description: A college student was stabbed to death and his brother and a friend were wounded in a confrontation with a group of youths on a street in Ridgewood, Queens, yesterday, the police said.

title: Expect Hensley to Drive Kulwicki's Car
description: JIMMY HENSLEY, the 1992 Winston Cup rookie of the year, is apparently the choice to assume the driving duties of Alan Kulwicki, the reigning Nascar champion who died last week in an airplane crash.

title: Pier 1 to Sell Nursery Stake
description: Pier 1 Imports Inc., the nation's largest specialty home-furnishings retailer, said today that it had agreed to sell its 49.5 percent stake in the Sunbelt Nursery Group to the General Host Corporation in a stock swap.

title: Lasertechnics Inc.(NSC) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included adjustments totaling a loss of $ 850,000. Adjustments included write-off of inventory for discontinued products, the accrual of final costs related to the termination of the lease on an idle facility in Torrance, Calif., the accrual of expenses associated with the resignation of the company's previous president and the accrual of expenses related to the company's equity in the loss of its French affiliate.

title: Florafax International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net lossFlorafax said that, ''Litigation settlement expenses of $ 101,000 significantly affected the difference between operating income of $ 220,000 and net income of $ 77,000 for the three months ended Feb. 28, 1993.''

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: GRANITE CONSTRUCTION INC., Watsonville, Calif., has been awarded a $32 million contract by the Airport Authority of Washoe County to build a new runway at Reno Cannon Airport in Reno. PARKER HANNIFIN CORP., Cleveland, has acquired the United States and European operations of TRW Inc.'s Ross hydraulic motor and hydrostatic steering controls business for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about retrenchment in the airline industry referred incompletely to data on the growth of miles flown by paying passengers, as well as the decline in cents earned for each mile flown by a paying passenger. The figures referred to domestic air travel only.

title: Reviews/ Music; Reflection and Song From Christa Ludwig And Jessye Norman
description: Christa Ludwig sang her last words at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon in "Die Walkure," with her back to the audience, telling Brunnhilde that Wotan had some news for her. That delivery, forthright, even a bit spunky, gave a poignancy to Ms. Ludwig's farewell to New York in this role of Fricka, the goddess of marriage. It was as if Ms. Ludwig, like her character, had completed her say. Two weeks ago was Ms. Ludwig's last New York recital; during the next year will be a string of farewells in other major cities. She has, over the course of her career, swayed listeners with her strength of character and her highly principled musicianship; she is now prepared to move on.

title: Chess
description: The strongest young player in the world is currently Vladimir Kramnik of Russia. This protege of Gary Kasparov is the only 17-year-old listed by the International Chess Federation among its 10 top grandmasters. In fact, Kramnik stands sixth in the official January ratings.

title: How One National Health System Collapsed; Rationing's No Panacea
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE SUSPENDS EFFORT FOR ACCORD ON CLINTON'S PLAN
description: Nine days into a filibuster and miles from any hint of agreement, Senate Democrats and Republicans abandoned the hunt for a compromise on President Clinton's economic stimulus package tonight, and decided to try again in two weeks.

title: Sports of The Times; They Came and Saw And They Learned
description: ASIDE from debating who might be the new national champion, the multimillion dollar question here last night was whether Chris Webber of Michigan would turn pro this spring. Would the Five X's be broken up?

title: Gary DeLoatch, Leading Dancer With Ailey Troupe, Is Dead at 40
description: Gary DeLoatch, a leading dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, died on Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 40 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Studying the Secrets Of Childhood Memory
description: WHEN Rachel Hudson was 2, she recalled details about things she had done weeks and months before, prompted by her mother, a psychologist studying children's memories. But by the time she was 8, the only episode Rachel could recall from her first couple of years was a trip to Disneyland.

title: Leslie Fay Files for Chapter 11
description: The Leslie Fay Companies filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday after it found itself unable to get credit to buy the yarns, fabrics and trims used in its dresses, suits and sportswear.

title: The Russians Seem Agreed: Yeltsin Had a Good Meeting
description: Russian officials today began the process of selling the results of the Vancouver summit meeting at a Kamchatka fuel stop, even before landing in Moscow. But the view here was that President Boris N. Yeltsin had done himself some good with a dignified, "presidential" summit organized to insure that he had to give few public concessions to President Clinton.

title: Australian Navy Helps Endangered Giant Clams to Relocate
description: THE Australian Navy has stepped in to help the giant clam, an endangered species that has been driven to extinction in waters off many South Pacific islands and heavily fished on the Great Barrier Reef by poachers.

title: Redskins Fill Receiving Spot With McGee
description: The Washington Redskins yesterday signed free-agent receiver TIM McGEE, who had spent his entire career with the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Russell Sherman Pianist Kathryn Bache Miller Theater

title: Biomechanics Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,247,270 in the latest year and $ 1,153,234 in 1991.

title: Lexington Precision reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on repurchase of long-term debt of $ 978,000, or 24 cents a share.Lexington Precision said that it wrote-off the $ 2,132,000 unamortized portion of two agreements on Dec. 31, 1992.

title: Fundamentalism: the 20th Century's Last Ideology
description: Scholars used to dismiss fundamentalism as a fossilized form of old-time religion, destined to dissolve in the acids of science and skepticism.

title: Pulling In the Skiers, and the Cash
description: Heavy snowfalls late in the season have pushed the spring ski season well beyond its traditional Easter finale this year -- a relief to the nation's ski industry, which has consolidated in a decade to 523 areas from 845 because of slow business and mild winters.

title: Reliance Group Holdings reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $ 4,105,000, or 5 cents a share, from discontinued operations, and after gain of $ 3,460,000, or 5 cents a share, on early extinguishment of debt.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 31,444,000, or 43 cents a share, a gain of $ 1,715,000 on the early extinguishment of debt, and after a gain of $ 894,000 of investee companies.

title: Heaton Sits and Waits, Not Quite a Yankee Yet
description: Neal Heaton is the invisible Yankee. Watch him take the team bus to today's game with the Indians, watch him get dressed at his locker, watch him work out with 25 other Yankees and then watch out because he is about to disappear.

title: Financial Times Says Chief Is Leaving Over 'Differences'
description: Pearson P.L.C., the parent of the Financial Times publishing group, announced today that David Palmer, the chief executive of the group, was leaving immediately over "differences in management style."

title: Baseball '93 Opens With Flurry of Firsts
description: On a day of renewal, when spring is suddenly suggestive of summer and hope springs eternal, at least until the bottom of the sixth, baseball began a new season yesterday with the usual fanfare and more: the debut of two teams and a lefty from Little Rock.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Off Broadway show "Another Time" opened on March 13, the night of the blizzard whose billing became "worst of the century."

title: Benguet Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 18,380,000 in provisions for losses from unrecovered capital development costs of suspended mining operations in the quarter and year.Results are in U.S. dollars.

description: b-Included a charge of $ 23,429,469 from write-off of an investment.c-Net loss

description: b-Included Chapter 11 reorganization costs of $ 8,437,000 in the quarter and $ 26,368,000 in the year, and a $ 7.1 million provision related to the Department of Energy's assessment on nuclear facilities, including the Palo Verde Nuclear Power Plant in the quarter and year.c-Included charges of $ 289.1 million arising from the discontinuation of the application of an accounting standard and $ 221.1 million attributable to Palo Verde Units 2 and 3 letters of credit draws in the quarter and year.

title: Bridge
description: Beginners learn to play game in an eight-card major-suit fit if one is available, and otherwise in three no-trump. But if no-trump is ruled out by a conspicuous weakness, the choice may between trying for 11 tricks in a minor suit or 10 in a shaky major suit. An example is the diagramed deal from a Regional Swiss Teams in Houston last month.

title: Theater in Paris: Elan, Eclat and Assistance
description: Tonight the seventh annual Moliere awards, the Paris equivalent of the Tonys, will reward this season's theatrical excellence. There is a lot of excellence to reward. With far more government financing than is available in New York, Paris offers a dizzying range of theatrical possibilities. This week, 173 active theaters are listed in the entertainment guides, some with more than one offering.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Healthplex reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 'There's Just a Lot of Pressure'
description: The following text was taken from more than 20 hours of discussions with teen-agers from the New York City region. Excerpts appear with each article.
