description: Chorovaya Akademia Kathryn Bache Miller Theater

title: CHRONICLE
description: Credit Dolley Madison with something more than making ice cream popular by serving it at the White House. It was she who moved the Easter egg roll for children to the White House lawn in 1812, when she learned that it could not be held on its usual site -- the lawn of the Capitol -- because of construction under way there.

title: It's Not Double Jeopardy in L.A.
description: Are the four Los Angeles police officers now on trial for the Rodney King beating being subjected to unconstitutional double jeopardy? After all, they were tried and acquitted in state court and are now being tried again for essentially the same acts in Federal court.

title: U.S. Oil Loan for Russia Faces Dispute and Delay
description: A White House plan to assemble $2 billion in Federal loans to the Russian oil and gas industry by next Wednesday is unrealistic, American and international financial officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A Reporter's Notebook article on Tuesday about the passage of this year's New York State budget misstated the political affiliation of Assemblyman Michael J. Bragman. He is a Democrat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 20 about political considerations facing President Clinton in choosing a successor to Justice Byron R. White misstated the position of Judge Amalya Lyle Kearse. She is a member of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, not the Federal District Court.

title: Give Special Schools a Chance
description: Many New York City students find high school an alienating experience. In large buildings and classes they lose their way, become apathetic, perform poorly and eventually drop out. To reach such students, Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez has pushed to create about 50 smaller high schools focused on themes ranging from the environment to community service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 6 about Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, referred imprecisely to his childhood. A letter dated March 22 from Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, points out that the general was born in Harlem and reared in the South Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the politics of gun control in New Jersey misattributed a message sent to the State Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, by one voter. Eugene L. Brenycz of Irvington said it was not he who sent the Senator an application for a job at McDonald's, filled out in Mr. DiFrancesco's name; he said he did mail Mr. DiFrancesco a yellow turkey feather.

title: IRAN IS REPORTED ACQUIRING MISSILES
description: Iran is close to concluding a deal with North Korea to buy a new intermediate-range missile that the Koreans are developing, United States officials said today.

title: Salick Health Care (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Books of The Times; Joyce Is in the Details, Preferably Freshly Plowed
description: James Joyce The Years of Growth, 1882-1915 By Peter Costello Illustrated. 374 pages. Pantheon Books. $30.

title: Bowe Will Seek Custody if Boy Is His Son
description: RIDDICK BOWE will seek custody of a 7-year-old boy if a paternity test shows that the heavyweight champion is the boy's father, Bowe's manager said.

title: Preparing for Womanhood Begins in Girlhood
description: To the Editor:

title: NESTLE, ALLIED-LYONS ACQUIRE MINERAL WATER COMPANIES
description: Nestle S.A., the Swiss food maker, and Allied-Lyons P.L.C., its British rival, stepped up their European mineral water acquisitions yesterday, buying companies in Greece and Ireland respectively.

title: WHERE TO FIND IT
description: EMBROIDERY comes in many guises, from bathrobe monograms and evening-gown embellishments to the New York Knicks logo stitched on sweat shirts and caps. "It can be very personal," said Dan Wiesner, publisher of Stitches magazine, a publication for the embroidery trade.

title: Tobacco Price Reductions Could Help the Bond Market
description: Philip Morris's 40-cent-a-pack cut in the price of its Marlboro cigarettes was bad news for the stock market, other cigarette companies and the idea of brand-name attraction. But the news could turn out to be a help for the bond market.

title: Russian Officials Say Little Radiation Is Released in Nuclear Plant Accident
description: Russian officials said today that the nuclear accident in the Siberian city of Tomsk-7 on Tuesday caused only minor contamination, but still qualified as the worst nuclear incident in the former Soviet Union since the Chernobyl explosion in 1986.

title: Preparing for Womanhood Begins in Girlhood; A Day for All Ages
description: To the Editor:

title: Networks and the Hollywood Monster
description: Pressured by a court order, the Federal Communications Commission wisely reversed some of the out-of-date rules that have kept the major television networks out of the lucrative rerun business. The rules have allowed Hollywood movie studios to dominate programming to the detriment of networks and viewers.

title: CBS Producer to Head NBC News
description: NBC has chosen Andrew Lack, a longtime news producer for CBS, to become president of the network's embattled news division.

title: Foreign Affairs; No Peace Without Keepers
description: A joke about Bosnia is running through the Clinton Administration. What's the only thing worse than the Serbs saying "No" to the Vance-Owen peace plan? The Serbs saying "Yes."

title: President Riverboat Casinos Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included one-time deferred compensation charge of $ 3.4 million.c-Net lossPresident Riverboat Casinos also reported pro-forma earnings per common and common equivalent shares of 51 cents (50 cents fully diluted) for the latest fourth quarter.For the latest full fiscal year, the company had pro-forma earnings per share of $ 1.17 on both a primary and fully diluted basis.The company said that the per share earnings are based on the reorganization and subsequent shares issued as a result of the public offering. The above represented shares outstanding as of Feb. 28, 1993. However, the company has announced a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid April 19, to shareholders of record April 5.The stock split would have doubled the shares outstanding and would have resulted in pro-forma earnings per common and common equivalent shares of 25 cents primary and fully diluted for the fourth quarter and 59 cents primary and 58 cents fully diluted for the year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Cotton as New as Today And as Old as Yesterday
description: IN Arizona and Texas, scattered among different farms, there are 10,000 acres producing field upon field of fluffy tan cotton. The cotton is called Coyote Brown by Sally Fox, below right, an entomologist in Wasco, Calif. Through crossbreeding she has developed what she calls Fox Fibre, a more durable, naturally colored cotton.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Dinosaur Jr. Roseland

title: Rules Are Faulted on Nuclear Plant Security
description: When a former mental patient crashed his car into the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in February, the plant's owners and Government officials erred in failing to consider that he might have intended to release radioactive material, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said in a study.

title: Wisconsin Race Sees Democrats Vote for Basics
description: Congressional primary voters looking for a successor to Secretary of Defense Les Aspin gave an easy victory on Tuesday to a conventional Democrat, who had pushed jobs and health care, over a rival who had run against Congress as hard as he had run for it.

title: InterVoice Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Executive Changes
description: ANN TAYLOR STORES CORP., New York, appointed Joseph Gromek senior vice president and general merchandise manager. FLEET SERVICES CORP., Providence, a data processing unit of Fleet Financial Group, named David M. Sheppard chairman and chief executive and Robert P. Drum president.

title: Russia Orders American Reporter Questioned in State-Secrets Case
description: The Russian Ministry of Security, still known by its old initials as the K.G.B., has ordered a Baltimore Sun reporter to report back to Lefortovo prison here on Thursday for questioning, after informing him today that his American lawyer and a United States Embassy official will be barred from the meeting.

title: A Volley of Airline News Raises Industry Stocks
description: Bulls woke to the sound of planes booming overhead yesterday, and apparently liked what they heard.

title: Morada Nova Journal; In Brazil, Too, the Withered Land Cries for Rain
description: Standing in the doorway of her mud-and-wattle farmhouse, Maria de Lourdes Oliveira Lima surveyed rows of bean plants wilting under the noonday equatorial sun.

title: Review at Huffy
description: The Huffy Bicycle Company in Dayton, Ohio, said yesterday that it had placed its account in review. The account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million, has been handled by Lois U.S.A. in Chicago for 10 years. Jeff Cox, the executive vice president at the Rojek Marketing Group in Cleveland, the marketing consulting company retained to manage the review, said that the incumbent and 15 other shops, primarily from the Midwest, were under consideration. A final decision is expected by mid-June.

title: AIDS Expert Fears an Epidemic In Central and East Europe Lands
description: The director of the World Health Organization's global program on AIDS, Dr. Michael H. Merson, warned today that central and eastern Europe might soon face a major AIDS epidemic.

title: TELEVISION-FILM DEAL FOR HARLEQUIN ROMANCES
description: After publishing 16,000 titles, Harlequin Enterprises is adapting its romance novels for television. Harlequin and the Alliance Communications Corporation, a film producer and distributor, said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture to produce made-for-television movies based on Harlequin's romance novels.

title: Radical Arabs Use Pakistan as Base for Holy War
description: It was a routine roadblock, the sort that the police in this Wild West border town have put up in recent weeks to try to stanch the flood of cars being stolen here and raced through the Khyber Pass into Afghanistan. What the police found, though, were not run-of-the-mill car thieves, but four Libyans armed with pistols and hand grenades.

title: Celebrating Millenniums Of Fiber Art
description: FIBER art originated about 20,000 B.C. Some people call it a craft. Others, like Cathryn Cootner, a research curator in the textile department at the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum in San Francisco, consider it an overlooked art form. Historically, fiber art has been made by women whose traditions were passed from mother to daughter, generation after generation.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Container Corp. of America is offering $500 million of 9 3/4 percent senior notes due in 2003 at a price of 100 through Morgan Stanley & Co. The notes are not redeemable, but are guaranteed by Jefferson Smurfit Corp., which bought Container Corp. in 1986. Underwriters note the issue is rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by Standard & Poor's. * Korea Electric Power Corp. is offering $350 million of 7 3/4 percent debentures due in 2013 at 99.353 to yield 7.814 percent through Lehman Brothers Inc. The noncallable issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Eddie Bo Tramps Cafe 45 West 21st Street Chelsea Through Saturday

title: Trade Center Blast Providing Economic Lift, Experts Find
description: In the first attempt at a comprehensive analysis of the economic damage caused by the bombing of the World Trade Center, Port Authority economists and consultants have concluded that the explosion has actually provided a lift to the local economy.

title: Brauns Fashions reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Quicksand, Therapy and Surgery The Academy

title: Peter Rabbit at 100: Still a Gentle Phenom
description: HE'S the subject of museum exhibitions in Paris; Melbourne, Australia, and Edinburgh. He's the star of ballet galas in London. He just got his own trendy boutique in New York. He's 100 and more animated than ever (in the leading role of a new series of television specials). Everyone seems to be celebrating this new centenarian. Happy Birthday, Peter Rabbit!

title: First Charter Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 300,000, or 9 cents a share, which reflected change in the method of accounting for income taxes.

title: U.S. Proposing Move by Israelis To Revive Talks
description: Trying to persuade the Palestinians to resume the Middle East peace talks, the Clinton Administration has suggested to Israel that it accept a prominent Palestinian leader from East Jerusalem as head of the Palestinian delegation, United States officials said today.

title: A TV Film Becomes a High Point In a Roller-Coaster Directing Career
description: By this town's standards, Michael Ritchie's prolific directorial career has been nothing less than a roller coaster, and he acknowledges it.

title: Suffolk Moves to Abandon Plans To Buy Robins I. as Nature Area
description: Suffolk County took the first step today toward abandoning plans to buy Robins Island, one of the largest uninhabited islands on the East Coast, and turn it into a nature preserve.

title: Dauphin Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time gain of $ 215,000, or 2 cents a share.c-Net loss

title: AT HOME WITH: Madeline Kahn; Funny? Yes, but Someone's Got to Be
description: MADELINE KAHN, who made a name for herself in "Young Frankenstein" by playing a Transylvanian American Princess who finds true love with an anatomically challenging monster, has never understood what's so fun about being funny.

title: Trial of 3 in Trucker's Beating Is Put Off Till July
description: A state judge today delayed until July the trial of three black men charged in the beating of a white truck driver at the outset of the rioting here last April.

title: First Federal Savings-Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 6,840,000, or 87 cents a share, which reflected implementation of FASB 109, and which related to the accounting of deferred tax assets.Year-ago per share are adjusted to reflect the effect of a 10 percent stock dividend distributed on Dec. 31, 1992, and a 50 percent stock split distributed on Feb. 26, 1993.

title: The Courts on Trial; Los Angeles Blacks Say Bias Is Issue In Riot Case and Retrial of 4 Officers
description: The discontent among many blacks that sets this city on edge has found a slogan, and it is emblazoned on red, black and green caps and T-shirts throughout South-Central Los Angeles: No Justice, No Peace.

title: Northern Ireland Needs New Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabin and Mubarak to Discuss Mideast Talks
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt will meet next week, probably in Egypt, to explore ways to give the stalled Middle East peace talks a badly needed jump start, Israeli officials said today.

title: Canadian Northstar reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an unspecified gain on the sale of its stake in Northstar Energy Corp.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: F&M Distributors Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: F&M Distributors noted that pro forma supplemental net income for the latest fourth quarter was $ 4,475,000, or 47 cents a share, compared with pro forma supplemental net income of $ 4,319,000, or 45 cents a share, in the year-ago fourth quarter.For the 1993 fiscal year, pro forma supplemental net income was $ 10,255,000, or $ 1.07 a share, compared with $ 9,349,000, or 97 cents a share, in 1992.Figures on a pro forma basis reflected F&M's initial public offering on Sept. 24, 1992 and its conversion from an S Corporation to a C Corporation at that date for federal income tax purposes.

title: Novelist Enlisted For Literacy Drive
description: The Adolph Coors Company is teaming with a best-selling romance novelist, Judith McNaught, to introduce the second phase of its "Literacy. Pass it on" campaign, aimed at combating illiteracy among American women.

title: Livery Driver Is Slain
description: A livery cabdriver in the Bronx was shot four times in the back last night in a slaying that the police described as resulting from an apparent holdup. The dead man, Sekou Kaba, 28, of Bolton Avenue, the Bronx, was found lying on the shoulder of a service road at the intersection of the Cross Bronx Expressway and the Bronx River Parkway in the West Farms section by a passing motorist shortly after 9 P.M., said Sgt. John McClusky, a Police Department spokesman. Mr. Kaba's car was found about a half block away, said Sergeant McClusky. He said that no weapon had been found and there were no suspects in the case.

title: In North Korea, Try Diplomacy First
description: North Korea's abrupt refusal to allow inspections of its nuclear sites has now led the International Atomic Energy Agency to take the unprecedented step of asking the United Nations Security Council to impose sanctions.

title: Calendar: History and Preservation
description: Preserving New York The Barbizon, 140 East 63d Street, and Cooper Union , 7 East Seventh Street; (518) 462-5658.

title: Calnetics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the television host Joe Franklin referred incorrectly to the longtime morning host on WOR-AM who retired in 1990. He is John A. Gambling.

title: Solving the Day-Care Puzzle
description: HERE is the bottom line of the child-care chase: parents want to find someone to care for their children as well as, or better than, they can.

title: Scudamore, a Top British Jockey, to Retire
description: Jockey PETER SCUDAMORE, who rewrote British racing's record books without winning the Grand National, announced his retirement yestertday. Scudamore, 34 years old, is Britain's most successful jump jockey in history, having won more than 1,600 steeplechase and hurdles races over an 18-year career. Named champion jockey eight times, his last major victory was on Captain Dibble in last year's Scottish National. (AP)

title: Capriati Evens Score With Rout of Russian
description: In the opinion of the loser, familiarity had apparently bred contempt.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the governorship race in New Jersey misstated the date of former State Senator James Wallwork's run for the Republican nomination. It was 1981.

title: Giants and Taylor Near A 2-Year, $5 million Pact
description: Lawrence Taylor and the Giants seem headed for a two-year, $5 million contract that may be worked out in the next two days.

title: Prime Capital reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Latest full-year results included a one-time gain of $ 2.57 million related to the elimination of recourse debt through the sale of assets, and a $ 720,496 gain from the tax effect of utilizing net operating loss carryforwards, for a total of 77 cents a share.The company said it lost $ 1.48 million in restructuring its operations and financial structure in the latest year. For 1991, Prime Capital said net income included a one-time ''income tax expense'' of $ 106,400.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Preparing for Womanhood Begins in Girlhood; Finding Self-Worth
description: To the Editor:

title: New Public Housing, French Vintage 1922
description: YOUNG architects are supposed to make a splash. It's a letdown when their first building doesn't herald a new voice. But Jean Dubus, 41, and Jean Pierre Lott, 31, have done something truly original. Their first work, an apartment building in Paris, reverberates with the shock of the old.

title: Dallas Gold & Silver Exchange (ECM) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: Study the North-South cards shown in the diagram, with the East-West cards concealed, and consider the prospects in six no-trump. On the face of it, there are 11 tricks and the declarer will need a winning diamond finesse to make 12.

title: Lucasfilm and Silicon Graphics Team Up
description: Industrial Light and Magic, the special-effects unit of Lucasfilm Ltd., and Silicon Graphics Inc. said today that they had entered an alliance to create the largest and most advanced production facility for the creation of digital imagery in entertainment.

title: CUOMO ANNOUNCES HE IS NOT SEEKING SEAT ON HIGH COURT
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he had asked President Clinton to remove him from consideration for an appointment to the United States Supreme Court, saying he wished to continue serving New York while the state was on the cusp of economic recovery.

title: Chase Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 9,000 in the quarter and 6 months, and a charge of $ 10,000 and income of $ 25,000, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both which reflected current and cumulative effects of tax accounting change under SFAS 109.The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: Essay; Not 'Ready to Go'
description: Bob Dole, the Republican leader in the Senate, chose Oregon's Mark Hatfield, a soft-spoken moderate, to talk to Pennsylvania's Arlen Specter about signing the filibuster letter.

title: Tough Talk Won't Help Trade With Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreman to Retire After June 7 Match
description: Six years after stepping out of retirement and back into the boxing ring, GEORGE FOREMAN, the lovable preacher-boxer, may soon be calling it quits again. At the tender age of 44, Foreman remains the novelty of professional boxing.

title: Big Bills Coming Due at H.U.D., Crimping Expansion of Programs
description: Several old bills are coming due at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and the costs are frustrating the Clinton Administration's hopes of rapidly expanding Federal housing aid.

title: No Headline
description: "I do not know whether you might indeed have nominated me, but because there has been public speculation concerning the possibility, I think I owe it to you to make clear now that I do not wish to be considered." -- GOVERNOR CUOMO, in a letter to President Clinton. [ A1:6. ]

title: Liberty All-Star Equity Fund reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Per share results are after total distribution of 27 cents a share during the first quarter.Net income represented total net assets.

title: Shuttles Profit Despite Fewer Fares
description: Like the aerial acrobatics of hummingbirds, which seem to defy the laws of aerodynamics, the shuttle operations of Delta Air Lines and USAir seem to fly in the face of airline economics. Despite falling ridership, the hourly flights between New York and Boston and New York and Washington continue to make money for the otherwise money-losing carriers, leading some industry analysts to nickname them Anomalous Air.

title: Review/Dance; Philadanco's Tease and Payoff
description: Philadanco saved the best for last on Tuesday when it opened a weeklong season at the Joyce Theater. There were moments of choreographic distinction throughout the evening. But nobody does it quite like Talley Beatty. And his recent "Morning Songs" ended the evening on a note of soaring triumph.

title: Paul Laszlo, 93, Dies; Architect to Celebrities
description: Paul Laszlo, an architect and interior designer in the United States and Europe, died on March 27 at home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 93.

title: Private Mortgage Insurers Are Facing New Competitor
description: Private mortgage insurers are facing competition from a new company, the Amerin Guaranty Corporation, which has pared costs sharply on policies that protect mortgage lenders if homeowners default, and charges premiums that are tax deductible to homeowners.

title: Ethics Committee Decides to Investigate Senator's Links to Bank
description: The Senate Ethics Committee opened a preliminary inquiry today into the relationship between the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, a Middle Eastern bank that collapsed two years ago amid spectacular instances of fraud, and Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah and his staff.

title: Power Corp. of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 46,050,000 for restructuring costs recorded by the company's Great-West Lifeco Inc. subsidiary, in the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain of $ 42.6 million, representing the company's share of a gain by its Power Financial Corp. subsidiary, resulting from the issue of shares by Investors Group Inc. at a price greater than Investor Group's carrying value.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Perez Goes on Disabled List
description: The Yankees placed Melido Perez on the disabled list with a strained left hip flexor today and finally rescued Neal Heaton from limbo by activating him to assume the roster spot.

title: Day Before Meeting on Guns, Bridgeport Has a Fatal Shooting
description: A 31-year-old woman who was eight months pregnant when she was shot late Tuesday night died early this morning shortly after giving birth to a son. The shooting death, which came one day before a statewide meeting here on gun-control legislation, prompted outrage from city officials, including Bridgeport's Mayor.

title: Joseph Robbins, 71, Lay Catholic Official
description: Joseph G. Robbins, the first layman to serve as the Assistant Chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died on Tuesday in Orlando, Fla., where he had retired. He was 71.

title: U.S. STEEL AND UNION BREAK OFF NEGOTIATIONS
description: United States Steel and the United Steelworkers of America suspended early contract talks yesterday after they were unable to reach swift agreement on critical wage and benefit issues. United States Steel, a unit of the USX Corporation, the energy and steel conglomerate based in Pittsburgh, entered negotiations March 3 with the union, which represents 16,000 workers at company operations in Pennsylvania, Alabama, Indiana and Minnesota. The current three-year labor contract expires next February.

title: Robert E. Lee, 81, F.C.C. Member And Telecommunications Leader
description: Robert E. Lee, who helped to mold national telecommunications policy as the longest-serving member of the Federal Communications Commission, died Monday at a hospital in Arlington, Va., his hometown. He was 81.

title: Bosnia Reconsidered; Where Candidate Clinton Saw a Challenge The President Sees an Insoluble Quagmire
description: After coming into office proclaiming the need to take action against moral outrages in Bosnia, the Clinton Administration has shifted gears, and is now telling the American people that Bosnia is a quagmire about which very little can be done.

title: U.N. Compromise Lets Macedonia Be a Member
description: The Security Council today approved United Nations membership for another former Yugoslav republic after a clumsy-looking compromise ended a controversy with Greece over its admission and injected a little more stability into the Balkan region.

title: Alcoa reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included currency exchange gain of $ 4.8 million, or 6 cents a share, on devaluation of Suriname guilder.c-Net loss and after a net charge of $ 1,111,400,000, which included a charge of $ 1,166,400,000 on the adoption of FASB 106, and a gain of $ 55 million, or 65 cents a share, on adoption of FASB 109.Year-ago first quarter's income from continuing operations of $ 55.1 million, or 64 cents a share, included a gain of $ 8 million, or 10 cents a share, on sale of investments in Venezuela.Year-ago results are restated.Revenue represented sales, operating revenues and other income.

title: United We Stand -- and Fly
description: President Clinton's decision to consider seriously Russia's proposal for cooperation on a space station holds promise. A joint venture could give new direction to our faltering space effort while reducing its cost. It could help reform in Russia and be the stepping stone to Mars. But many barriers remain.

title: Corrections
description: The front page of Business Day yesterday carried a reprint of Monday's Business Digest in some copies in place of the correct one. Readers wishing copies of yesterday's digest may write to the editor, Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Improvements in School Security Force Proposed
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday called for changing New York City's force of 3,000 school safety officers into a better-trained, better-educated department modeled in many ways on big city police departments.

title: Future Doctors Unsettled By Health-Care Changes
description: In the library, at home, even between cuts in the operating room, the prospect of dramatic change in the health-care system is the talk among medical students in this city known as a mecca for future doctors because of its concentration of teaching hospitals and medical schools.

title: Heritage Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
China Police Have Gang Link In Hong Kong, Official Says
description: China's top law enforcement official said today that the police maintained links with Mafia-style gangs based in Hong Kong and once even used them to help protect a Chinese leader traveling abroad.

title: Couch Potatoes, Arise! A Temple of TV Awaits You
description: PAYING a visit to the Museum of Television and Radio in Manhattan is a lot like passing an average afternoon in front of the tube. Except without the snacks, the commercials, the interruptions to answer the phone, the sound of your neighbor's lawn mower, the familiar couch or, finally, anything that really resembles a television set.

title: Chicago's Mile of Retailing Magic
description: In an era when staying alive is a major feat for a downtown shopping district, North Michigan Avenue's "Magnificent Mile" of department stores and boutiques is a standout in that it has continued to live up to its name.

title: Historic Day at Bar: Dodger Stays in Brooklyn; Judge Says, Among Other Things, That Los Angeles Club Has No Good Name to Lose
description: Nothing can heal the wound left when the Brooklyn Dodgers packed up their bats and balls and headed to Los Angeles after the 1957 season. But yesterday, Brooklyn got a small measure of revenge.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Night of Flamencos

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: The total assets of the nation's 628 retail money market mutual funds increased $3.85 billion, to $394.12 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Film; Twins' Surreal Visions
description: The surreal visions of the film-making team known as the Brothers Quay have an angst-ridden intensity that can make watching a three-minute short feel like gobbling an exceedingly rich and exotic candy and wondering afterward what exactly has been consumed. For those who have a taste for such things, Film Forum 2 is offering a program of six animated short films by the Quays, which opens today and plays through Thursday. They range from a recent music video for the singer and songwriter Michael Penn, to "Anamorphosis," a formal examination of perspective in 16th- and 17th-century paintings.

title: Art in Review
description: Joan Mitchell Robert Miller Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through May 8

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CCB FINANCIAL CORP., Durham, N.C., and Citizens Savings, Lenoir, N.C., announced an agreement in principle under which Citizens Savings would convert into a stockholder-owned organization and merge into CCB Savings Bank of Lenoir, N.C. CLINTON GAS SYSTEMS INC., Columbus, Ohio, has reached an agreement with Bill Blair Inc., New Springfield, Ohio, to purchase a majority interest in 158 producing oil and gas wells.

title: Keane Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cuomo Urges Product-Liability Revisions
description: In an effort to protect manufacturers from exorbitant legal judgments, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed significant changes in the state's laws on product liability that would make it harder for people who have been injured to establish fault and recover damages.

title: Reviews/Film; 'American Friends,' A Michael Palin Tale
description: Anyone who has ever underrated the wit, intelligence and sheer classiness of "Howards End," "A Room With a View" and other Ismail Merchant, James Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala collaborations should be sentenced to sit through "American Friends" at least twice. This new English film, made by people who have otherwise always seemed sane and talented, is a ghastly if unintentional parody of the sort of thing the Merchant-Ivory-Jhabvala team does successfully with such seemingly supreme ease.

title: Serbs Bar U.N. General From a Muslim Enclave
description: The French commander of the United Nations military force in Bosnia was halted by a crowd of angry Serbs and forced to turn back today as he tried to reach the besieged Muslim enclave at Srebrenica.

title: What Can We Do About Balkan Atrocities?
description: Hoping to bring to justice those responsible for atrocities in the former Yugoslavia, the United States presented the United Nations last week with a plan for the establishment of war crimes tribunals. The tribunals would be similar to those held at Nuremberg and Tokyo at the end of World War II.

title: Art in Review
description: Paul Pagk Thread Waxing Space 476 Broadway (near Broome Street) SoHo Through April 17

title: Saatchi's Team One Shifts Management
description: Team One Advertising of El Segundo, Calif., said yesterday that it had restructured its top management. John Hirschboeck, Team One's president, has been promoted to the new position of executive vice president at the agency's parent, Saatchi & Saatchi North America. Mr. Hirschboeck, 46, will be based at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific in Torrance, Calif.

title: Victor Jacobs Dies; A Lawyer for Chefs And Restaurants, 87
description: Victor Jacobs, a lawyer who represented several leading French chefs and restaurants in New York City, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Food Lion Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
Westinghouse to Sell Property Loans
description: In a move to resolve one of the biggest real estate fiascos of the 1980's, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell most of the commercial property loans held by its financial services unit for about $1 billion to a new partnership it has formed with an affiliate of Lehman Brothers.

title: Clinton Plan Adds Money For New York
description: The New York metropolitan region stands to benefit substantially from President Clinton's proposed increase in financing for mass-transit and social-welfare programs, according to analyses by state and city budget officials.

title: LEXMARK TO ACQUIRE AUSTRALIAN LASER PRINTER MAKER
description: Lexmark International Inc. of Lexington, Ky., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Gestetner Lasers, an Australian maker of laser printers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 'Empty Net' Scenario Starring the Rangers
description: This is a rehearsal for my pitch meeting at Paramount. The television show will be called "Empty Net," and the star is the Vanrichter, a two-headed goalie with an ambivalent attitude toward teammates, coaches, media and the owner, who will be thawed out of suspended animation every so often to make crucial decisions. So you've got the basic elements: fish out of water, odd couple, family and weird science. It's a comedy.

title: Dreco Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Corrections
description: Charts on March 23 and 30 listing movie box-office figures misstated the number of theater screens on which the top 10 films were shown. Correct figures appear today on page C19.

title: E.D.S. Discusses Its Ogilvy Account
description: Electronic Data Systems, the Dallas-based data-processing and telecommunications division of the General Motors Corporation, said it had been discussing the status of its account now at Ogilvy & Mather Houston.

title: Victor Tyson Jr., 76, U.S. Maritime Officer
description: Rear Adm. Victor E. Tyson Jr., a retired chief of staff at the United States Merchant Marine Academy and the shoreside manager for three America's Cup yacht racing teams, died on Tuesday at the Medical Center of Ocean County in Point Pleasant, N.J. He lived in Allenwood, N.J., and was 76.

title: Review/Theater; To Grandmother's House They Go
description: When Leslie Ayvazian first played the title role in "Jenny Keeps Talking" last June in the one-act festival at the Ensemble Studio Theater, the author was Lise Erlich, who seemed to be a very promising playwright. It turned out that this was a pseudonym for Richard Greenberg. Now, under his own name, Mr. Greenberg stands up for feminism and against the occupational battering suffered by women who dare to play the game by men's rules. While polishing the play, he has also put it in context, having added a related one-act, followed by a brief epilogue. The result is a pungent chamber trilogy of character sketches.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that will close soon: Closing This Weekend "THE WIZ," Beacon Theater, 74th Street at Broadway. A revival of the 1975 all-black musical adaptation of L. Frank Baum's "Wonderful Wizard of Oz." Directed by George Faison. Through Sunday. Performances: tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $30 to $37.50. Cash only at the door. Information: (212) 496-7070. Closing Next Weekend "JOEL PERLMAN," Emmerich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan. Sculptures. Through April 17. Hours: Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 752-0124.

title: Investors Flee Metals After Aloca Report
description: Investors battered aluminum stocks yesterday, and analysts said the issues were likely to remain under pressure until huge inventories of the metal have been pared.

title: My Lord, What a Morning!
description: She had a voice that dazzled Toscanini and a dedication that heartened the whole world. Marian Anderson, who died yesterday at 96, sang compellingly that her Lord held the whole world in His hands. With her gloriously quiet manner she, too, held multitudes in her hands.

title: Nets Keep Petrovic Waiting
description: In an attempt to safeguard his health, the Nets have decided that guard Drazen Petrovic, who has missed the last eight games because of a torn ligament in his left knee, will not make his comeback until next Wednesday when the Nets play at Indiana.

title: The Lone Dissenter
description: To the Editor:

title: Education Dept. to Take No Action on School Chief
description: The New York State Education Department said today that it did not have the authority to reduce the $964,000 retirement package given to Edward J. Murphy, a Long Island school superintendent whose case has become a political cause celebre.

title: Dinkins Proposes a 2-Year Freeze On New York City's Water Rates
description: Responding to fierce complaints of higher water bills in New York City, the Dinkins administration proposed a two-year freeze on water and sewer rates yesterday and a ceiling on those rates in the two years after that.

title: One Small Step for Knicks; One Banner for Garden
description: The Knicks have won the Atlantic Division. They hope that accomplishment is just the start of bigger things.

title: Tokyo Defends Big Stimulus Plan
description: The Government has begun a vigorous defense of a huge new spending package to jump-start the economy and ease political pressure from Washington, even though details of the plan will not be announced for another week.

title: Review/Art; A New View of India's 'Decadent' Sculpture
description: "Gods, Guardians and Lovers: Temple Sculptures from North India, A.D. 700-1200" at the Asia Society Galleries is a visually glorious show that proposes a revisionist look at 500 years of a country's art.

title: Pier 1 Imports reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: The 1992 year included a gain of $ 4,200,000, or 11 cents a share, on the sale of 50.5 percent of Sunbelt Nursery Group's shares in an IPO.

title: Penn President Chosen For Humanities Agency
description: The Clinton Administration has selected Sheldon Hackney, the president of the University of Pennsylvania, to be the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, a White House official said today. The choice of the 59-year-old Mr. Hackney, an outspoken advocate of freedom of expression, had been expected for several weeks.

title: Marian Anderson Is Dead at 96; Singer Shattered Racial Barriers
description: Marian Anderson, whose velvety contralto and dignified, affecting stage manner melted the hearts of music lovers around the world, and whose determination helped shatter racial barriers in the arts, died yesterday in Portland, Ore. She was 96.

title: Weather and Tax Fears Stall March Retail Sales
description: Cold, wet weather and the prospect of higher taxes put the brakes on retail sales in March.

title: DISCOVERY'S CREW ATTEMPTS REPAIRS
description: After a night launching, the astronauts aboard the shuttle Discovery were busy today trying to repair minor equipment problems as the spacecraft began a mission to study the Earth's atmosphere, especially its ozone layer.

title: Deduction Proposal Is Softened
description: After promising strict new rules to limit deductions on executive pay of more than $1 million, the Clinton Administration offered a proposal today that would continue to allow deductions of seven-figure compensation as long as it was tied to performance and approved by shareholders.

title: Movies Remind Us That Power Can Corrupt
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Resign High Posts At Synergen
description: Synergen Inc., the biotechnology company whose main drug has proved disappointing in tests, yesterday announced the resignations of its chief executive and a top research officer.

title: Art in Review
description: Rochelle Feinstein David Beitzel Gallery 102 Prince Street SoHo Through April 17

title: The Art Market
description: Whither 12 Warhols?

title: The Quayle Trail
description: If you thought Dan Quayle was history, you must be right, for news now comes from Indiana that Mr. Quayle will soon have his own museum.

title: Police Aided Farrow Case, Lawyer Says
description: A lawyer for Woody Allen lashed out at the Connecticut authorities yesterday, asserting that law-enforcement officials investigating sex abuse allegations against Mr. Allen were aiding Mia Farrow's custody case by giving her lawyers exclusive access to major pieces of evidence.

title: Government Set To Strip Army Of Vaccine Test
description: In an effort to resolve a bitter dispute over how to test an experimental AIDS vaccine, top Government researchers have tentatively agreed to shift the task of testing the vaccine from the Army to the National Institutes of Health.

title: Nicklaus Defies Age, Shares Lead At Masters
description: Against the tide of age, lackluster play and widespread skepticism, 53-year-old Jack Nicklaus once again turned back the clock at his favorite time tunnel, Augusta National, to tie for the lead today in the first round of the 57th Masters.

title: Stone Container Holds Off On Stock and Debt Offering
description: The Stone Container Corporation, its stock pummeled since it disclosed plans last week to raise $500 million by selling stock, said yesterday that it would postpone any attempt to raise capital.

title: RUSSIA REBUFFS U.S. ON TOUGHER MOVES AGAINST BELGRADE
description: Underscoring the international community's problems in pushing through even modest measures to punish the Serbs for resisting a peace accord for Bosnia and Herzegovina, Russia refused today to accept a toughened set of American-sponsored sanctions against Belgrade.

title: Bandag Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the cumulative effect of accounting changes as a result of the adoption of FAS 106 and FAS 109.Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to give retroactive effect to the company's June 10, 1992, stock dividend of class A common stock.

title: Review/Film; Postwar Western Gay Culture
description: Barbara Hammer's "Nitrate Kisses," opening today at the Cinema Village, is a passionate, very subjective meditation on what the film maker describes as the "repressed and marginalized history" of gay women and men in contemporary Western culture since World War I. Ms. Hammer describes her work as "a post-modern constructivist collage," though it's difficult to hold her to that: the terms are vague at best.

title: Researchers Find Genetic Defect That Causes Rare Immune Disease
description: Cells taken from a boy who lived for most of his 12 years inside a sterile protective environment have helped researchers locate the genetic defect that causes a rare immune system disease.

title: Review/Film; Inertia, But Crisply
description: "Bodies, Rest and Motion" takes its title from Newton's first law of motion, the one that says a body at rest or in motion will remain that way unless acted upon by an outside force. Inertia is the more common name for this phenomenon, but it sounds much less like "Sex, Lies and Videotape," a film to which this one owes a noticeable debt.

title: Executive Changes
description: CELLULAR PRODUCTS INC., Buffalo, named Bert C. Del Villano president, chief executive and a director. CENFED BANK, Pasadena, Calif., a unit of Cenfed Financial Corp., named Lawrence J. Winslow executive vice president for lending and administration.

title: TV Commercials for Stein Are First in Race for Mayor
description: Weeks before any other candidates seem likely to join him, City Council President Andrew J. Stein began the New York City mayoral race in earnest last night by broadcasting the campaign's first television commercials. They are two biographical hymns that portray him as "standing up, fighting back for a better New York."

title: Prosecutor in King Beating Tells Jury to Focus on Tape
description: In closing arguments, a Federal prosecutor today accused the four officers charged in the beating of Rodney G. King of acting as judge and executioner to punish Mr. King for being disrespectful to them.

title: Review/Photography; Horror and Camp in Work by Joel-Peter Witkin
description: In recent years, Joel-Peter Witkin has attracted a cult following with photographs that combine campy and horrific elements in varying degrees. Typically Mr. Witkin presents such unnerving subjects as corpses, body parts or people with extreme physical deformities in daintily staged tableaux that evoke 19th-century studio photographs.

title: 'Assault' Gun Bans Won't Curb Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: On Terming Proposed U.S. Attorneys a 'Woman and a Black'
description: To the Editors:

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Abbott Labs said that earnings included losses on foreign exchange of $ 4,266,000 and $ 10,765,000 for 1993 and 1992, respectively.

title: CHANGE UNDER WAY AT ENERGY DEPT.
description: Seeking to streamline her department, the new Energy Secretary isreversing some organizational changes that her predecessor made to improve nuclear safety, provoking a vituperative fight and the resignation of a top official.

title: Topics of The Times; Spellbound
description: Alfred Butts, a New York architect who died this week, wasn't much of a speller. That's surprising because it was he who invented Scrabble, an immensely popular spelling game. "I was out of work," he recalled later, "and just decided I would invent an adult game." He had the idea in 1931, but it was not until two decades later that it finally caught on, and then it soared. A national craze in the early 1950's, it is still popular to this day around the world in multiple languages and configurations.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Robert E. Lee, a former member of the Federal Communications Commission, misidentified his surviving wife. She is the former Rose Bente. The former Wilma Rector was his late first wife.

title: German Court Backs Use of Armed Forces In Bosnia Air Patrol
description: A German constitutional court ruled 5 to 3 tonight that German military personnel could remain on NATO air surveillance planes when enforcement of a United Nations ban on Serbian military flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina starts on Monday.

title: Boitano Wins at Hershey's Pro-Am
description: BRIAN BOITANO, 10 months before the next winter Olympic Games, has again established himself as the United States' best male figure skater. On Wednesday night, in his first competition since his Olympic gold medal year of 1988, he won the Hershey's Kisses Pro-Am in Los Angeles, finishing ahead of the 1984 gold medalist, SCOTT HAMILTON, and the 1992 Olympic silver medalist, PAUL WYLIE.

title: The Guggenheim Foundation Awards Fellowships to 146
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Foundation has named 146 artists, scholars and scientists as recipients of its 69th annual competition for fellowships totaling $3,925,000.

title: Cyril F. O'Neil Jr., 60, Law Firm Co-Founder
description: Cyril Francis O'Neil Jr., the senior partner and a founder of Richards & O'Neil, a New York City law firm, died yesterday at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 60 years old.

title: Paulsons Are Sticking To Their Derby Dream
description: One year later, the high command of Allen Paulson's racing stable gathered for breakfast at the serene, green Keeneland Race Course today and plotted their return to Churchill Downs, 75 miles and many heartaches to the west along Interstate 64.

title: Clinton Campaign Aide Leads Lobbying Group
description: The man who reviewed the work of the Federal Communications Commission as a member of the Clinton transition team is now coordinating a lobbying group trying to influence billion-dollar decisions by the agency. Critics say those actions put the former aide, Ronald Plesser, in violation of the spirit of the transition team's ethics rules.

title: Hanoi Journal; Colonel Fights With His Pen, Defending the Poor
description: For a lieutenant colonel who retired only last year after 27 years of service, and a Communist Party member since 1970, Nguyen Khac Truong holds decidedly nonconformist views. What's more, he has expressed them in a novel that not only was published but even shared the 1991 fiction prize of the Vietnamese Writers Association.

title: After Cuomo's Court Withdrawal, Time to Work on a Legacy
description: This time there was no plane left waiting on the tarmac.

title: Accounts
description: * Wilson Sporting Goods Co., Chicago, to DDB Needham Chicago, to consolidate its European account, previously divided among various local shops. DDB Needham already handles the American advertising for Wilson's racquet sport division. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Wallace Decides to Attend North Carolina
description: RASHEED WALLACE, a 6-foot-11-inch center and one of the top high school basketball players in the country, said yesterday he will attend North Carolina.

title: Diner's Journal
description: World Financial Center Discounts

title: Arch Petroleum Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago figures are for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31. The company has since changed the end of its fiscal year to Dec. 31. The company said figures for the 12-month period ended Dec. 31, 1991, were not available. The above year-ago period included an afte- tax gain of $ 6.3 million on the sale of oil and gas properties.

title:
Distressed Project;
Builder Cuts Sizes and Prices of Homes
description: K. Hovnanian Enterprises, a leading New Jersey developer known for its affordable attached homes, is finding new opportunities in the lingering residential building slump by taking over distressed projects.

title: XEROX TO BUILD AN ASSEMBLY FACTORY IN UTICA, N.Y.
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it planned to build a factory for simple work in Utica, N.Y. Components assembled at the Utica plant will be put into Xerox copiers and printers at the company's factory in Webster, N.Y. The new factory will employ about 50 when it begins production. Xerox decided on the site after conducting a joint study with the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union on ways to keep assembly jobs in the United States. The union represents workers at Xerox plants in the Rochester region.

title: Price Palpitations
description: Medtronic Inc. has prospered by selling its pacemakers and heart valves to surgeons at premium prices. Yesterday, however, its stock price fluttered and fell sharply a day after a Hambrecht & Quist analyst raised questions about whether Medtronic's profits would be hurt by the Clinton Administration's plans for curing health-care costs.

title: In a Rustic Barn, a Quest for Spiritual Simplicity
description: Jammed together in a pre-Civil War barn with the ambiance of a theater in the round, several hundred worshipers bow their heads in silent prayer.

title: Inflation News Heartens the Bond Market
description: After several weeks of nervousness and a heavy selloff in the bond market, traders and investors got some reassuring news on inflation yesterday and drove the yields on Treasury bonds and notes sharply lower.

title: Right. Left. Baerga Knocks Out Yanks in 7th.
description: If the Yankees were unconcerned about their pitching, if they thought the fourth spot in the starting rotation and the vaunted bullpen were reliable, they were given enough evidence tonight to prove that maybe they should worry a bit. Reams of evidence.

title: Restaurants
description: The neighborhood around Park Avenue South and 29th Street has become a bistro hub of sorts, with three respectable representatives clustered there. The first was Park Bistro, an immensely popular spot; next was an offshoot across the street, Les Halles, with a butcher shop motif; the latest, not officially related but a kindred spirit, is Pigalle.

title: Corrections
description: A heading on the front page of The Metro Section in some copies yesterday, in a contents reference to an article about the Yankees-Indians game, misidentified the Yankee pitcher who gave up a two-run homer that gave the Indians a 4-2 victory. He was John Habayan, a relief pitcher.

title: Michael Marsh, Author And Quaker, Dies at 75
description: Michael Marsh, an author and Quaker leader, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Washington. He was 75 and lived in Washington.

title: The President's Budget Priorities
description: The budget presented yesterday by the Clinton Administration contained no big surprises. The line-by-line details in its 1,300 pages mirrored the economic plan Mr. Clinton outlined in February. Still, the budget's release provides a good occasion to measure the progress and implications of President Clinton's assault on Reagan-Bush economics.

title: No Headline
description: Trading upon Los Angeles's 'good will' in Brooklyn would have been fatal to the defendants because many Brooklynites despise the Los Angeles Dodgers. -- CONSTANCE BAKER MOTLEY, a Federal judge, upholding use of the name Brooklyn Dodger Sports Bar. [ B1:5. ]

title: With Chance To Advance, Nets Stay In Retreat
description: Seven games and counting, and as one former Net might have said, the ship be sinking. Well, not exactly sinking but on a course to Cleveland for the playoffs.

title: Paris Affirms Its Links To Bonn on Economy
description: Prime Minister Edouard Balladur said today that the new center-right French Government was committed to a strong franc whose exchange rate against the German mark should remain unchanged, and he reiterated that France would establish an independent central bank similar to the Bundesbank in Germany.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL -- Named John Shelby manager; Tim Conroy pitching coach and Bob Zeihen coach at Butte of the Pioneer League and Phil Wellman manager; Bill Sizemore pitching coach and Juan Bustabad coach at Lethbridge, Canada of the Pioneer League. National League CINCINNATI REDS -- Sent William Canate, outfielder, to Indianapolis of the American Association for medical rehabilitation.

title: DOW JONES & CO. (N)
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its net income jumped more than 90 percent in the first quarter, primarily because the comparable 1992 results were depressed by a one- time accounting charge of $10.8 million.

title: Movies Remind Us That Power Can Corrupt; A Striking Expose
description: To the Editor:

title: There'll Always Be an England, In New York
description: IN wave after wave, immigrant groups have arrived in New York and slowly bent it to their needs. The British are no exception. Thrown out in 1781, they have been making their way back of late, in a trickle that has become a flood in the last decade.

title: Quiet Leader: Semak Is Devils' M.V.P.
description: Although Slava Fetisov is the most heralded and Aleksei Kasatonov the most vocal, it is Aleksandr Semak who is making the biggest impact among the Russians on the Devils this season.

title: LifeCell Corp.(NSC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 206,000 non-cash expense from the issuance of capital stock and warrants.

title: Yeltsin Acts to Sweeten Pot for Voters
description: Despite a new round of appeals and incentives from abroad to push for economic reform, President Boris N. Yeltsin is raising wages, increasing spending and issuing low-cost credits for bankrupt industries as part of a campaign to win a crucial referendum this month.

title: First Virginia Banks reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pop/Jazz; Bacharach Reminisces on a Magic Moment
description: American pop history has been scrutinized so intensively over the last 15 years that it is easy to forget that the songwriters who created many of the best-selling records of the 1950's and 60's were too busy scrambling for hits and meeting deadlines to consider whether their work would last.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Two Executives Promoted in Reorganization at Staples
description: Staples Inc., the creator of office-supply supermarkets geared toward small businesses, announced a reorganization of its top management, including the resignation of its president and the promotion of two top executives.

title: INSIDE
description: Problems in Technology Sale

title: Audi of America Hires Jones-Lundin
description: Audi of America in Auburn Hills, Mich., said yesterday that had it retained the consulting company of Jones-Lundin Associates in Chicago to help manage the review on its estimated $23 million to $28 million account, which had been at DDB Needham Worldwide since 1969. The account was placed in review on March 23 and DDB Needham was notified two days later that it would not be included in the review. A decision is expected in early summer.

title: Murdoch Requests Waiver
description: Lawyers for Rupert Murdoch late Wednesday formally asked the Federal Communications Commission to allow him to buy The New York Post even though his ownership of a television station in New York City, WNYW-TV, Channel 5, would normally prohibit the acquisition.

title: Article 709793 -- No Title
description: Surrounding the corner of West Broadway and Grand Street in SoHo are four French bistros, fueling their youthful customers with equal parts style and food, like gas stations at a suburban crossroad. Among them but standing almost sardonically apart is Toad Hall, the name both a nod to the house in the classic children's book "Wind in the Willows" and a playful jab at the Francophile pretensions of the bistros.

title: A Court for Real People
description: Mario Cuomo's withdrawal from consideration for the Supreme Court is another baffling event in his career but only a glitch in President Clinton's search to fill the impending vacancy. We may never learn how well New York's Governor could fit Mr. Clinton's description of him: "a legal scholar who also understands the impact of the law on real people's lives."

title: Art in Review
description: Thomas Ruff 303 Gallery 89 Greene Street (near Spring Street) SoHo Through April 24

title: SHAREHOLDERS SUE LIFETIME OVER REJECTION OF OFFER
description: Three lawsuits have been filed by shareholders of the Lifetime Corporation of Boston, contending that the company breached its fiduciary duty when it rejected a $261 million buyout offer from Abbey Healthcare Group Inc. Lifetime rejected Abbey's offer -- its second -- on Tuesday, saying that the price of $27.50 a share was inadequate. Abbey made an initial offer of $23.50 a share on March 12. On Wednesday, Abbey, of Costa Mesa, Calif., withdrew its sweetened offer, citing the Lifetime board's refusal to meet with Abbey representatives. From the time of the first offer, Lifetime's shares had climbed to $25.25, from $16.75 Yesterday, Lifetime's shares fell $3.625, to $21.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: No Headline
description: Rabbi Joseph Dov Soloveitchik, a major Jewish philosopher who shaped Orthodox Judaism in America through his writing and lectures and his ordination of more than 2,000 rabbis, died last night at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 90.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jimmy Heath's Saxophone

title: BELGRADE IS URGED TO CONTROL SERBS
description: The International Court of Justice urged Yugoslavia today to assure that any forces it controls in Bosnia and Herzegovina do not violate the 1948 convention banning genocide.

title: COCA-COLA SHARES FIRM AFTER FALLING TO A LOW
description: Shares of the Coca-Cola Company fell yesterday to a 52-week low but recovered a bit after the company said it was buying back as much stock as it could. Coca-Cola's chairman and chief executive, Roberto C. Goizueta, said that the stock's recent swoon has created "the buying opportunity of the decade."

title: For Children
description: 'Origami for Easter' Queens Museum of Art Flushing Meadows-Corona Park Queens (718) 592-9700 Recommended ages: 8 and up Sunday

title: Clinton, in Gesture of Peace, Pops In on Pentagon
description: At the Pentagon early this morning, the alert was spreading by word of mouth and flashing messages on computer screens: The President is coming! The President is coming!

title: Dynamics Research reports earnings for Qtr to March 20
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Purveyors of Requisites
description: New York City is not exactly a hardship post, but British subjects who live here must think strategically in order to satisfy basic cultural needs. Below is a selection of businesses that form part of the British support system, with bonus points awarded for unusual contributions. Drink

title: Torahs Rise From Rubble After Blaze At Synagogue
description: Members of a Jewish congregation in Brooklyn whose synagogue was destroyed by fire on Wednesday afternoon rejoiced last night when three Torahs -- the scrolls that Jews hold sacred -- were recovered, undamaged, from a safe in the rubble of the building.

title: Bit of Hartford's Past Yields to Change and Chains
description: FOR 158 years, through the days of whale oil lamps and the brief flowering of a local literary culture around such luminaries as Mark Twain and Harriet Beecher Stowe, Huntington's Book Store knew Hartford well enough to survive just about anything.

title: Abroad at Home; No Place To Hide
description: Judging by his words and his tone of voice, President Clinton feels anguished at the savagery being committed by Serbian forces in Bosnia. He agreed when a reporter said this week that he seemed frustrated at the prospect of the Serbs getting what they want by force.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Washington's efforts to restart the Middle East peace talks misidentified the forum in which Bill Clinton spoke about Jerusalem shortly before the November election. It was in an interview with Middle East Insight, not the Middle East Institute.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: France Takes Tough Stance On Crime and Immigration
description: France's new conservative Government announced a major campaign today to combat urban crime and illegal immigration, but it is already under fire from human rights groups after three shootings this week in which the police killed two young men and wounded a third.

title: Taylor Very Near a Return Ticket
description: It seems all but official: Lawrence Taylor is coming back to play another day for the Giants.

title: TOP HERMAN'S EXECUTIVE SHIFTS TO A NEW POST
description: Martin Burke, hired three weeks ago as president of Herman's World of Sporting Goods, has relinquished his post to become president of the holding company that was formed to acquire the chain, now in bankruptcy protection. Before joining Herman's, Mr. Burke tried to resuscitate the ailing Conran's Habitat stores in the United States.

title: Books of The Times; An Antidote for Optimism After the Cold War
description: Out of Control Global Turmoil on the Eve of the 21st Century By Zbigniew Brzezinski 240 pages. A Robert Stewart Book/ Charles Scribner's Sons. $21.

title: Surgery Scheduled for Reds' Morris
description: Cincinnati Reds first baseman HAL MORRIS is scheduled to have surgery today on his separated left shoulder. He will be sidelined for 8 to 10 weeks.

title: The Sex Market: Scourge on the World's Children
description: BRUSSELS -- Doctors, police officers and social workers accustomed to dealing with sexual abuse are reporting a troubling phenomenon: children and adolescents are increasingly in demand as prostitutes because clients see them as "safer" and likely to be free of AIDS.

title: Producer Prices Rose 0.4% in March
description: In a report that calmed fears of resurgent inflation, prices received by American producers rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, but scarcely at all when figures for the erratic energy and food sectors are removed.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Monday about the Bosnian Serbs' strategy referred incorrectly to their leader. He is Radovan Karadzic.

title: Bill Rodgers Retires from Marathon
description: In his last marathon, BILL RODGERS wilted in the heat and humidity of Vietnam and walked the final three miles. In that race, two weeks ago, he took such a pounding he still feels the effects.

title: Islanders Cooked Again At Home
description: The Chicago Blackhawks aren't pretty, but they certainly are gritty. Tonight, they earned a 3-2 victory over the Islanders before 14,114 at the Nassau Coliseum, a performance that showed why Chicago reached the Stanley Cup finals last season and why the Hawks are tied with Detroit for the lead in the Norris Division.

title: Questech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected the effect of $ 372,000 net gain from early extinguishment of debt, and loss of $ 371,000 for the cumulative effect of the adoption of Statements of Financial Accounting Standards Nos. 109 and 112.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Penn Traffic Co., Johnstown, Pa., is offering $400 million of 9 5/8 percent senior subordinated notes due in 2005 at 99.127, to yield 9 3/4 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. and BT Securities Corp. Callable in five years, the notes are rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B by Standard & Poor's. * Seagram & Sons Inc., a unit of Seagram Co., is offering $200 million of 7 percent debentures due in 2008 at 100 through Goldman, Sachs. The noncallable notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

title: CLINTON OUTLINES SPENDING PACKAGE OF $1.52 TRILLION
description: President Clinton today sent Congress a $1.52 trillion budget full of new details showing how he wants to reduce the Government's deficit while spending more money on public works, education and retraining jobless workers.

title: Art in Review
description: Balla and Boccioni Paolo Baldacci Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through May 1

title: Today's TV Listings
description: Television and radio news, listings and advertising appear today on pages B14-15.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When KIRK DOUGLAS heard that MICHAEL JACKSON had paid $650,000 or so to set the poems of Robert Burns to music for a show, he thought, "What in in the world is this?" he said yesterday from Santa Barbara, Calif. "I was intrigued."

title: Sports of The Times; Waking Up The Echoes At Augusta
description: AFTER the roar for a 12-foot birdie putt at the first hole, a red 1 slid into the Masters scoreboards next to Arnold Palmer's name. After a louder roar for a 6-foot putt at the second, a red 2 for another birdie. After an even louder roar for a 15-foot putt at the third, a red 3 for another birdie. All over Augusta National yesterday, the azaleas were not yet in full bloom but the Masters reserve unit of Arnie's Army was in full cry.

title: Movies Remind Us That Power Can Corrupt; Our Reputation Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Executive Is Guilty in Fraud
description: A former executive director of a security agency for airports in the New York region pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to Federal charges of fraud and filing a false income-tax return.

title: Networks Don't Like Price of an Envelope
description: The networks have grown accustomed to bending to the will of the National Football League. But in the bidding for the 1994 Super Bowl, the networks are fighting back.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Shaw Sets 3-Point Mark Brian Shaw wasn't known as a 3-point shooter -- until last night. Shaw, who made only eight 3-pointers in three seasons before this one, set a National Basketball Association record by making 10 long-range shots in Miami's 117-92 victory in Milwaukee. The Heat guard sank six 3-pointers in the first quarter and added four in the third period to break the record of nine held by Dale Ellis and Michael Adams. Over all, Shaw was 10 of 15 from long range. "Once I had a few, my teammates kept encouraging me to shoot them," Shaw said. (AP) Rockets 95, Jazz 90: Vernon Maxwell's short jumper with 56 seconds turned the game around after a 23-point Houston lead had shrunk to 1 as the Rockets triumphed in Salt Lake City. Maxwell added two foul shots 12 seconds later to seal the Rockets' fourth straight victory. (AP) TENNIS Sabatini Wins Swiftly Gabriela Sabatini advanced posthaste to the quarterfinals, keeping alive her pursuit of a third straight Bausch & Lomb Championships title yesterday at Amelia Island, Fla., when Petra Langrova of the Czech Republic retired with a groin strain after winning only seven points in five games. Sabatini's next opponent will be eighth-seeded Leila Meskhi, who overwhelmed Angelica Gavaldon by 6-4, 6-0. In another third-round match, fourth-seeded Manuela Maleeva-Fragniere advanced by defeating Sabine Hack, 7-5, 6-4, and will face sixth-seeded Natalya Zvereva, who defeated Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, 7-5, 1-6, 6-4. Kathy Rinaldi lost to fifth-seeded Amanda Coetzer, 7-5, 5-7, 6-3. Coetzer faces Jennifer Capriati, who eliminated Argentina's Inez Gorrochategui, 6-3, 6-1. Courier Loses Second in Row in Japan: An upset sent Jim Courier out of a Japanese tournament for the second straight week yesterday, as he was beaten in the Japan Open. The defeat threatened his No. 1 position in the world ranking. Jonathan Stark, rated 77th worldwide, defeated Courier by 6-4, 6-2. Meanwhile, Pete Sampras fired 17 service aces and beat a Frenchman, Guillaume Raoux, 6-4, 6-7 (4-7), 6-3, and moved into position to take the top listing. (AP)

description: It is the field of screams that produces mostly official silence. Players like to talk around the subject of the infield at Shea Stadium, circling it as if it were a bunt they wished would spin foul. One gets onto the topic of the infield, and one finds oneself off the record.

title: TV Weekend; Travails of a Would-Be Cheerleader's Biggest Fan

The news media wasted no time in descending on the town of Channelview with opportunities for interviews on national television and contracts for possible movies.

title: Uncommon Parasite Tied to Ills in Milwaukee
description: The parasite implicated in a recent outbreak of intestinal illness in Milwaukee is uncommon but is being recognized more frequently throughout the world. The parasite, known as cryptosporidium, has caused several water-borne outbreaks elsewhere in the United States and England in the last 10 years.

title: Milwaukee's Water Suspected as Cause Of Intestinal Illness
description: An intestinal illness has stricken hundreds and perhaps thousands of people in the Milwaukee area during the last few weeks, and the city has now been seized with alarm by health officials' suspicion, first announced late Wednesday, that the cause may be contamination of the municipal water supply.

title: Security Issue Overlooked In Computer Concern's Sale

description: The World Boxing Council champion, LENNOX LEWIS, and FRANK BRUNO, Britain's top two heavyweights, are tentatively lined up to fight each other in September.

title: Students in Many States Raise Math Scores Steeply
description: Students' mathematics scores are substantially improving in half the states that took part in a national test, but 75 percent of students nationwide are still below standard, according to a Federal report released yesterday.

title: Limited U.S. Force Held Still an Option in Bosnia
description: As senior Administration officials prepared to meet on Friday to discuss American options in the face of the apparent collapse of peace talks in Bosnia, a senior Defense official insisted today that the use of limited force to stop Serbian attacks has not yet been ruled out.

description: Although female guards may pat down male inmates, a Federal appeals court has ruled that male guards at a Washington state prison cannot conduct random searches of clothed female inmates.

description: Yahtove Reid, an aspiring reggae artist, was the envy of many in his Brooklyn neighborhood and a star to his brothers and sisters. He was becoming known around his streets as a talented singer and a lot of people thought he was on his way up.

He started Wednesday night, when New York played the New Jersey Devils, as a wild card played in goal by an all-but-beaten hockey club. This time, Hirsch gets the nod partly out of desperation, but also partly out of necessity.

description: The opening sequence of "This Boy's Life" defines the style of almost everything that comes after in the film adaptation of Tobias Wolff's fine, spare boyhood memoir about growing up at loose ends in the 1950's. description: At a spirited and often testy public hearing in lower Manhattan yesterday, several members of the New York State Assembly vowed to enact legislation that would set tight restrictions on the ability of museums to sell off portions of their holdings.

description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he expects that 50,000 people will have applied to take the exam to become a New York City police officer when the filing deadline arrives at midnight tonight, the largest number for any police test in 11 years.

A Superstar for the Nursery-School Set
description: THE fans were dancing in the aisles, clapping gaily, chomping on teething rings. Not ordinary behavior for a Broadway audience, but then the main attraction was no ordinary Broadway performer. A dark-eyed, cheery man with a gentle manner, he is either a thrilling luminary or nobody special, depending on whether you are old enough to tie your own shoes. In the show-business cosmos, which is not the world that most interests him, Raffi Cavoukian occupies a unique position: baby's first superstar.

title: Needed: Minority Lawyers for Big Job
description: Susan Davis, who has a new law practice in Columbia, S.C., had never thought of the Resolution Trust Corporation as a potential client. But that changed after the agency pulled her name from a state bar association list and invited her to a conference this week on opportunities for minority and female lawyers.

title: Stocks Little Changed Despite Positive Data
description: In the last day of a trading week shortened by Good Friday, the stock market lurched downward for most of the session yesterday but ended with overall prices barely changed. Good news from the Government on inflation did not seem to command many traders' attention.

title: A Budget With a Chance
description: For years, Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush sent Congress budgets that were, it was commonly said at the time, dead on arrival. Since no one expected the Democrats who controlled Congress to approve the proposals of the Republican Presidents, the budget documents were more election manifestoes than operational plans, dependent more on stirring words than on sound fiscal analysis.

description: President Clinton delivered a wry eulogy of Hugh E. Rodham at a memorial service here today, describing his father-in-law as a staunch conservative who "thought Democrats were one step short of Communism -- but that I might be O.K."

title: North Korean Chief's Son Gains Military Post
description: In the clearest signal yet that North Korea is in the midst of a transition of power during its nuclear standoff with the West, the country's Government said today that Kim Jong Il, the son and heir apparent of the nation's founder, has been appointed chairman of the National Defense Committee, one of the three highest posts in the nation.

IRAQI GUNNERS FIRE ON AMERICAN JETS IN NORTH, U.S. SAYS
description: American fighter jets today bombed Iraqi antiaircraft batteries that fired at the aircraft as they flew a routine surveillance mission over the no-flight zone in northern Iraq, Administration officials said.

title: F.D.A. Issues Advice On AIDS Prevention
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that manufacturers of contraceptives had agreed to label their products to make it clear that most contraceptives prevent pregnancy but provide no protection against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, or against other sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Another Barely Balanced Budget
description: "New York State is on the way back," boasts Gov. Mario Cuomo in a confident commentary on the new state budget. But back to what? Negotiating in secret, he and the leaders of the Legislature patched together another year of precariously balanced books, but no long-term solution for the state's fiscal squeeze.
