Steere of New England Medical Center and Tufts University School of Medicine.

title: Alpha Microsystems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included pretax provision for restructuring of $ 2,676,000 related to the costs of closing Italian and French subsidiaries.c-Net income

title: Joint Recital Canceled
description: The pianist Maria Joao Pires and the violinist Augustin Dumay have canceled their Sunday recital at Alice Tully Hall because Miss Pires is ill. Refunds are available at the box office Monday through Saturday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., or by mail: Alice Tully Hall Box Office, 1941 Broadway, New York 10023.

title: On Their Own, More Parents Raise Funds to Fight Disease
description: When she was only 4 months old, Morgan Gelblum was found to have a disease her parents had never heard of, a genetic deterioration of the brain that means the little girl is never expected to sit, crawl, walk or talk, or live through childhood.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST CHICAGO CORP., Chicago, a bank holding company, said that its venture capital subsidiaries sold a $300 million portfolio to Ifint Diversified Holdings Inc., owned by Ifint S.A., a Luxembourg investment company.

title: Harleysville National reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 300,000, or 12 cents a share, from adoption of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Kite Out With Herniated Disks
description: TOM KITE's back problem has been diagnosed as herniated disks and the United States Open champion will be out of action for an undetermined length of time.

title: SynOptics Communications Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: SynOptics said that results for the latest quarter reflected the company's market and technology strength, coupled with the building market momentum for client/server computing.

title: Coca-Cola Co. (N)
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported strong results yesterday for the first quarter. Operating profit increased 18 percent, to $454 million; per-share earnings advanced 21 percent, to 35 cents.

title: Traveling Down
description: The Marietta Corporation has nothing to do with the military contractor or the Georgia town of the same name. It makes personal hygiene products, including soaps and shower caps, mainly for hotels and motels. Since early March, its stock has been trailing downward, reflecting sluggish prospects for the travel and lodging industry.

title: Molex Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings were restated to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid in November 1992.Molex said that currency translation increased net revenue by $ 1 million and net income by $ 300,000 for the third quarter. The 9 months' effect was to increase revenues by $ 14.7 million and to increase net income by $ 1.9 million.

title: Bankruptcy Needs Reform
description: The airline industry has lost more than $10 billion over the last three years. Even American, United and Delta -- the world's low-cost carriers -- have lost billions. The fundamental problem is excess capacity: Too many seats chase too few customers.

title: Spacelabs Medical (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
2 Inmates Let Nosair Make Extra Calls, Prison Says
description: Two prisoners at the state prison in Attica, N.Y., were charged yesterday with breaking prison rules to help El Sayyid A. Nosair make surreptitious phone calls. Mr. Nosair, who is serving time on charges related to the assassination of Rabbi Meir Kahane, has also come under scrutiny by investigators in connection with the World Trade Center bombing.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to the man at the left and carried an incorrect credit line. The man was Frederick M. Teach. The photographer was Glen Cochoran.

title: Xplor Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Samuel Walker, 83, A Realty Executive And Developer, Dies
description: Samuel R. Walker, a real-estate executive who directed the development of Sterling Forest in Orange County, died on Friday at his home in Niantic, Conn. He was 83.

title: State Urged To Rebuild L.I. Beaches
description: A task force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called today for the quick restoration at public expense of major Long Island beaches that suffered severe erosion during the winter's bruising storms.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN CASEY, winner of the 1989 National Book Award for his novel "Spartina," was about to leave his home in Charlottesville, Va., for a public appearance, "one of those things writers have to do," he recalled the other day, when "I heard a thunk on the front porch, and scurrying feet."

title: Witness Gives Step-by-Step Description of Killing
description: Salvatore (Sammy Bull) Gravano, a Mafia leader who turned informer, provided the anatomy of a murder for a jury yesterday as he described how he led a "hit team" that used guns, walkie-talkies and three cars to carry out the killing of a Queens man in 1988.

title: Huge Stimulus Package Is Announced by Japan
description: Japan announced on Tuesday a $116 billion stimulus plan, the biggest in its history, to rescue its faltering economy. The announcement gave a furious boost to the recent rally in the Tokyo stock market as a feeling spread here that an end to the nation's persistent recession, while not around the corner, is at least in view.

title: Methanex Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a loss of $ 700,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Regulators Tell of Clifford's Assurance on B.C.C.I.
description: As the bribery and fraud trial involving the Bank of Commerce and Credit International resumed in Manhattan yesterday, two former Federal bank regulators testified about Clark M. Clifford's statements regarding the bank's role in the takeover of another bank that would be controlled by Mr. Clifford.

title: Canadian Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbus Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Office Depot Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
Metropolitan Diary
description: SCENE: The Department of Motor Vehicles on Hudson Avenue in Brooklyn on a recent afternoon.

title: Unitrin Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 39.9 million from an accounting adjustsment reflecting the effect of the adoption of SFAS 106 and 109. The results for the 1992 first quarter have been restated accordingly.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How do you give a birthday party for someone beloved by friends and colleagues, who is known among them for her love of old songs and for more than a touch of hypochondria?

title: Sonic Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Sonic said that system-wide sales, increased 10.9 percent in the latest second quarter, and 13.4 percent in the latest 6 months. Company-owned comparable average sales per restaurant increased 0.3 percent in the latest quarter, and 3.2 percent for the latest 6 months.The company said system-wide comparable average sales per restaurant increased 3.4 percent in the latest quarter, and 4.9 percent for the latest 6 months.

title: Katharine Casey Gerrity; Volunteer, 65
description: Katharine Casey Gerrity, a volunteer worker in Westchester County, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. She was 65 and lived in Rye, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: U.S. to Double Aid for Russia, Diplomats Say
description: President Clinton told Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa Tuesday night that American contributions to Russia would increase by at least $2 billion, officials here said today.

title: Income at Westinghouse Dips 1.5% in First Quarter
description: The strengthening economy has not done much so far for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which reported today that net income from continuing operations in the first quarter of 1993 was down 1.5 percent from a year ago.

title: Recycling Answer Sought for Computer Junk
description: Eric Buechel tours his domain at a brisk pace, assessing his inventory with the pragmatic humor of an undertaker. In his warehouse sit rows of hulking computers, each weighing tons. They once whirred and flashed, but now they rest cold, unplugged, discarded.

title: Officials in Westchester Seeking Man Bitten by a Rabid Raccoon
description: In an extraordinary manhunt, Westchester County health officials searched today for an unidentified man who was bitten by a rabid raccoon on a Yonkers street on Friday and then fled before the authorities arrived to help him.

title: Laws May Change, but the Bible's Values Don't
description: To the Editor:

title: Mattingly Slips a Rung on Yank Ladder
description: Don Mattingly still receives the most thunderous ovations at Yankee Stadium, he still receives the most autograph requests from fans, he is still the one player Manager Buck Showalter solicits information from most often and he is still the No. 3 hitter in the lineup. Mattingly is the Yankees.

title: The Pop Life
description: Benefits for a Waitress

title: Sports of The Times; Jesse Jackson In the Sports Spotlight
description: THE story goes that a man was crawling on his hands and knees in the street at night. When a passer-by asked what he was doing, he replied, "Looking for my wallet." The other man said, "Oh, you lost it here?" "No," said the first man, "I lost it on the next block. But the light is better here."

title: D. F. Elmendorf, 69, Pulmonary Specialist
description: Dr. DuMont Frelinghuysen Elmendorf Jr., a retired physician who specialized in pulmonary diseases, died on Saturday at St. Peter's Hospice in Albany. He was 69 and lived in suburban Menands.

title: Versus Technology reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 245,000 from the sale of its U.K. subsidiary in July 1992. The company received $ 1,128,000 for the unit, which will be recognized over the next 20 months.Versus Technology said that 1992 revenues decreased because of economic conditions and the sale of the U.K. unit. Results reflected less than nine months of the unit's revenues.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 ARISTIDE ACCEPTS HAITI AMNESTY Diplomats and advisers to Haiti's exiled President say the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide has reversed himself and extended an offer of amnesty to his most bitter opponents among the army leadership. A1 U.N. ASSAILS SERBIAN SHELLING After months of restraint in their reaction to Serbian bombardments in Bosnia, senior United Nations harshly condemned the Serbian shelling on Monday that killed more than 50 civilians in the besieged Muslim enclave of Srebrenica. A1

title: Settlement in Sanderson Case Stops Trial
description: The secretary who accused former Alabama basketball coach WIMP SANDERSON of punching her in the face accepted a $275,000 settlement yesterday in Tuscaloosa, Ala., just as the case was going to trial.

title: Bank Set To Acquire Boston Five
description: Confident that the devastation in the New England real estate market has ended, the Citizens Financial Group, a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland, agreed yesterday to buy the Boston Five Bancorporation. Citizens, which is based in Providence and has $4.6 billion in assets, agreed to pay $95 million in cash, or $13 a share, for the $1.7 billion Boston-based savings bank.

title: Unique Mobility Inc. (ECM) reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Shares outstanding reflected secondary public offering in November 1991.

title:
Revitalization;
Kmart Sets Kansas City Housing Plan
description: Mention the names Kmart or Wal-Mart in the Midwest and what comes to mind is cornfields turned into shopping centers, with parking lots as far as the eye can see. But a redevelopment project here could change that.

title: Metro-Richelieu reports earnings for Qtr to March 13
EGYPT AND P.L.O. CONFER ON TALKS
description: President Hosni Mubarak met today with the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, and plans to see Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel on Wednesday as part of Egypt's effort to resume the Middle East peace talks.

title: Clinton Finds a Friendlier Chamber of Commerce
description: Grabbing for a piece of the Republican coalition, President Clinton went to the United States Chamber of Commerce tonight, stoking a feud between the powerful business group and conservatives in Congress.

title: Review/Television; A Light Look at Working After Dark
description: "All Night Long," a brisk tour of after-dark life in New York City, offers glimpses of people who work, people who play, people who talk and people who toss and turn. The subject brings out the literary in Dan Rather (or his scriptwriter), who calls this edition of "48 Hours" "a journey through the heart of darkness." But no fear, it is much less ominous and considerably more fun than Joseph Conrad's vision of Africa.

title: Photo Control (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net lossShare figures restated to reflect 5-for-4 stock split on March 19, 1993.

title: C-Cor Electronics Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
Church Groups Asked to Assist Homeless Effort
description: The Dinkins administration, facing contempt charges because of a shortage of shelter for homeless families, is asking religious groups for help.

title: Keystone Consolidated Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $ 69,949,000 from cumulative effect of adopting new accounting standards 106 and 109.

title:
Black Intellectuals, Jewish Tensions;
How to End The Impasse
description: After Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of Harvard's Afro-American Studies Department, condemned black anti-Semitism on this page, Emerge: Black America's Newsmagazine asked him and Cornel West, director of Princeton's Afro-American Studies Program, to discuss black intellectuals' role in reducing black-Jewish frictions. (Mr. West's essay came from his book "Race Matters.") These articles are adapted from the March issue.

title: S.& L. Agency Seeks Smaller Buyers
description: The Clinton Administration significantly expanded the opportunities today for smaller investors to buy the real estate and other assets once owned by bankrupt savings and loan associations.

title: Plan Is Afoot to Shift OTB Regulation
description: The chairman of the commission looking into the future of racing in New York State said yesterday that the group was concentrating on a plan to put racing in the hands of a corporation, a regulated monopoly that would also run offtrack betting in New York City, but not elsewhere in the state, at least for a while.

title: IP Timberlands reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shar earnings represented class A unit.

title: Bancfirst Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Judge Upholds Population Count
description: A Federal judge dealt a final rebuff today to a coalition of major cities seeking to force an adjustment of the 1990 census to make up for the acknowledged undercount of more than five million people, many of them black or Hispanic.

title: Stein Hires Manager And Consultant To Bolster Campaign
description: Seeking to ignite his stalled and fractious mayoral campaign, Andrew J. Stein, the New York City Council President, has hired a Queens political aide to be his campaign manager and a high-powered San Francisco consultant to handle direct mail and field operations.

title: Vietnam-Jeep Deal Is Seen
description: The Chrysler Corporation is working on a plan to produce its Jeep Cherokee vehicle in Vietnam once the United States trade embargo is lifted, Automotive News said this week.

title: Results Plus
description: GYMNASTICS Dawes Is Off to Good Start Dominique Dawes, the 16-year-old from Silver Spring, Md., registered a startling set of scores to win the first of six rounds of qualifying at the world championships in Birmingham, England. First came 9.712 for her floor exercise, then 9.618 for the vault and 9.75 on the asymmetric bars. She topped that with a 9.812 on the beam to complete a total of 38.892, which put her ahead of the other 14 competitors in her section. (AP) TENNIS Sampras Advances in Hong Kong Pete Sampras, starting a tournament for the first time as the world's No. 1 player, defeated Stephane Simian of France, 6-2, 6-4, in the first round of the Salem Open in Hong Kong. (AP) HORSE RACING Alydeed Wins at Keeneland Alydeed fought off Binalong in the stretch at Keeneland yesterday to win the $182,350 Grade III Commonwealth Breeders' Cup by a head and in stakes-record time. The winner, ridden by Craig Perret, covered the seven furlongs in 1:212/5 to take two-fifths of a second off Black Tie Affair's stakes record set in 1991. Alydeed paid $2.80 for $2 to win. (AP) BOXING Holmes Stops Canadian in Seven Rounds Larry Holmes, the 43-year-old former heavyweight champion, stopped a bloody Ken Lakusta of Canada in seven rounds in Bay St. Louis, Miss. The handlers for Lakuta (21-20-1) called off the bout before the eighth round because of a bleeding cut around the boxer's left eye. Holmes (57-4) is 9-1 since coming out of a three-year retirement. (AP)

title: New York Has to Make School Board Elections Voter-Friendly; Concerned and Fed Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Baker Visits Bucs 2d Time
description: In their six seasons as wide receivers with the Giants, Mark Ingram and Stephen Baker were close friends and close in their football accomplishments. Now Ingram has moved to the Miami Dolphins with a three-year, $4 million contract, and Baker is trying to get similar money in the National Football League's new era of free agency.

title: Dispute Over the Kahlo and Rivera Legacy
description: For almost two years, as the world's fascination with the Mexican painter Frida Kahlo fed a stream of pilgrims to the funny blue house in which she was born and died, visitors there were met by bolted doors and a guard mumbling about "repairs."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League ATLANTA BRAVES -- Traded Mark Davis, pitcher, to the Philadelphia Phillies for Brad Hassinger, pitcher. Assigned Hassinger to Durham of the Carolina League.

title: Crompton & Knowles reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-After a charge of $ 5,800,000 from adoption of FASB 106 and FASB 109, new methods of accounting for retirees' benefits and income taxes.

title: INSIDE
description: New Buyers of S.& L. Assets

title: Rio de Janeiro Journal; The Collor Story (Cont.): Much Ado About Magic
description: For most Brazilians, more than enough drama was packed into the impeachment of the President last September on charges of profiting from a multimillion-dollar extortion ring. But now a first wave of memoirs is renewing the national uproar by asserting that the President, Fernando Collor de Mello, tried bribery and black magic to ward off the first impeachment of a Brazilian President.

title: Vance, Leaving, Sees Hope for Bosnia Plan Despite Fighting
description: Winding up nearly 19 months as a peace negotiator in the Balkan conflict, Cyrus R. Vance said he thinks that the plan he helped frame for ending the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina is still "very much alive" despite a new surge in fighting.

title: U.S. Shouldn't Export Mineral Industry Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Starks Stylish Despite a Flak Jacket
description: With one eye on the Chicago Bulls and another on John Starks's injured ribs, the Knicks may have been looking past the Washington Bullets last night.

title: Mississippi Democrat Is Elected to Congress
description: Bennie Thompson, a liberal Democrat turned back a surprisingly strong bid by a conservative Republican today to win the Congressional seat vacated by Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy.

title: The High-Tech Way to Grocery Shop
description: EACH week, Marilynn Glazer of Skokie, Ill., shops for groceries by sitting down at her personal computer and typing the log-on "peapod." She then scans the screen for sales. She sorts and chooses items by unit prices. She checks to see when she last bought milk and other staples. And within 90 minutes, her order arrives at her door. The delivery person even accepts coupons and recycles her plastic bags.

title: France Will Replace Its General in Bosnia
description: The French Defense Minister today confirmed the imminent replacement of an outspoken French Army officer, Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon, as commander of United Nations forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Old Fear Haunts Poles in South Africa
description: The first worshipers arriving for the Polish-language Easter Mass at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Pretoria found a banner strung across the door, painted with a warning: "We Will Kill You All for Our Leader."

title: A. C. McGiffert Jr., A Seminary Leader And Educator, 100
description: The Rev. Arthur C. McGiffert Jr., a retired Congregationalist minister who was president of two seminaries, died on Friday in a retirement community in Claremont, Calif. He was 100.

title: Edmund H. Kellogg, Professor Emeritus And Diplomat, 81
description: Edmund Halsey Kellogg, a retired Foreign Service officer, conservationist and professor emeritus at Vermont Law School, died Friday at the Kendal retirement community in Hanover, N.H. He was 81.

title: Petrovic Returning to Nets In Time for Playoff Run
description: Chuck Daly was joking with reporters during an impromptu break in today's Nets practice.

title: Ballard Medical Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago results are restated to reflect the 4-for-3 stock split on Feb. 26.

title: OFFER OF AMNESTY REMOVES OBSTACLE TO ACCORD IN HAITI
description: Removing a final major obstacle to settling Haiti's 18-month political crisis, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide has reversed himself and extended an offer of amnesty to his most bitter opponents among the army leadership, diplomats and advisers to the ousted President say.

title: Crestar Financial Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dieter Plage, 57, Dies Filming in Rain Forest
description: Dieter Plage, a German wildlife film maker whose documentaries brought attention to African conservation issues, died in an accident while filming in the rain forest in Sumatra on April 3, said a spokesman for Survival Anglia Ltd., a British film company. He was 57 years old.

title: Review/Dance; On the Heels of Abstraction
description: H. T. Chen is a choreographer who tells stories. He has perfected a style based on American modern dance and Asian traditional dance and theater, all of which the Shanghai-born Mr. Chen has studied and performed. But in "Opening the Gate," a work-in-progress presented on Friday night at La Mama E.T.C. Annex Theater, Mr. Chen comes uncharacteristically close to abstraction. There are suggestions of animal life in the dancers' snaking arms and small pounces, and he hints at the imagery of birth, said to be the dance's theme. But most of all, the fast-flowing piece is throbbing, swirling spectacle.

title: Arbor National HoldingsInc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included pre-tax charges of $ 535,000 and $ 1.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from termination of bank application and integration of acquired branch networks.c-Included pro forma adjustments for income taxes as if the company had been a C corporation.Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and year were not available; the company went public in August 1992.The company said certain amounts in the fiscal fourth quarter 1992 earnings were reclassified to conform to the fiscal 1993 presentation.

title: A French Twist on an Italian Staple
description: IT will take no more than 20 minutes to put this very savory meal together.

description: b-Included a charge of $ 437,000 for continuing research and development charges for the company's previously reported automated blood bank instrument project.Immucor Inc. aid its latest third quarter earnings were affected by foreign currency transaction losses on purchases of inventory in Italy and Germany totaling $ 225,000.

title: BHA Group (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Educators Find a Lot to Like in a Little Increase
description: Even though President Clinton has proposed increasing Education Department spending by less than 2 percent for the next fiscal year, his new budget is winning praise from education groups because of its emphasis on those at either end of the public-school ladder: preschool children and high school students who need job training.

title: Document Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year included a one-time charge of $ 272,000 for restructuring operations and certain debts.

title: New York Has to Make School Board Elections Voter-Friendly
description: To the Editor:

title: Compaq and Microsoft Plan Alliance
description: Two powerhouses in the personal computer industry, the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation, today announced an alliance to develop innovations intended to keep their momentum going.

title: Comdial Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comdial Corp said first quarter results reflected benefits of the sale of its electromechanical phone operation in July of last year. It said the sale caused a $ 2.7 million decrease in latest-quarter revenes, but increased the company's gross margin to 26 percent from 22 percent.

title: Willamette Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $ 26,364,000, or 48 cents a share, reflecting the adoption of FASB 106 and 109, relating to post-retirement benefits and income taxes.

title: Consolidated Papers (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 38,047,000 which is related to accounting changes for post-retirement benefits and income taxes.

title: Cypress Semiconductor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Court Upholds the Crazy Horse Beer Label
description: After months of uncertainty, the Original Crazy Horse Malt Liquor will be flowing again. A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a law banning the use of the name was unconstitutional. The Government had argued that it was preventing "offensive exploitation" of Crazy Horse, a revered leader of the Sioux Indians.

title: Rubbermaid Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net charge of $ 2,831,000 from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principles.

title: BSD Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: G.M. Grants Its Chairman A Pay Raise
description: Expanded duties at the world's biggest auto maker are earning John G. Smale, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, a fatter paycheck than before.

title: For Rangers, There Had to Be a Mourning After
description: Today, Mark Messier was publicly shunned by Team Canada. There was no invitation to play for his country in the world championships in Germany. Adam Graves was called, so was Mike Gartner. Messier was not.

title: Judge Approves Plan to Bar Leader From Teamster Posts
description: A Federal judge yesterday approved an agreement permanently banning Barry Feinstein, a prominent New York City labor leader, from holding office in the teamsters union.

title: GOVERNOR'S TRIAL OPENS IN ALABAMA
description: Guy Hunt, the Primitive Baptist preacher who in 1986 became Alabama's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction, looked on calmly today as prosecutors in the first day of his felony trial accused him of illegally using his office to collect $200,000 for his personal use.

title: Eating Well
description: HERE'S why Americans are confused about nutrition:

title: Pentagon Is Wary on Hanoi Text; Families See Proof of Lies
description: Pentagon officials cautioned today against putting too much stock in a newly unearthed document that suggests that North Vietnam lied about the number of American prisoners it held in 1972.

title: Delchamps Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
Parts Were Denied, Satellite Developer Charges
description: Developers of the next generation of military reconnaissance satellites were denied access to computer parts they wanted to use because the manufacturer feared a military contract would jeopardize the company's chances of being sold to Japan, a Government contractor said today.

title: New Questions on the P.O.W.'s
description: The long smoldering issue of unaccounted-for American prisoners from the Vietnam War has flared anew. Hanoi has only its long history of duplicity on the P.O.W. issue to blame for this latest ambushing of its hopes for more normal ties.

title: General Electric Co. (N)
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that profits rose 9.6 percent in the first quarter, led by a strong performance at its financial unit, GE Capital Services. The unit's net income was up 22 percent in the quarter, compared with a year ago.

title: Larizza Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on extinguishment of $ 711,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina referred incompletely to violations of the no-flight zone. The violations, which have involved transports and medical evacuation flights, have been committed by Serbs, Croats and Muslims, although the greatest number have been committed by the Serbs.

title: A Feud and a Book Unplug the Cork On the Gallo Empire
description: IN the spring of 1983, Joseph Gallo Jr., the younger brother of Ernest and Julio Gallo, opened a cheese factory near his home in Livingston, Calif. Joseph Gallo was a rancher and farmer who had grown rich selling grapes to his brothers' E. & J. Gallo winery, 40 miles north of Livingston in Modesto. He envisioned the cheese project as a way to use surplus milk from his large dairy farm.

title: Review/Music; An Oratorio Enhanced With Parallel Lives
description: It is impossible to hear Mendelssohn's first oratorio, "St. Paul," without considering the theological, historical and personal baggage that comes with it. That and its having been overshadowed by its successor, "Elijah," made it an ideal work for Leon Botstein, a conductor who likes to resurrect rarities and who seems to relish peering into composers' baggage as much as performing their music. The work's sacred character also made it well suited to Easter Sunday, when Mr. Botstein performed it with the American Symphony Orchestra and the Pro Arte Chorale at Carnegie Hall.

title: First Comes Scoring, Then It's the Snoring
description: Perhaps, with a playoff berth clinched and all those potential post-season opponents scouting them at Nassau Coliseum tonight, the Islanders didn't want to reveal any secrets.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: ITALIAN broccoli, or broccoli rape, one of the early, bitter greens that act like a tonic to our bodies, is a sign of spring. It has longish stems and much smaller flower heads than conventional broccoli. Locally grown broccoli rape is available in spring and fall, and it is now being grown almost year-round in Salinas, Calif., the broccoli capital of America.

title: Review/Television; An Apocalyptic Vision of Wall Street's Future
description: Last represented on "Great Performances" with a trilogy of Mozart operas that he set in 1980's Manhattan, Peter Sellars returns to the public-television showcase tonight at 9 with "The Cabinet of Dr. Ramirez." This time, with an impish nod to the 1919 silent film "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari," he moves into the 1990's. The film is pretentious, exasperating and thoroughly fascinating.

title: Bond-Accounting Shift Is Approved
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, on a 5-to-2 vote, approved a new financial standard yesterday that will force banks and other financial institutions to report profits or losses when the market value of many bonds in their portfolios changes.

title: Review/Music; Works From Jazz to Buzz
description: Thursday night's performance at Merkin Concert Hall meant to bring together radically different performing esthetics. The first composer, Katrina Krimsky, presented standard post-hippie compositional ideas -- a little Indian music, a little jazz, a bit of violin -- and kept the normal concert etiquette, asking the audience to sit still and listen. The second, LaMonte Young, brought a minor sort of ideological framework to his piece. By situating his musicians around the hall, Mr. Young asked the audience to participate in a non-traditional way. In fact, everybody just sat there and listened. Given the general revolution in the relationship between audience and performer wrought by African-American and popular American music, the whole thing seemed more than a bit innocent.

title: ENDOSONICS SHARES SLIDE ON CATHETER'S TROUBLES
description: Shares of the Endosonics Corporation dropped by 14.7 percent yesterday in its second consecutive day of losses after its combination balloon and ultrasound catheter failed on Monday to win approval from a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel. The Pleasanton, Calif., company's stock fell to a 52-week low of $5.75, before rebounding a bit to close at $7.25, down $1.25 for the day in Nasdaq trading.

title: HONG KONG TALKS ARE SET TO RESUME
description: Britain and China announced today that they would resume talks next week on Hong Kong's future, a decision that suggests a long and bitter impasse may have finally been broken.

title: Electronic Toll Collection Still a Dream for Drivers
description: While drivers in Chicago, Dallas and Boston can breeze through some toll plazas without rolling down a window or stopping, drivers in the metropolitan New York area still face old-fashioned traffic jams when they approach a tunnel or toll bridge. A plan for electronic toll collection istwo years behind schedule, delayed by a web of complications and technical obstacles.

title: Public & Private; Uniquely Perilous
description: Life over the course of the last half-century has been confusing for those people who manufacture and sell cigarettes. Their product went from being an accepted part of daily life to a suspected carcinogen to the most reviled legal substance in America.

title: Drug Use by Younger Teen-Agers Appears to Rise, Counter to Trend
description: After years of declining drug use among high school students, researchers and rehabilitation specialists said yesterday that there are signs of an increase in marijuana, cocaine and LSD use among the youngest teenagers.

title: Boise Cascade Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 43,320,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change.The company said effective as of Jan. 1, 1993, the company adopted new Financial Accounting Standards Board requirements that govern the way deferred taxes are calculated and reported. Adoption of these requirements based on a one-time adjustment had no effect on the company's first-quarter 1993 net loss. Financial statements for prior periods have not been restated.The company also said during the fourth quarter of 1992, it adopted, effective as of Jan. 1, 1992, the Financial Accounting Standards Board's new requirements applicable to accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions. The company's retiree health care costs that had previously been recorded when paid are now accrued.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST FINAL REBUFF FOR BID TO REVISE '90 CENSUS

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Sara Lee Names a President, From Europe
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said today that it had named Cornelis Boonstra to succeed Paul Fulton as president and chief operating officer.

title: Freedom of Choice Bill Protects Women
description: To the Editor:

title: An End to the New York Games?
description: The New York Road Runners Club was awaiting an 11th-hour rescue yesterday from an undisclosed international sponsor, or it would have to cancel the New York Games track meet scheduled for Wien Stadium in northern Manhattan on May 22.

title: Abortion-Rights' Scorned Prophet; Hated by Both Sides, Bill Baird Raises Hackles, Not Funds
description: Mention his name on the phone and Betty Friedan's gravelly voice turns into liquid vitriol. Then she hangs up.

title: ALC Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 13,500,000, or 38 cents a share, from the adoption of FAS 109.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 1,326,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: New Basis For a Rally In Bonds
description: With concerns about inflation dampened by restrained price increases in March, a new theme is popping up in the bond market. And if it catches hold, yields on the 30-year bond and other Treasury securities could break the historic lows reached at the beginning of March.

title: Clean-Air Laws Push Big 3 To Cooperate on Electric Car
description: In an extraordinary collaboration by Detroit's auto makers, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are discussing jointly building an electric car to meet the requirements of the clean-air law first enacted in California and recently adopted by several Northeastern states.

title: Review/Theater: Three Men on a Horse; An Odd Couple Take to the Track For Love and Luck
description: In its two seasons on Broadway, the National Actors Theater has often seemed like the greenest of expansion teams. Can anyone here play this game? Among the victims were Feydeau and Chekhov (although Shaw fared better with "St. Joan"). But nothing can equal "Three Men on a Horse," which opened last night at the Lyceum Theater with a reunion of Tony Randall and Jack Klugman, television's "Odd Couple." This time, Mr. Randall's company is defeated by a double burden of miscasting and maladroit acting. The way to revive "Three Men on a Horse" would be to rejuvenate it with an ensemble of young actors and clowns. Instead, the approach is the opposite: a geriatric production.

title: ResourceCan reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a writedown of investments of $ 546,000 in the quarter and year.c-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Who's Coach of Year? Bet on Riley
description: A year ago, the Knicks were about to lose a five-game lead with eight to play and blow the Atlantic Division to the Boston Celtics, and it was painfully obvious to Pat Riley why.

title: TRC Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 320,000 related to staff reductions, closing of sales offices and an additional allowance for accounts receivable.c-Net income

title:
Black Intellectuals, Jewish Tensions;
A Weaving Of Identities
description: After Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of Harvard's Afro-American Studies Department, condemned black anti-Semitism on this page, Emerge: Black America's Newsmagazine asked him and Cornel West, director of Princeton's Afro-American Studies Program, to discuss black intellectuals' role in reducing black-Jewish frictions. (Mr. West's essay came from his book "Race Matters.") These articles are adapted from the March issue.

title: As Los Angeles Tenses, Fears for Rights Grow
description: In a city where every conversation seems to turn to speculation about what last year's arsonists and looters might do, Paul L. Hoffman's fear has a different cast. He is afraid of what the police might do.

title: Fresh Choice Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 21
Weis Markets reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Included income of $ 1,046,000, or 2 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment reflecting FASB 109.

title: CBS Has $54 Million Profit In 1st Quarter; Stock Rises
description: A strong performance by its television network helped CBS Inc. post a first-quarter profit yesterday that sent its stock soaring.

title: U.S. Shouldn't Export Mineral Industry Jobs; Green Effetists
description: To the Editor:

title: Indy Making Room for Stock Cars
description: The Indianapolis Motor Speedway has scheduled a news conference for this morning in Indianapolis at which it is expected that the track will announce that for the first time since the Indianapolis 500 began in 1911, the historic oval will be the site of a second race.

title: Micropolis Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Auto Makers In Joint Patent
description: The Big Three auto makers said today that their research consortium had been awarded its first patent. The patent covers technology that one day may permit auto makers to substitute parts made of lighter-weight plastic composite materials for parts made of steel, thus improving fuel economy.

title: Ending Restraint, U.N. Aides Denounce Serbs for Shellings
description: After months of restraint in their reaction to Serbian bombardments of Muslim populations in Bosnia, senior United Nations officials today harshly condemned the Serbian shelling on Monday that killed more than 50 civilians in the besieged enclave of Srebrenica.

title: Citizens Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Lucrative Nike Deal for Krzyzewski
description: A change of emblems for Duke's basketball team could be worth millions to coach MIKE KRZYZEWSKI. The Blue Devils -- who for years have worn Adidas shoes, the ones with three stripes -- will switch to Nike.

title: KLLM Transport Services Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
Campus Journal; Retracing Freedom's Route to Oberlin
description: Somewhere in West Virginia, Michael DiAngelis began looking for the signs: a white stripe on a chimney or a hanging quilt with black in the pattern. Either signal told escaping slaves that they had found a "safe house."

title: MathSoft Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net lossSome of latest results were pro forma, as the company went public on Feb. 3, 1993.

title: Review/Music; New Voices In 'Ariadne' At the Met
description: A number of singers entered the cast of Richard Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos" for the last performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening, but attention centered on Deborah Voigt in the title role. Ms. Voigt, a young American soprano, has already achieved acclaim in a variety of roles, including her Ariadne at the Boston Lyric Opera two seasons ago.

title: Bridge
description: It is generally understood that a duplicate player must strive for overtricks, even perhaps jeopardizing a contract to do so. It is not so well understood that this effort is sometimes right and sometimes wrong.

title: Hancock Holding Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Angola's Killer of the Dream
description: Rarely has a sore loser in an election wreaked such havoc as Jonas Savimbi in Angola. During a civil war that began with Angola's independence in 1975, Mr. Savimbi insisted that his Unita rebels were democrats thirsting for a chance at the polls to unseat a leftist Government in Luanda. He got his wish last September, but his rival, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, won by a plurality in a generally fair first-round vote that was to be followed by a runoff. But instead of contesting the runoff, Mr. Savimbi resumed fighting, ferociously.

title: What You Reveal To a Psychotherapist May Go Further
description: MILLIONS of people in recent weeks have heard of psychotherapists testifying in court about intimate emotional details told to them by Woody Allen, Mia Farrow and their children, or by Sol Wachtler, the former Chief Judge of New York State.

title: 46 Arrested in Drug Raids
description: More than 200 police officers broke up what they described as a major heroin ring yesterday in Lower East Side housing projects, arresting 46 people. Among those arrested in the raids shortly after dawn was Richard Rodriguez of Union, N.J., who was described by Drug Enforcement Administration officials as the leader of the group. The suspects included suppliers to dealers who, police said, operated in the Riis, Wald, Baruch, Campos Place and Bracetti Place projects in Manhattan. In addition to the arrests, nine guns and one pound of heroin were confiscated. John Dowd, a special agent of the D.E.A., said the raids were made after a nine-month investigation.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: WITH the first gentle breezes of spring comes one of the great delicacies of the sea: soft-shell crabs. The season has arrived once again in the Northeast, having gradually spread north from ocean waters off the Middle Atlantic States.

title: Administration Considers 'Penalty Tax' to Hold Down Health Costs
description: Groping for ways to carry out a crucial feature of President Clinton's health-care plan, the White House is considering a "penalty tax" on doctors and hospitals to constrain medical spending.

title: Dow Maintains Momentum, Rising 15.94
description: The reviving stock market struggled yesterday to keep its momentum of Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 15.94 points, less than half what it gained the day before.

title: Steinbrenner Adds Randolph As an Assistant to Michael
description: Willie Randolph, the second baseman who defined class and stability during his 13 seasons with the Yankees, returned to the organization last night when George Steinbrenner named him an assistant general manager. The announcement was made at a dinner in Manhattan to welcome the Yankees back to New York.

title: Park Communications Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No Headline
description: "Those firing the guns at Srebrenica knew that the town was packed with many thousands of displaced people, mainly women and children. This kind of attack can never be justified, whatever the provocation. It is an atrocity." -- CEDRIC THORNBERRY, the top U.N. civilian official in what used to be Yugoslavia. [ A8:5. ]

title: No Definite Findings In Park Ave. Deaths
description: Results of an autopsy on the bodies of a couple found dead in their Park Avenue apartment were inconclusive, the New York City Medical Examiner said yesterday, leaving open the question of why and how they died.

title: E-Z Serve Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Included accounting adjustment of a $ 9,637,000 writeoff of goodwill related to the acquisition of the company in 1986 by its former parent, Harken Energy Corp. in both the quarter and year. The quarter also included a provision of $ 8,171,000 to recognize the difference between the anticipated sale proceeds and the net book value of the remaining non-strategic commissioned marketers, and the shutdown of the Amber refinery and the Amber pipeline properties.c-Included an $ 8,436,000 reduction in the net book value of commissioned marketer and Amber properties, as well as a $ 3 million provision for environmental remediation, primarily related to underground storage tanks in both the quarter and year.

title: Cab Driver Killed After Kelly Announces Plan to Add Protection
description: A taxi driver was shot to death last night, only hours after Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said he would create a special detail to fight violent crimes against medallion and livery cabbies.

title: Mets Have The Rockies To Thank For This One
description: The best thing the Mets did tonight was keep their bats on their shoulders. In an eighth inning that reminded Colorado fans that theirs is an expansion team, New York drew four consecutive walks, received a dribbling wild pitch, saw Rockies outfielder Dante Bichette badly misjudge a ball in the outfield, batted around, scored six times and suddenly forgot it was freezing outside.

title: PFIZER AND P.& G. WITHDRAW FROM PLANNED DRUG VENTURE
description: Pfizer Inc. and the Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that they had called off their planned joint development of a drug for osteoporosis, a bone disorder that affects more than 100 million post-menopausal women worldwide. The companies said yesterday that they were unable to reach final terms, but they did not elaborate.

title: Mayor Eases Regulations On Sweeping of Gutters
description: The Dinkins administration, in a second move in two days to address complaints of small- and medium-sized business owners, said yesterday that it will suspend in some areas of the city a requirement forcing businesses to be responsible for sweeping the street within 18 inches of the curb in front of their stores.

title:
PRO BASKETBALL;
In Pursuit of Kukoc, a World Away
description: On the morning of Toni Kukoc's biggest day this year, he walks straight through the glorious lobby of the hotel headquarters of the European final four basketball championship. He is walking a lot like Bill Russell walked four decades ago. Kukoc is not wearing the headphones and dark glasses preferred by his American peers. He does not have to ignore dozens of fans asking for his autograph, because no one is asking.

title: A High Court Fantasy: Kunstler Ponders a Fancy
description: NO, absolutely not, said William M. Kunstler over lunch, he had never imagined himself on the Supreme Court. "My role is outside the system."

title: Paulson Capital reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Family Tree Nurtures a New Generation of Chefs
description: FOR years, aspiring young chefs in this country would brag about having worked under some famous French chef. Tossing a three-star French name around was like hanging an Ivy League diploma on the wall, a telling indication of how a young chef had been trained and where his aspirations might lead.

title: Personal Health
description: DURING a recent bicycle tour in Mexico, the tire of a passing truck turned a small stone into a potentially blinding missile. As the stone struck the lens of my protective glasses, I recalled a similar near-mishap much closer to home years ago that had turned me into a devotee of eye guards. Looking around at my 17 biking companions in Mexico, I was surprised to note that while all wore helmets as required by Backroads Inc., the tour sponsor, and nearly all wore sunglasses, no one else was wearing the polycarbonate eye protectors that had kept the stone from striking my eye.

title: Superior Industries International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
An auction at a fallen agency is a reminder of the industry's modern perils
description: GEER, DUBOIS died in February, but the funeral, such as it is, is being held this morning. The agency's office in the Flatiron neighborhood of lower Manhattan will reopen a final time to sell its few tangible assets.

title: Radio Receivers May Be Catching Echo of Big Bang, Scientist Says
description: A leading astrophysicist reported today that radio receivers in space and on the ground might be recording the passage of cosmic gravity waves, huge perturbations of space that echo the almost instantaneous expansion of the infant universe 15 billion years ago.

title: Let France Disclose Complicity With Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rebuffs Cities On Altering Census
description: A Federal judge dealt a setback to coalition of American cities that sought to force an adjustment of the 1990 census to make up for an acknowledged undercount of more than five million people, many of them black or Hispanic.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

description: b-After a charge of $ 65,901,000 which included charge of $ 67,222,000 on adoption of SFAS 106, and gain of $ 1,321,000 on adoption of SFAS 109.c-Net income

title: Home Shopping Network reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 6,900,000 from the repurchase and commitments to repurchase $ 143.3 million in long-term obligations prior to scheduled maturity in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $ 100,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.Latest quarter and 6 month's losses from continuing operations of $ 20,000,000 and $ 14,200,000, respectively, both included a provision of $ 22.7 million for inventory reserve related to change in merchandising philosophy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: The Pulitzer Prizes
description: ARTS Fiction -- "A Good Scent from a Strange Mountain," by Robert Olen Butler Drama -- "Angels in America: Millennium Approaches," by Tony Kushner History -- "The Radicalism of the American Revolution" by Gordon S. Wood Biography -- "Truman," by David McCullough Poetry -- "The Wild Iris," by Louise Gluck General non-fiction -- "Lincoln at Gettysburg: The Words That Remade America," by Gary Wills Music -- "Trombone Concerto" by Christopher Rouse JOURNALISM Public service -- The Miami Herald Spot news reporting -- The Los Angeles Times staff Investigative reporting -- Jeff Brazil and Steve Berry of The Orlando Sentinel Explanatory journalism -- Mike Toner of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution National reporting -- David Maraniss of The Washington Post International reporting -- John F. Burns of The New York Times and Roy Gutman of Newsday Beat reporting -- Paul Ingrassia and Joseph B. White of The Wall Street Journal Feature writing -- George Lardner Jr. of The Washington Post Commentary -- Liz Balmaseda of The Miami Herald Criticism -- Michael Dirda of The Washington Post Editorial cartooning -- Stephen R. Benson of The Arizona Republic Spot news photography -- Ken Geiger and William Snyder of The Dallas Morning News Feature photography -- The Associated Press staff Articles are on page B6.

title: AT THE OFFICE WITH: Louis Begley; Inventing a Life, Then Living It
description: LOUIS BEGLEY sits in the posh and hushed offices of Debevoise & Plimpton, the white-shoe law firm where he heads the international department. He is the very picture of the successful lawyer, from the size of his executive suite to the self-consciously simple and obviously expensive gray suit he wears.

title: Bucs' Bid to Carrington, Chargeers' Standout
description: Reserve safety DARREN CARRINGTON, the San Diego Chargers' special teams player of the year for the last two years, has signed a three-year, $2.35 million offer sheet with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. The Chargers have one week to match the deal signed Monday by Carrington, who led the Chargers last season with six interceptions, including three in the final four regular-season games. (AP)

title: Market Place; Wal-Mart Falls Out of Wall St.'s Favor
description: Investors in Wal-Mart Stores Inc. suffered another blow yesterday, as erosion continued in what was one of Wall Street's premier stocks for several years.

title: Microsoft's Profit Rises 36% On a 41% Gain in Revenue
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the dominant company in the personal computer industry, reported yesterday that it had earned $243 million, or 80 cents a share, in the fiscal third quarter ended March 31, an increase of 36 percent over the $179 million, or 60 cents a share, earned in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Learning Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shares outstanding reflected the company issuance of 1 million shares in its April 28, 1992 initial public offering and 1.2 million shares in a Feb. 4, 1993 equity offering.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Orthodox Holy Thursday and Good Friday, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City.

title:
PRO FOOTBALL;
Bledsoe Could Be at Head of the Draft Class
description: Amid the guessing on who will be the first quarterback selected in the National Football League draft April 25, Drew Bledsoe of Washington State doesn't back down as he is compared with Rick Mirer of Notre Dame.

title: You Can't Legislate Campus Relationships
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Control Spring Eagerness

title: Sales Rise For Vehicles Built in U.S.
description: Sales of domestically built vehicles excluding those built by the Ford Motor Company rose 14.8 percent in early April from the corresponding period a year ago.

title: U.S. ENVOY ISSUES WARNING TO SERBS
description: The Clinton Administration's special envoy to peace negotiations on the former Yugoslavia warned today that the United States would support lifting an arms embargo against Bosnia and Herzegovina unless the Serbian forces who have carved up the country agreed soon to a United Nations peace proposal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Layoff Appears to Hamper Becker Boris Becker didn't last long in his first tournament in two months, losing in the second round of the Nice Open in France yesterday to Franco Davin of Argentina, 4-6, 6-3, 6-1. Davin wore down Becker in the 2-hour-14-minute match, racing through the final set in less than 30 minutes. The second-seeded Becker lost his service two times in a row to fall behind, 4-0, in the third set before winning a game. "It was like playing against a wall," said Becker, who pulled out of a tournament in mid-February because of a viral infection. "I kept hitting winners and they kept coming back all the time. Then I missed a couple and that was it." (AP) Patrick McEnroe Advances in Hong Kong: Patrick McEnroe, a wild-card entry, upset eighth-seeded Jan Siemerink of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-4, to advance to the quarterfinals of the Salem Open in Hong Kong. McEnroe, 118th in the ATP ranking, will play the defending champion, Jim Courier, who is top-seeded. Courier, who lost his world's top ranking to Pete Sampras last week, moved into the quarterfinals with a 6-1, 6-4 victory over Jeremy Bates of Britain. (AP)

title: Clinton Said to Seek Increase in Intelligence Funds
description: President Clinton has asked Congress for authority to spend even more money on spy agencies, satellites and other intelligence activities in the 1994 fiscal year than it allotted for 1993, Congressional and Administration officials say.

title: Drama Surrounds Legend of a Kentucky Derby Past
description: Two and a half weeks before the 119th Kentucky Derby, racing people in the bluegrass country are keeping a vigil for a 16-year-old mare these spring days.

title: 12 Leaders of Failed Soviet Coup Get Their Day in Court, in Russia
description: Twelve leaders of the August 1991 coup attempt finally went on trial today, accused of betraying a motherland that no longer exists.

description: Nassau County's system of government was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal judge, who described the weighted-voting system on the Board of Supervisors as a mathematical quagmire.

title: YELTSIN IS BACKED AT TALKS IN TOKYO
description: The world's seven leading industrial nations pledged support today to President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia but were still struggling to assemble an aid program to promote his economic reforms and to help him win a nationwide referendum in less than two weeks.

title: Ohio Prisoners and Officials Make First Deal
description: Corrections officials who are engaged in a tense three-day-old standoff with rebellious inmates holding eight guards hostage at a state maximum-security prison here achieved their first success in negotiations today.

title: USF&G Selects Margeotes, Fertitta
description: The USF&G Corporation, a Baltimore-based insurer, said yesterday that it had selected Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss Inc. of New York to handle its account, previously handled by Gray Kirk/VanSant, formerly known as VanSant Dugdale & Company of Baltimore, for more than 60 years.

title: Critic's Notebook; How the Smile of Comedy Has Turned Wolfish
description: Back in the 1950's, standup comedy was a fairly uncomplicated craft. On television showcases like "The Ed Sullivan Show," an Alan King could start building a career on wife jokes. In clubs, a Lenny Bruce could venture into unconventional material. In either case, standup was a relatively modest job in the wide, wide world of popular entertainment.

title: Thatcher Assails West's Bosnia Policy
description: In a sudden and furious assault on Western policy in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Lady Thatcher has sharply condemned allied leaders, including her successor as Prime Minister of Britain, saying they lack the resolve to take stronger action on behalf of Bosnia's embattled Muslims.

title: Dover Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Turk Says Russia Is Tangled in Caucasus War
description: President Turgut Ozal of Turkey said today that there is heavy Russian involvement in the fighting in the Caucasus between Azerbaijan and Armenia.

title: Most vodkas are indistinct, so their ads are anything but.
description: THE tagline of a print advertisement for Jubilaeum citrus vodka urges consumers to "Keep Evolving." The vodka industry itself appears to have taken the words to heart.

title: Harken Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 172,000 in both the quarter and year.c-Net loss and the year is after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,997,000.

title: FOSSIL OFFERS CLUE Of A MISSING LINK
description: Scientists exploring the Gobi Desert of Mongolia have discovered fossils of an unusual animal that lived 70 million to 80 million years ago. It was the size of a long-legged turkey and had the long tail and strong teeth of a dinosaur but other traits of a flightless bird. The fossils could be critical to an understanding of the evolution of birds and flight.

title: Foreign Affairs; When to Forgive and Forget
description: Let's say it's authentic -- the document found in old Soviet archives in which a North Vietnamese general says Hanoi held three times the number of U.S. prisoners of war it had acknowledged to Washington. Suppose, further, that Hanoi killed the P.O.W.'s to destroy the evidence.

title: All American Communications (NMS) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 940,976.c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,029,485.The company said share earnings are after preferred dividends and non-cash charges related to accretion to increase the carrying value of redeemable stock.

description: Speaking About Architecture Cooper Union Great Hall, 7 East Seventh Street; (212) 753-1722.

title: Outside the Gates, Losing A Definition of Security
description: The manufacturing operation at the Pratt & Whitney headquarters here is known as the mother plant, the oldest and largest of Pratt & Whitney factories. The jet engines that rolled out of its bays led the world in aviation technology.

title: SHARP AND A.T.& T. ANNOUNCE JOINT MARKETING EFFORT
description: The Sharp Electronics Corporation and A.T.& T. announced a joint effort to market a wireless version of Sharp's Wizard line of electronic pocket organizers that will allow people to send and receive messages over the air. Under the agreement, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will supply a radio communications device about the size of a credit card that plugs into the pocket organizer and links it to A.T.& T.'s electronic mail system, known as Easylink. The organizers cost between $360 and $500.

title: Ex-Chairman of Grumman Is Fined $10,000 for Bank Fraud
description: After enduring a five-year Federal investigation into allegations that he took kickbacks from a subcontractor, the former chairman of the Grumman Corporation was fined $10,000 today for bank fraud.

title: Binks Manufacturing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $ 195,000, or 7 cents a share, for a one-time adjustment to comply with FASB 109, accounting for income taxes. Net income before the adjustment was $ 420,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Raul Juarena and the New York-Buenos Aires Connection Dance Theater Workshop

title: Levi Strauss Associates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Levi Strauss Associates is the privately held parent of Levi Strauss & Co.

title: It's Clinton's Turn to Bargain With Japan
description: A more harmonious and prosperous era in U.S.-Japan relations could start tomorrow if President Clinton plays his cards right during the visit of Japan's Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa. The first step must be for both sides to avoid the traditional omiyage, or gift, of a Japanese stimulus package. For nearly 50 years, Japanese prime ministers have come to Washington bearing gifts that usually have been promises to stimulate their own economy.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP. (N)
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., reported a 19 percent increase yesterday in its first-quarter net income, to $26.5 million, or 55 cents a share. The earnings were in line with analysts' expectations of 50 to 60 cents a share. But before the cumulative effect of accounting changes, the earnings were equivalent to 48 cents a share, a bit less than the analysts had forecast.

title: GANNETT CO. (N)
description: The Gannett Company reported yesterday that it earned $66.3 million in its first quarter this year, in contrast to a loss of $91.5 million in the 1992 quarter. The loss last year was in large part attributed to changes in accounting policies.

title: Wilander Comeback
description: Following in the footsteps of BJORN BORG, a fellow Swede, MATS WILANDER, is attempting a comeback. Wilander, the former No. 1-ranked player, gave up tennis last year after dropping to 157th in the world at the end of 1991. Wilander, 28 years old, was granted a wild card into the main draw of the A.T.&T. Challenge, an ATP Tour event that opens April 26 at the Atlanta Athletic Club. Wilander, who also plans to play World Team Tennis in New Jersey this summer, hasn't played a regular tour event since an unrewarding Wimbledon tuneup at Queen's Club in June 1991. (AP)

title: White House Reviewing Trade Pact Compliance
description: The Clinton Administration is closely reviewing whether Japan and other countries have complied with trade agreements with the United States and is prepared to take unilateral action to insure compliance, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said today.

title: For Wickman, It's Easy Till the Last Out
description: The manager said nothing. This is a good thing in Bob Wickman's new world. It was a sunny day in the Bronx, and his sinker had been so consistently effective that Wickman called upon just one changeup all day.

title: New Hope in the Hunt for Top Quarks
description: Physicists reported today that the top quark, a subnuclear particle that is vital to the jigsaw puzzle of matter, remains tantalizingly out of reach. But there are signs that the hunt, which has been under way for 15 years, is at last within sight of its goal.

title: Wallace Stegner Is Dead at 84; Pulitzer Prize-Winning Author
description: Wallace Stegner, the novelist and short-story writer whose work celebrated the American West and won him the country's highest literary awards, died on Tuesday night at St. Vincent Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 84 and lived in Los Altos Hills, Calif.

title: FIRST UNION CORP. (N)
description: The First Union Corporation, a banking company that has been on an acquisition spree, yesterday reported first-quarter earnings of $200 million, more than doubling the restated earnings of 1992's first quarter.

title: Education Board Breakup Urged
description: Three borough presidents proposed yesterday that the city's Board of Education be disbanded and its authority spread among borough boards and local groups.

title: Stephen P. Taylor, 69, Economist And Federal Reserve Statistician
description: Stephen P. Taylor, an economist and a retired official of the Federal Reserve System, died last Friday at a hospital in Arlington, Va., his hometown. He was 69.

title: Pratt & Whitney Threatening To Shut 2 Connecticut Plants
description: Pratt & Whitney threatened today to close two Connecticut plants and to eliminate 2,300 additional jobs unless it receives concessions from its unions and tax breaks from the state.

title: K Swiss Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: As long as there has been a Wicks Law, which is 72 years now, there have been people trying to repeal it.

title: Trevino Is Making Yet Another Adjustment
description: Lee Trevino has been through more passages than any of golf's great champions.

title: A.T.&T. Gets Switch Order
description: Time Warner Inc. picked A.T.& T. yesterday to supply an advanced switching system for a showcase cable television system in Orlando, Fla., that will provide digitally stored movies on demand, two-way data communications and other information and services.

New Film Studio Hires Saatchi Offices
description: Savoy Pictures, a movie studio formed last year, said yesterday that it had named the New York and Torrance, Calif., offices of Saatchi & Saatchi to handle its account, estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

description: b-Included a gain on the sale of riverboat investments. Before the gain, net income was $ 40.3 million, or 31 cents a share.

title: Humphrey Indicted
description: Miami Dolphins running back BOBBY HUMPHREY was indicted Tuesday on aggravated assault and other charges stemming from a Jan. 31 fight at a Columbus, Ga., hotel. (AP)

title: Paine Webber's Net Income Down 4.6% for First Quarter
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. reported yesterday that its net income fell 4.6 percent in the first quarter, in contrast to the large gains posted by two other big brokerage firms, Merrill Lynch & Company and the Bear Stearns Companies.

title: Strictest Curb on Smoking In U.S. Backed by Cuomo
description: Citing new information about the dangers of secondhand tobacco smoke, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed legislation today that would prohibit smoking in schools and many restaurants and prevent advertising for tobacco products on all billboards and signs.

title: No Headline
description: "The boomers are beginning to embrace the new frugality. They are changing from being a group of spenders to being a group of savers." -- DON UNDERWOOD of Merrill Lynch. [ D2:3. ]

title: A New Tack in Fighting Crime Against Cabbies
description: When Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly offered a new plan this week to fight violent crime against cabdrivers, it amounted to an acknowledgement that strategies put into place only a year ago had proven inadequate.

title: Is Yeltsin a)President b)Politician c)Failure?
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin hadn't spent more than two hours in Siberia's coal country, considered one of his most loyal strongholds, before he was accosted by his first angry pensioner of the day.

title: Sports of The Times; Rangers Must Search For a 'Riley'
description: TO the Paramount corporate honchos at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers were money in the bank, but the bank failed.
